Home Die2nite Residents Forum [Contest]Die2Write
On february 15, 2013
Colette

Ladies and Gentlemen, the spiritual successor to the old W2N and previous Die2Nite writing contests is here! This is where talented players from all over the World Beyond gather to show off their literary skill! And this time with a prize! Courtesy of Epoq and MT, the winner of our contest wins the magnificent prize of 15 Hero Days.

I've taken and simplified some of the old contest rules to make them friendlier and more fun. Basically:

Die2Write is a writing contest. All of the Die2Nite players are welcome to participate. The contest is made of three rounds, each with a different theme. All of the qualifying entries will be scored by our set of judges (more on that later). The participant with the highest score at the end of the three rounds will get the prize. So let's get going!

In order to qualify, entries must follow these simple rules:

Rules:

All entries must be related to or based on Die2Nite.
An entry is eligible if it is written between the launch date of the round and the deadline of the round, which is one week from today.
Upon submission, the author assures that the work is fully theirs and is not plagiarized. If plagiarism is discovered, the offender will be permanently banned from the contest. Show some creativity, people!

Judging:

All stories will be judged by our judges panel, as well as our special Guest Judge that many of you will recognize . Stories will be judged on the following categories:

Coherence:

How well-written and structured it is. A good story has to be coherent and be easy to read. Ideas should flow easily.
Good spelling and grammar are always important

Style:

How well narrated and interesting the story is. Keeping the reader interested and eager to keep reading is essential.

Creativity::
How original and fun it is. A predictable and dull story is a boring story. Clich√©s and repetitiveness should be kept to
a minimum

Theme:

How well the story adheres to the round's theme. A story that does not adhere to the theme will be forfeiting these points.

Each category is worth 25 points. Points will be deducted if there are flaws on the story. At the end all points are added up for a story's total, for a maximum of 100. Furthermore, judges can add up to 15 points as a Judge's Bonus if they enjoyed a story particularly. The maximum is still 100 points.

This week's judges are Alisette, lostalien and myself, Colette. Our week's Guest Judge is none other than Annette!


Theme:

To launch this round, the first week is Themeless. That is, you can post whatever you please. Just keep it D2N related please.

The deadline for this round is until Friday 22 after the attack.

Notes:

If you need clarification or help, or if you're interested in taking a judge's seat, please send me a Twinoid message. First come first serve .

Good luck to all, and happy writing!
On february 15, 2013
Anglophone

Is there a recommended word limit?

I'm excited to read the entries.
On february 15, 2013

Id just keep in mind some people wont read pages of a story, if ya want everyone to read it make it shorter. That is just my opinion though

On february 15, 2013
Colette

Exactly. There's no recommended limit, but keep it easy for our judges to read

On february 16, 2013
Coldflame

Sacrifice
Ya know, my old man always told me something.
‚ÄúEveryone has to make sacrifices, son. It‚Äôs not about what the sacrifice is, or how much of it you sacrifice. It‚Äôs about what you sacrifice it for.‚Äù
His words are something I‚Äôve yet to let myself give up on. Everything else, I‚Äôll give up. But I‚Äôll never let morality die. I‚Äôll never let my humanity die.

I‚Äôll never let myself get to their level.

I‚Äôve made mistakes. Lots of them. That‚Äôs an understatement. I‚Äôve made the biggest mistake of all time. I made the fuckup that‚Äôs the reason humanity is in the sorry state it is now. That‚Äôs a story for later. If I ever find another typewriter ribbon.

Today‚Ä¶ hellava day. Just got away from a settlement. There was‚Ä¶ 34 of us, I think. Fought ‚Äòem off good, really. We lasted a good month. Longer than anyone saw coming. One night, though‚Ä¶ We‚Äôd all worked so hard, pushed ourselves to the utmost limits. We were all so fucking drained‚Ä¶ None of us had the energy left to close the goddamned gates. Except me. They‚Äôd already gotten in. More of them were coming soon, it was inevitable. If they were shut then, it woulda been averted.

Nothing‚Äôs ever that simple, though. Not anymore.

Was a one-way trip. Anyone who got near those gates wasn‚Äôt coming back. A few of us had the strength left to move it. None of us had the balls. It was clear we weren‚Äôt gonna make it. I‚Äôd like to tell you this is the part where I manned up and closed them; or someone else did. Nope. Every fucking person in that settlement was devoured in minutes. Not yet, though‚Ä¶

See, I‚Äôd been following the attack patterns. There‚Äôs always a bird of prey flying above it. Like a crow. It was flying awful low. I thought I would just have one last actually tasty meal. With all the others. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôd chosen to instead catch that fucking maggoty bird. Shot it down with my ‚Äòtrusty sidearm‚Äô (Ain‚Äôt so fucking trusty when you only ever had one clip). I snuck around the side of the horde, keeping quiet. Everyone had called me a madman. But, I grabbed it. From underneath the wall. One maggoty, dirty crow.

Brought it back to the workshop, where we‚Äôd started holding up. Cooked it a little, just so it wouldn‚Äôt kill us then. Right as I was about to gut the poor thing, it sprung back to life‚Ä¶

Wasn‚Äôt natural, though. Even the rotters abide by the basic laws of nature, but not this bird. Tore apart half of us in seconds, faster than I could vomit. It was bloody, guts hanging everywhere After I‚Äôd done vomiting, the noise stopped. The zed just stood there, swaying slightly. Something wasn‚Äôt right. Roughly five of us sat there, staring in awe. The bird spoke, in a gravely, dark voice. That incited fear right away.
‚ÄúYou DArE ChaLLenGE ThE MIgHtY CCCCCCCCCCCROOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOWWWWWW???‚Äù
It was clear enough the thing was looking at me. I was only going to live a few more minutes, might as well take a gamble.
‚ÄúYes. I do challenge the ‚Äòmighty crow‚Äô,.‚Äù
‚ÄúYOuR LIVeR LoOKs AWfuL TasTY, ToNIGht. WhhhhYYYYY sHOUldnT I JuST EaT iT? GeTTT OnN yOuR KnneeeeEEEeess ANd BEgggGGGG, ThEEEEn I mIGht JuST OnlY KiLl YoU OnCE‚Ä¶‚Äù
I wasn‚Äôt about to just let myself be bettered by a fucking bird. I can clear he was the eternity-of-torture kind, but frankly that‚Äôs what I deserve for causing the apocalypse. I leapt at him with all my strength.

In seconds, it grabbed hold of me and flew away into the sky at lightspeed. I saw the zombies start to devour my comrades for a splitsecond, and then-

Well, that‚Äôs actually about present day. I woke up in a cave full of anything valuable. I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm in for a lifetime of torture, but it‚Äôs worth it. I sacrificed my eternal soul, to give the finger to whoever‚Äôs shitstirring this mess. It was worth it. I might have been chickenshit back at the town, but at least I got a chance to stand for what I believed in.

On february 16, 2013
Hawager

Blood.

I can remember a time when we weren't used to it. A time when the sight of it would turn our stomachs sour. That was a long time ago, before we came to this settlement, before I became watchmen. It all started on July 11th the sun went down and the horde came out. We weren't ready... not yet... Too many people died because of our failure. The Arenas of Sweat they called it, don't ask me who came up with that stupid name. I'd imagine all that's left of it is chewed up bones and dust. I ran.. We ran... I can still remember his screams. James died to the horde that night. I heard his screams, I heard his bones snap like twigs, I even heard his blood flowing on the cold desert sands. You wanna know what I did? I ran. I ran like any sane person would. I suppose I'm not sane anymore, I've stopped running.

Bang.

I eventually found a new town, The Menacing Barrack of Irma. Another stupid name if you ask me, I've yet to meet anyone in town named Irma and anyone I ask has nothing to say. I'm a newcomer, fresh meat, they expected me to be dead before the night was over. I proved them wrong. When the horde came to the gates, I didn't run this time. I stood with a few other stoic survivors, watchmen they called themselves, when the gate shattered and the horde rushed in. We met them, A war cry in our throats and weapons in our hands. I was a new blood, the only weapon they were willing to spare to me was a human femur. I met the hordes charge all the same.
Skulls cracked and broke, blood slashed out from knife wounds, I even say two watchmen fighting with furniture! Furniture god damn it! Can you even imagine? I saw one lady smash a zed to pieces with a Beer Fridge! Poor bugger never even had a chance. After the dust settled and our blood cooled off we had to deal with the inevitable.. Our own casualties. We watered the ones we could. We tossed the rest. Huh? Whats that? Oh yes, back there to the left? Yes, that is the bone I used that night. I've used it on many watches, not failed me yet.

Bang.

Yes... Yes I do think it's getting louder... No, It's nothing to worry about. Anyways, where was I? Oh yes, those of us who survived the night went about our normal routines for the day before we tucked in for the night. One thing I don't think any of you ever understood about us was that yes, we defended you, we fight hard every night for your safety. We also busted our asses everyday making sure projects got done and that people who were stranded got saved.

Bang. Bang.

Now now, don't you worry yourselves about that, hush all of you. I'm sure its just my fellow watchmen erecting the last of our defenses for the night.

Bang. Bang. Bang.

You all need to understand what makes us different. We fight for your safety, not because of courage, not because of honor, but because each of us has a sin in our past that we must atone for. Mine? Mine.. was.. leaving James to die that day... I swore that if I survived the desert I'd never run again. I haven't, not to this day.

Bang. Bang. BANG. BANG.

Today though I did run... But I ran for you my fellow survivors. Here in a few minuets that doors going to open. Despite everything I told you, It will not be my fellow watchmen that enter. It'll be the source of all our nightmares. We noticed a steady rise in the zed population and we knew we couldn't fight them all, we knew tonight there would be to many.

Bang. BANG. BANG. BANG
.
Listen to me, this is very important! Hush! Quite now listen to me! Any second now that doors going to cave in, I'm going to charge them. I'm going to kill as many of those twisted parodies of life that I can. I'm going to clear a path for you. Head for the screaming saws, turn them off and head into the wasteland. I know it sounds insane! If you stay here you die, out there you have a chance.

BANG. BANG. BANG. BANG.

Get ready... It'll happen anytime now...

BANG.

The door came crashing in, and he didn't run, not away at the very least. He hit the foremost ranks of the horde with two water bombs instantly making a hole for all of us to get outside, In that moment a few of the citizens found the fire in their belly, the stood with him, they took weapons off the wall and charged the horde along side him. He fought the zeds back with his trusty bone urging us to leave them, to get out of town. We did, I could hear crunching bone as we ran... Then I heard the screams.. the first watchmen to die that night... I'd imagine he wasn't the last. We made it to the screaming saws and got out of the town. We survived, we made it to a new location, we built walls and we built homes. Most of all though we continued the one thing left to us from Irma.

The tradition of the watchmen. We stand for those who can't stand for themselves, we fight for those to tired from the days work who can't do it themselves, and we kill in the memory of those who saved our lives that night. My father was wrong about one thing, not all watchmen fight to forgive a sin. Me... You... All of us...

We fight for hope.
On february 16, 2013
Joanne
Community Companion

Wow fantastic!!

You have all set the bar so high

On february 16, 2013
Maxwell

Where am I? I thought to myself as I sit in this chair.
The chair its self was rickety and my scrumming didn‚Äôt help its case. There was molding flesh on the floor in front of me and it was green and a shade of violet. I looked up and saw that the shelter I was in was in deep repair. Planks hanging from the ceiling, floorboards ripped up from there places, the door was hanging on by a hinge, the walls all tattered with what looked like holes from something fired at great magnitude. Not much was left here; something was left on the stove in the kitchen. Looks like somebody was cooking something but never finished. The bathroom reeked and it was just a horrid smell of feces and urine. The shower curtains and the toilet was in shambles. There was a dead animal in the hallway, probably a cat or a small dog; either way it was dead. A hellhole was this place no doubts about it what interested me was how I myself was still alive. I could see a little bit out the window, a barren wasteland, rocks, dead bodies, completely lifeless and no sign of any life. I see weird beings flying through the sky, smashing thing on the ground. I could not call this life. It could be life there was no need as for it was a terrible sight in its self they didn‚Äôt even look human. Human, the thought crossed my mind at that moment. What happened to everyone and was I the only one left? Every possible thing went through my head. I had faint memories of what happened. I remembered that there were crashing sounds, things being knocked over, it wasn‚Äôt a person though, it was some type of‚Ä¶ of‚Ä¶ horrific monster. I couldn‚Äôt even say it was a monster it was far more terrifying. It gave me chills just thinking about it.



Just then a clutter of things fell outside this run-down shack, making a terrible ruckus. I heard many different shrieks it wasn‚Äôt even bearable sound. I was dazed couldn‚Äôt tell up from down, and left from my right. The scream was agonizing if I didn‚Äôt know any better, I could be deaf if I wasn‚Äôt already somewhat out of it. It was terrible I was just clutching my ears wondering what the hell was going on. Then, out of nowhere a vile being pushed in the door. Not even pushed in, launched the door across the room and the door disintegrated into a million splinters against the opposing wall. It was just a horrid thing, had green liquid dripping from its fangs. It had no eyes and two holes where the nose ‚Äúshould‚Äù have been. I really was hopping I could of remembered something from this but I was just panicked, everything was rushing, my heart, my thoughts, my sweat. Everything was just in a state of shock in the presence of this thing that looked like it came from hell. I thought to myself this is it. Not even a second to regain myself and not even a minute to figure out where exactly I was, nothing it all seem to end here. Something else rang out; I saw a spark from the window on the far side out of the corner of my eye. The being must have heard it and it had only inched its head to my right. Its head had then at that point exploded into mangled mess of blood and what appeared to be bits of the brain. Shades of green, red, and magenta came gushing out of its head and I became even sicker than before. I had lost control of my body functions and proceeded to puke all over it and the floor. It was the most retched feeling ever, my guts were churning and my brain began to gasp for air as for I was vomiting a lot. I looked up for a second and saw what looked to be a military man. He was dressed like one that is, he had the gear on and everything, the helmet, rucksack, what looked like to be an M4, and his night vision goggles on top of his helmet. He looked at me for a sec and then his eyes got huge. He then grew a huge grin on his face, just seeing him made me feel so much better. I then continued to puke on the floor after that thought though.

Here's mine I hope it counts
On february 16, 2013
DaryleDixon

On february 17, 2013
TOShokking

Decrepid Pits. I remember that name. I will always remember that name.

Decrepid Pits was in a region far from here. You can't visit it now - by the time you read this, it's probably turned to ash and rubble, consumed by the ever-shifting sands.
When I first hauled myself through those gates, it was with two friends. But I don't know the other four people there now, standing, watching... waiting.

It was a Saturday... Perhaps a Sunday, when I first went through that gate. I should know - weekends never worked out for me in the end. As we crossed the boundary, we saw the frame of an abandoned outpost. Little more than a handful of deserted camp beds and a rickety shack with nothing in it. Over time, of course, more people arrived. We never checked them. We just... assumed... they would be fine to stay. We never checked their motives for coming, or why they left where they did to get here...

Day one. Usually one of the toughest days, it seems. Nobody knows what the plan is. Mainly because there isn't one - forty strangers walk into a fort, you don't get a magic slip of paper that unquestionably tells you what to do. There's always a level of debate, of uncertainty, the feeling that perhaps what you do right now, will determine the lives of everyone around you. And it does. More than you think.

We got through the first four days perfectly, or so it seemed. We lost one or two people here and there - in the apocalypse, it's inevitable. We stuck a plank in the ground, and moved on. You can't waste time thinking about the past. Ha. Can't think about the past, but you're still reading this, aren't you? And I'm still writing, because for now, I still have a story to tell.

After the fifth night, things started to skew a bit. The message boards were almost empty, conversation seemed to almost cease. What had been a busy town seemed to cough to a halt, the people moving lethargically from place to place, mechanically doing what they had to. I have no doubt that we could have survived. But one person had other ideas.

We may never know why he decided to do it. But he took his Watch position beside the gate, stood blindly out facing the oncoming horde. But did he prepare for impact? Not really. He was on their side. He was the Day Six doorman, letting them in for their evening meal.

We lost twenty two people that night. I still don't know how I survived. When the attack was over, we just headed straight to our homes, trying not to think about the massacre. When we woke the next day though, did we have a hell of a job clearing the streets. I'll never forget that sight.

We've managed to drag the wreck of a town we have through a few more days. I've lost track of how many days since we arrived for the first time... nine, ten, perhaps eleven? It won't be long now. Five people can't hold off the armies of the undead forever, and we're in the loop of their rotting, decaying gallows. It's only a matter of time before we're choked, left with nothing to defend ourselves with but our bare hands against the flood of corpses.

So here I am now, rattling on. Writing my tale, telling my story to the next generation who decide to settle here. We weren't so lucky, what makes you think you are? You're in the same boat as us... ultimate destruction, just a few kilometers away. It's never far. But if you are set on surviving here, remember this: Nobody has ever seen it except me. That little flicker of black in the sky after the attack ends. I swear that... thing... sweeps it's eye over the carnage when we're done. Every day, it drops a paper, and leaves. Maybe fi you can find out where it comes from, you can survive.

But you don't look so special to me. You look like the same people who are out there now, staring out into the wastelands. Good intentions, bad implementation.

For now, I'm just hiding here. They can't force me out of my house. I'm going to watch them die the same way I saw everyone else go. And when they have - I'll take all I want from here. It's not the laborer who reaps the rewards - it's the person who can hold their home longest.

I think I can. Can you? I'd like to see you try...
On february 17, 2013
MadDonut

The King of Nowhere

There in the dark shadows of the small decayed room sat a rather well dressed man who sat in an old wooden rocking chair. His face was illuminated in the darkness by the small tender flame on the end of his fine Cuban cigar as he rocked back and forth staring out through a gap the wall that served at a window. His face was smooth as a baby's bottom and his eyes twinkled a devilish charm. The man's name was Styles Moely, but people around here call him Sly. The man was smart, strong, and charming. That's why they made him king.

"King of Nowhere," He humorously mumbled to himself. It was true that his kingdom was in a rather isolated spot. The wasteland spread out forever in all direction and even the best scout they had available couldn't find civilization for miles. Alive civilization, that is. There were plenty of sand eroded and forgotten structures that had remained inhabited throughout the years, but though the inhabitants wore the skin of the previous occupants, they weren't the same. The things that removed them and took their identity were not human, let alone an animal. They were feral, hungry, and most of all, dead.

Sly had wound himself up in this small little town that had been protecting itself from both the sands and undead for years. The large wall that held out against these forces was built with a mix-match of wooden, metal, and whatever else was laying around, just like the town buildings themselves. The original townspeople were welcoming and kind; that would be their downfall. Soon, as tired survivors marching along the sandy wasteland began stumbling upon their shelter, the town grew and grew until they were forty strong. Then, like a switch, the town sealed the gates and refused to have anymore survivors enter. Supplies ran low and what housing space they had room for was damp, cramped, and poorly lamped. That's when Sly stepped forth, with many people behind him, to calm the situation. The citizens adored him for his charming features, wise words, and GETTING IT DONENESS (a popular phrase spoken by Mayor Fasi's followers). He gave speeches, blamed others, created mobs, killed a few good citizens, but in the end, he'd made them happy. They trusted him now. They trusted him completely.

"They trusted me too much," said Sly with a painful sadness as he sat up and walked to the window. He gazed out from the watchtower penthouse he had spent his glory days in and looked around at his little kingdom. He looked down and spotted the town homes and the groups of people walking about the streets. Sly cleared his dry throat and roared with his strong, booming voice, "Citizens! Come gather around the tower! I wish to.. to tell you how deeply sorry I am." Though the desert wind blew howling mad, the citizens heard and began making their way to the base of the tower. "I have betrayed you. I tricked you, played tricks on your mind. I gave you words of comfort and strength to lure you into a false state of safety." Sly's eyes began to water as the citizens came closer. "A man can kill, rob, and rape, but I find lying to be the hardest sin to bear of all. I-I... I am truly sorry."

Sly began to cry as his cigar trembled from his lip and down to the crowd below. The tower was beginning to sway as the citizens beat their fists upon the coarse wooden base, but they were not fists of anger, dear reader, they were fists of hunger. The townsfolk had been brutally butchered and slain by the night's attack before joining the ranks of the enemy themselves. They had no warning despite the fact Sly knew that the defenses would not hold. He knew he had the power to alert everyone, but he instead chose to give them a last shed of comfort by telling them soft lies and hiding the coming storm behind his words. Sly leaned further out the window as he continued to sob, his salty tears plummeting softly down on the horde bellow, causing small sizzles and pops on their diseased flesh. He was leaning half way out the window before speaking, with suppressed sobs, to himself, "I was a drifter and now I have become the King of Nowhere." He balanced his gut on the window as the tower creaked. "Long live the king, you cheating lying bastard."

And with that, whether coincidence or fate, the wall snapped from the rotting room and Sly slipped out as he and the debris came crashing down. Sly didn't die immediately as he smacked hard into sandy ground. No, he laid there, disoriented as the town surrounded him in a putrid circle of fleshy arms and bared teeth. They ate him, bit by bit, as he succumbed to the violent wounds. In the darkness of night, a small glint sparked on a nearby rooftop, and with a flutter of black feathers, a large bird soared into the moonlight sky to give a nasty caw. Within minutes, the dark speck disappeared in the sky as the grueling sound of snapped bones and tearing flesh echoed the dunes for miles, past the abandoned structures and much beyond where the scout had daringly explored. The King of Nowhere was dead.
On february 17, 2013
TheStaff
MadDonutThe King of Nowhere

There in the dark shadows of the small decayed room sat a rather well dressed man who sat in an old wooden rocking chair. His face was illuminated in the darkness by the small tender flame on the end of his fine Cuban cigar as he rocked back and forth staring out through a gap the wall that served at a window. His face was smooth as a baby's bottom and his eyes twinkled a devilish charm. The man's name was Styles Moely, but people around here call him Sly. The man was smart, strong, and charming. That's why they made him king.

"King of Nowhere," He humorously mumbled to himself. It was true that his kingdom was in a rather isolated spot. The wasteland spread out forever in all direction and even the best scout they had available couldn't find civilization for miles. Alive civilization, that is. There were plenty of sand eroded and forgotten structures that had remained inhabited throughout the years, but though the inhabitants wore the skin of the previous occupants, they weren't the same. The things that removed them and took their identity were not human, let alone an animal. They were feral, hungry, and most of all, dead.

Sly had wound himself up in this small little town that had been protecting itself from both the sands and undead for years. The large wall that held out against these forces was built with a mix-match of wooden, metal, and whatever else was laying around, just like the town buildings themselves. The original townspeople were welcoming and kind; that would be their downfall. Soon, as tired survivors marching along the sandy wasteland began stumbling upon their shelter, the town grew and grew until they were forty strong. Then, like a switch, the town sealed the gates and refused to have anymore survivors enter. Supplies ran low and what housing space they had room for was damp, cramped, and poorly lamped. That's when Sly stepped forth, with many people behind him, to calm the situation. The citizens adored him for his charming features, wise words, and GETTING IT DONENESS (a popular phrase spoken by Mayor Fasi's followers). He gave speeches, blamed others, created mobs, killed a few good citizens, but in the end, he'd made them happy. They trusted him now. They trusted him completely.

"They trusted me too much," said Sly with a painful sadness as he sat up and walked to the window. He gazed out from the watchtower penthouse he had spent his glory days in and looked around at his little kingdom. He looked down and spotted the town homes and the groups of people walking about the streets. Sly cleared his dry throat and roared with his strong, booming voice, "Citizens! Come gather around the tower! I wish to.. to tell you how deeply sorry I am." Though the desert wind blew howling mad, the citizens heard and began making their way to the base of the tower. "I have betrayed you. I tricked you, played tricks on your mind. I gave you words of comfort and strength to lure you into a false state of safety." Sly's eyes began to water as the citizens came closer. "A man can kill, rob, and rape, but I find lying to be the hardest sin to bear of all. I-I... I am truly sorry."

Sly began to cry as his cigar trembled from his lip and down to the crowd below. The tower was beginning to sway as the citizens beat their fists upon the coarse wooden base, but they were not fists of anger, dear reader, they were fists of hunger. The townsfolk had been brutally butchered and slain by the night's attack before joining the ranks of the enemy themselves. They had no warning despite the fact Sly knew that the defenses would not hold. He knew he had the power to alert everyone, but he instead chose to give them a last shed of comfort by telling them soft lies and hiding the coming storm behind his words. Sly leaned further out the window as he continued to sob, his salty tears plummeting softly down on the horde bellow, causing small sizzles and pops on their diseased flesh. He was leaning half way out the window before speaking, with suppressed sobs, to himself, "I was a drifter and now I have become the King of Nowhere." He balanced his gut on the window as the tower creaked. "Long live the king, you cheating lying bastard."

And with that, whether coincidence or fate, the wall snapped from the rotting room and Sly slipped out as he and the debris came crashing down. Sly didn't die immediately as he smacked hard into sandy ground. No, he laid there, disoriented as the town surrounded him in a putrid circle of fleshy arms and bared teeth. They ate him, bit by bit, as he succumbed to the violent wounds. In the darkness of night, a small glint sparked on a nearby rooftop, and with a flutter of black feathers, a large bird soared into the moonlight sky to give a nasty caw. Within minutes, the dark speck disappeared in the sky as the grueling sound of snapped bones and tearing flesh echoed the dunes for miles, past the abandoned structures and much beyond where the scout had daringly explored. The King of Nowhere was dead.

Woah...I admit it gave me feels.Nice one Costumed One...nice one...
On february 17, 2013
TOShokking

I like that story Donut!

But where were the delicious bakery treats in that story?

On february 18, 2013
SaucyemmettC

Pain

Are you going to die? HAH! Death doesn't exist. Sure you'll "die", but you don't really "die" die. Some people believe that death does however. That "final escaping place", that "ending suffering", that "true happiness". Do I believe? HAH! That's a difficult question to answer. I'd guess I'd have to say I don't believe, but I sure HOPE to hell that it does. Life... Life is shit. It doesn't matter what you do, you WILL feel it. We all do, that thing, that PAIN... Pain... Why? Why does it burden us. Life would be easy without pain. Some people say the pain doesn't affect them any more, that they have built a resistance. HAH! Sure they can tolerate it longer than the others but they all succumb to it in the end. Pain is inescapable, it consumes us all eventually. The only way out is death. But death does not exist. You know, HAHAHA, the thought hadn't even crossed my mind before that man. The Man. But he was hardly a man at all. What kind of man kills without reason, steals without cause, and runs off to greet false death's embrace? SHUT UP AN SIT DOWN! HAHAHA, because you see. It got me wondering. Why would anyone do that. And then there was more men. Harbingers of grief, traitors of humanity, doormmen of pain. There were so many, stealing, murdering, they all did such unthinkable things, and for no reason anyone could understand. HAH! People would say they went insane, that they were just plain evil. No, that wasn't it. Their eyes. I could see it in their eyes. They knew something. But what? Why? And then I heard it. That blast. As soon as I heard that blast I knew my answer was imminent, I ran, ran toward that blast that others were cowering from. The blast came from a tent, but when I reached for the tent flap some THING flew out and attacked me. It screeched the most painful sound, and slashed my face up with its most painful claws. And then it was gone. Where, I don't know, but what I do know I'll tell you now, so stop your squirming and listen closely. Do you know what I saw in that tent? HAH! I saw a dead man. But not just a dead man... A DEAD dead man. I knew it as soon as I saw him, looking into those eyes... There was no life left in him and there never would be again. I wondered who he was, and how that lucky bastard escaped this, I knew it had to do with the thing that attacked me before, but how? And how could I do it. How could I escape? Others approached cautiously, all unknowing of what wonder they were witnessing. One man walked up and spat on the dead dead man. I remember his words well, ‚ÄúThis here was Cornealeos, a bastard known for his violent acts. It seems his actions caught up with him‚Äù. Everything fell into place. Life is pain. Therefore by enduring this pain you are living life, but the only way to end life is to create pain. HAHAHA! And so I began plotting. How was I going to create enough pain to die? I could follow in the others footsteps, stealing and murdering. But their actions were recoverable. They aimed too high, and their attacks were too spread out. No, HAHAHA, you have to hit small and hit hard. The first was this cute little girl. I crawled into her tent one night and bashed her over the head. She went out like a light, HAHAHA. Then I dragged her back here, where you sit so patiently now, HAHA, and I started on her toes. She awoke at once, shrieking like a banshee. HAHAHAHA, much like you will. But little good it did her and little good it will do you. Once I had her toes I mover up to her nose. I used this to pull it off. Then it was her ears. HAHA, oh how she struggled when I started cutting them up! Next was just a beating. Just a continuous beat you know. Thunk Thunk Thunk Thunk Thunk Thunk Thunk‚Ä¶ She passed out after only ten minutes. I woke her back up by removing her tongue. I didn‚Äôt know what I was doing back then. I was careless. She died after an hour. HAHAHA, but I‚Äôve been getting better. That kid lasted bout 3, then his brother 5. HAH! Last one lasted 3 days. I wonder how long you will? But don‚Äôt worry, you won‚Äôt die. You‚Äôll wish death upon yourself, but you and I both know death doesn‚Äôt exist.
On february 19, 2013
Juha

The diary of mad lonely man



8 days... already 8 days since everyone went to outside to get supplies and did not return...

in fact, they DID return, i saw John last night, banging head into town gates, john have never been the "sharpest pen" in our town, why he uses head when he have ARMS? well, atleast other of arms... HAH!

Its silent, too silent, i know those tricky, greenish fellows are planning somethink! Atleast im safe in town we found couple weeks ago, or rather months, im not sure anymore

8 days... already 8 days... i wonder if there are still anyone behind those gates... not like i would open them if someone happen to be there... HAH!

Im low on food, there is only couple cans of corn, and one half-rotten fat cat i managed to get here behind eastern wall... how? Duct tape and long stick, you can do ANYTHINK with duct tape!

Atleast im not bored here! this little boy jack left gameboy here... before he got devoured by jawless zombie, dont ask how, even i dont know... HAH! ... i just hope that someone would be here to hear my puns...

I have been examing those little, damned thinks... i have very good subject here: tied up zombie we caught to find weak spots and cure for this disease... we had change to find those, if just that brainless John wouldn't trip and cut ropes! we lost many good friends before we managed to catch that zombie again... Robert got bitten to neck when he was eating cereals... HAHAH!

Hahah...

I hate this world, why it had to be me who kept guard in town while others went outside to get ambushed?

I hate this world, why it did not let me die before my friends?

I HATE this world, why nobody haven't rescued us... me yet?

I just hope that those zombies finaly manage to break gates this night, gates are weakened because of nightly attack... i havent been able to sleep because of zombies having "De Destroy gate party" every night... HAH!

I just dont have guts to end my life, neither i have strenght to open gates myself... how long i still have to wait until i can join yet again with my friends?

I hope not long... 8 days have already been too long...
On february 19, 2013
Sniluey

The deep discussion

A surprisingly calm evening. It was half an hour till the usual attack. Fred, also called scrapster, was sitting at the gates waiting. He was one of the watchmen ordered to keep the gates in check. He knew there was one more, but who? That he didn`t know. Suddenly he heard steps coming towards him. He picked his cricket bat and shouted out.

Fred: Whose there!?

???: You should know better. Clean your eyes.

It was Randy, a guardian. He was considerably bigger than Fred, almost 10 inches taller, and he carried an even larger shield with him. Fred turned little bit red from shame.

Fred: Should have known you were gonna be the second watchman today.

Randy: yup, you should have. I see your well equipped for today. Though maybe one water gun would not hurt...

Fred: Nah, didn`t save my water ration today. I think we are fine, what, with you having 2 of these bats with you.

Randy: Well, you know, don`t wanna risk dying.

Fred: Yeah, yeah...

A little bit awkward silence filled the air. It was pretty boring, but still somehow scary. Suddenly, Randy opened his mouth.

Randy: Do you ever wonder how we ended up getting this screwed? With all of these zombies?

Fred: Beats me. I know, that the shaman has a theory about that. Two in fact. One of them includes an intense nuclear war...

Randy: That feels a little bit stupid. Like some stupid movie or a kids show.

Fred: Well, it is kinda nicer than his other theory.

Randy: Spit it out. In this place, there is no real need to be "Nice."

Fred: We are apparently in hell. Like in Dantes Inferno.

Randy: He really jumped into the worst possible thing didn`t he.

Fred: Yup, but there is some sense in it atleast.

Randy: Like what?

Fred: Well, In dantes inferno, the hell has different levels. everyone is worse than the other, and the devil watches over every single one of them.

Randy: And, if I may ask, who is the devil?

Fred: According to the shaman, the crows.

randy: *Pfft* I know they are scary at this time of the day, but seriously? A black bird is the devil? He has been smoking a bit too much.

Fred: Well, the stages of hell are all here.

Randy: tell me. Shamans drugged up stories are always the best.

Fred: Well the first level is us. Here in this town. Apparently, even if we die, we will just resurrect. Basicly, our punishment, is to live in this world, without a shred of hope to survival, but we can still enjoy the life the best we can with alcohol and other people.

Randy: Come on. That could never be true.

Fred: The second level is the animals in the desert. They can do NOTHING, but wait for their imminent destruction, either by us or the zombies.

Randy: ...

Fred: The third level is the zombies. They have no hope of ever being human again. They always feel pain, they always hunger for the flesh of those who have survived better than them, and never stop. They, as you could call them, are abandoned by the god.

randy: Okay, stop that. I know that that must be a lie! There is no wa...

Fred: Do you remember where you came from? How you ended up here? How we all are wearing the same clothes? It must be someones doing.

Randy: A mere citizen shouldn`t kno...

Fred: Don`t you remember? The shaman told me this theory. If it is true, there might be even a heaven, and after suffering here, we might go there.

Randy: But what if there isn`t?

Suddenly, a huge growling noise filled the air. They were coming, and very fast.

Fred: Okay, now just get ready. You`re the stronger one here so...

Randy: Dangit all...

That night, everyone survived under the crows watchful eye.

On february 23, 2013
Colette

So, the Round 1 of this contest is now over, and Round 2 begins!

The results and judge scores for this round will be posted here on the next Tuesday after the attack.

The theme for Round 2 is Infection. How and why your neighbors are infected? How does the infection spread? Be creative, have fun!
On february 23, 2013
TOShokking

The four survivors picked their way through the ruined facility, looking for anything they might be able to use to survive, for just one more day.
The apocalypse had occurred no more than two or three months ago, yet already everything was deserted, ruined, turning to dust in the state of neglect.
Fortunately, most of the buildings still stood. Or at least, the shells of them. Most of the interiors were stripped away by raiders, coated in the entrails and... bits... of people who'd tried to fortify the position... or both.
One of them watched the door, the other three splitting up to look around.
The first survivor scanned the surroundings. It was astonishing how quickly the virus could infect people, and how quickly the infection had spread.
Then, he saw the glowing red light. It emanated from a computer panel. State of the art, somehow missed by the raiders. He brushed it off, and pressed the on-screen keys.

[Cantrex OS 1.14]
Enter password: []________

A password. Typical. Fortunately, Technicians have a way with keys of all kinds. And viruses come in more than one form in the modern world.
The flash stick flashed as it uploaded it's destructive capabilities on the hard drive.

[Cantrex OS 1.14]
Enter password: ^^^^^^^^[]
Password accepted.

Excellent. He browsed around the pages for a short while, eventually finding the folder marked Observations.
He opened it, and began reading.

[Observation #382]
Cantrex Formula 3
Subject 112
-
Subject Information:
Average weight
Average height
No history of any lasting or hereditary illness
-
Observations
[00:00] Subject injected with experimental formula 3
[00:30] Subject began displaying symptoms of paranoia, watching nearby scientists intently.
[00:45] Scientists left the room, and began watching from the one-way mirrors.
[01:30] Subject forced their way loose of the chair, and began tapping on the walls, muttering that there was food there.
[02:30] Subject seemed to be trying to smell something in the air, and began banging on the door with more vigour than previously.
[04:00] Scientists changed shift.
[04:15] A chance power cut closed down the use of the one-way mirrors. Two scientists entered the chamber, the other four went to supervise the activation of the reserve power supply.
[04:30] Power restored. The two scientists and the subject were all missing from the chamber. One of the two one-way mirrors was destroyed and there was a substantial quantity of blood in both rooms. The mirror room door had been destroyed.
[05:00] Full quarantine was finally put in place. This observation was declared closed.

Interesting.
Under the Observations folder, a System Log folder.
This was his next observation.

[Cantrex OS 1.14]
[Security System Log]
[23:58] Test room 1 door opened.
[23:59] Test room 1 door closed.
[00:04] Test room 1 door opened.
[00:05] Test room 1 door closed.
[00:44] Test room 1 door opened.
[00:46] Test room 1 door closed.
[00:51] Test room 1 mirror rooms active.
[01:34] Test room 1 restraining chair compromised. Test subject loose in test room. Security of Test room 1 is maintained. Do not enter the test room.
[04:12] Test room 1 door locks overridden.
[04:13] Test room 1 door opened.
[04:14] Test room 1 door closed.
[04:16] Test room 2 door opened.
[04:19] Power to facility Block 4 lost. Do not open test room doors. Remain in secured rooms until power is restored. Do not override locks unless absolutely necessary.
[04:22] Test room 1 mirror A compromised. Evacuate Block 4. Do not re-enter Block 4 until cleared by Security.
[04:30] Temporary power supply active. Door locks remain active. Do not enter test rooms unless necessary.
[04:53] Unknown contact detected in corridors of Block 4. Quarantine active. Do not enter Block 4. Do not override quarantine until cleared by Security.
[04:58] Quarantine overriden.
[05:01] Security de-activated.

Security was de-activated?
He glanced around. The others were in the other rooms, searching the debris.
The radio buzzed. Moving down the corridor. Watch our backs. No problem.
A glowing icon on the desktop caught his eye. README.
He read it. It said nothing except the following lines:

THEY ARE HERE
I HEAR THEM
THE QUARANTINE HAS BEEN REMOVED
KILL THEM OR WE ARE DOOMED
WE CANT SURVIVE
SOME OF THEM LOOK JUST LIKE US
TRUST NOONEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEERETHTJYLU

He read it again.
Some of them look just like us. Trust no-one.
He wasn't sure what caught his attention first. The sound of rubble crunching underfoot, or the reflection in the screen.
"You're done already? I thought there was more to the corridor than that."
No response. He turned.
One of the others stood there. Covered in blood, he looked like he'd walked straight out of hell.
"What happened?"
The message glowed on the screen. Trust no-one. The other survivor just watched him closely.
Then the penny dropped.
Trust no-one. Test room 2 opened but never closed. The subject was never accounted for. They look just like us. They never even accounted for the quarantine being lifted early. Why...
The other survivor just watched. And smiled, a smile that radiated pure hunger.
The technician dived for the machete. But wasn't fast enough.

Nobody heard the screams. There was nobody left in the town to hear.
The door log registered one person going out. Just like the last person to leave, three months ago.

Sorry it's so long, I got bored waiting for work!

Sacrifice by Coldflame: 343/400
On february 27, 2013
Sniluey

The cure seekers



"Can you stop puking blood? Kinda creeps me out"

"Yeah, like I could do something about it. You are not the sick one here..."

"I have been punched in the gut. I think I know enough about it"

"Well, atleast we can get more supplies..."

"Can`t be any worse. You didn¬¥t dare to tell me you were sick before yesterday, so I couldn`t even try to help you."

"..."

"Well, the bank is there... Or so I atleast think."

"Kinda flat."

"Help me dig stuff up from there, so we can leave as soon as..."

"Uuugh..."

"Okay, just me digging then..."

A long while passes by...

"Gotta thank the leader for inventing "the pillbox" idea. Othervise all the pills would be mush by now."

"I think my body is STARTING to turn into mush..."

"Ummm... random question..."

"What?"

"Can you read gibberish?"

"Don`t tell me..."

"Yup, not a single name is comprehensible."

"Crap..."

"I know!"

"That is a terrible idea and we both know it!"

"Well, we gotta save you somehow. Better to have funky brains than no brains at all."

"Throw a pill."

"First one."

"*gulp*"

"Well?"

"Nothing... A dud I guess... The zombie cure pill takes effect immediately, what I remember..."

"Okay... Try this black one. Fresh from the package even."

"*gulp* ...Oh goouuuuuurrgghhhh......"

"You okay mate?!"

"I think you gave me laxative..."

"Ummm... Sorry?"

"You should be! I think I`m trying to poop an intestine here because of you!"

"Okay, no more black pills then..."

After a long while of disgusting stuff, and cleaning the same stuff...

"You ready for the next one? This one is green."

"I really don`t think I should test these. I already feel addicted."

"well one more won`t hurt then."

"*sigh* *gulp* ..."

"Feel any better?"

"Actually yeah. My body feels like it has muscles again. And my heart seems to be bumping we√∂√∂√∂√∂√∂√∂√∂√∂√∂√∂√∂√∂√∂√∂√∂√∂rgh...."

"Darn mate! You are puking blood!"

"Yup... steroids... ugh..."

"Ummm... we have only 2 kinds of pills left luckily... I think. Another one from the box. It has nice animals on it."

"Let us hope for some kids medicine. That would not hurt this much atleast... *Gulp*"

"One more pill left after this. How do you feel?"

"Pretty good tasting pill. Sadly seems it has no effeeeee?"

"Oh god... OH GOD!"

"WOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!"

"Hide it! HIDE IT!"

"Well, now I atleast feel better."

"I also notice your need of new pants... Let`s see the box again... Oh dang..."

"Let me guess..."

"It is horse medicine... And you don`t wanna know what for."

"Believe me, I do. Sadly all the towns womens are already dead."

"Just eat the last pill..."

"*gulp* zzsskkijj..."

"Now you are foaming man! You are freaking foaming and shaking!"

"Huh...huh... Mate, we got the jackpot... I don`t taste blood in my mouth anymore... I can breath!"

"Marvellous! Now bring your muscly body here and dig this stuff up!"

"Oh! Yes, immediately!"


THE END
On february 27, 2013
TheStaff

I would like to imagine this in webcomic form.
On february 28, 2013
Hawager

"Infection. Little 'i' as apposed to big 'I'. We all know about The Infection. The walking corpses outside our gates, those animated cadavers that think of nothing but grinding our flesh between their teeth. We all know about that Infection. We all know how to try and avoid it. Don't get bit, don't get overwhelmed outside the gates, and most of all pray they don't choose your home that night. We know how to deal with that Infection."

"But there is a hidden killer here in these dusty town steads. Infections. Rampaging bacteria that overwhelm the last of your bodies defenses. They get into your body and tears it down from within. We've regressed so far. Modern Medicine can knock out an infection with one pill. Paracetiod, a wonder drug. One of those babies and you feel brand knew. You might even be able to forget about this hell we live in... For a time."

The man speaking paused. He knew he was giving the poor wretches false hope. He had to though, he had to make them willing to take the drugs. Even if they had no chance of saving them.

"Unfortunately Paracetiod is rare, very rare, and without out it... your chances are slim. From our estimates you have a seventy-five percent chance to die in this hell we call home. There are few options for those with an infection. Worse still... If you fall to this infection. We have to deal with you as a member of the other Infection."

"That's why we've locked you in old man Jenkins' house. One way or another you all have an infection. We've locked you in here because we have no more Paracetiod, no more wonder drug, and very little options left to us."

He stopped again and observed his 'patients'. He could see the terror in their eyes now, he'd just pulled their high hopes right out from under them. He told them there was a cure then he slapped them across the face with the knowledge that they didn't have it. Now they understand why they are here. Now they know why we had to cage them away like animals. At least they think they understand.

"The town has provided us with some unmarked medical products. Five of them, one for each of you. We have no guarantee this will work but it is worth a shot. We also have one other... option. This my friends is Cyanide. Will put you lights out seconds after you take it, once your dead we can deal with you body and guarantee you want harm our former neighbors. We have two of them." Another lie, the man thought, but one that needed to be told. "Any takers? No? Not yet? Alright lets start experimenting then shall we?"
The man dropped one package of unlabeled drugs into the room, the infected residents played a game of Rock, Paper, Scissors to see who would go first. A woman won. The man couldn't remember her name. Probably for the best that way. She took the pill and washed it down with her water ration. She waited a moment before she began to shake her head. She told her fellows that she didn't feel like it did anything. It didn't do anything at all. She broke down crying and sat in a corner of the room. The next man seeing that the girls result elected to take one of the cyanide tablets. He did. He stopped breathing before his body even hit the ground.

The next two men were brothers and asked if they could go at the same time. The man behind the glass obliged them and dropped two more unlabeled drugs into the room. Both of the men felt an effect but found it hard to tell if they had been cured. One broke down. screaming at his shadow trying to hide from everyone's eyes, trying to hide his eyes, to hide the terror written there. The other brother became hooked. It was easy to see, he was hyper, alert, and asking if he could have more. He became agitated when told that no more would be provided to him.

The last subject, a woman, chose to take the last cyanide. Seeing the man catatonic with fear had broken her will. Now she only wanted to end it all. So she did. The pill went down then she did as well. The man behind the glass turned to the mayor with a weary smile.

"Experiment complete." The mayors eyes grew wide as he saw Watchmen enter the room and kill off the poor wretches who had survived the ordeal.

"None of them were infected were they?" The man smiled. "You'll sleep better not knowing Mayor. Just know that I found out what you wanted, we now know some of the effects of these drugs." The Mayor nodded and left slowly. The man looked at he corpses of the people he had just murdered. There was no excuse. That's what he had done. Not a single one of them had been infected. None of them.

With that last thought the man took out the third cyanide tablet. The one he had hidden away for himself. His last thought was of the infection raging in his body, the one he had hoped to cure with this experiment. Well he found a cure alright he thought. The only cure is death. With that he took the tablet and cured himself forever.
On february 28, 2013
Hawager

Also thanks to everyone Congratulating me! That came as A surprise! Thank you all very much!
On february 28, 2013
DaryleDixon

The Fat Cats Mother.

The sun shines into the open end of the lean-to she has come to call home. However, on this specific morning she is not there. Her mattress still cold and it's purpose unfulfilled since the night before last. The girl that inhabits it was to busy to sleep. She only just made it back to town, with the man on her back, before the undead descended upon the town to commence their nightly attack. The undead mob profiting from the fear the darkness multiplies in the hearts of the residing townsfolk. They managed to hold the hordes back last night though, fighting back against their inevitable extinction.

This town, if you could call it that, was still young, many of the people here have only been so for a couple of days. Most of them had been in another small town and had fled when it's walls crumbled and the townspeople plunged into chaos against a formidable terror. Those that were lucky to get out alive were left to wander the wasteland, those that were luckier still; stumbled across another town in it's beginnings, a desperate attempt to recreate what they had before all of this, an attempt to recreate some sort of order in the midst of a world in pain. Those that were less naive understood that this was not possible now, all they seek is a temporary safe haven from the marauding undead. The end was coming to the human race, everybody could sense it now. The girl understood this and vowed to live as long as she could, even if it meant she was the last of her kind on the planet. She will show she is made of sterner stuff, she will show them why her kind have ruled this earth for however many thousands of years they have done. She will live. At least, that's what she told herself at night, when she tried to distract herself from the screams and piercing shrills.

She knew the cell would be hard on the man, after all, her hands had helped build it. Nothing but bare concrete. Concrete walls, floor and ceiling. The only thing that softened the eye at all was the old battered mattress, stained black with old spilt blood and only a few inches thick. Presumably, the filling had been taken by the other townsfolk to in turn soften their own. It couldn't possibly make the man's stay any more comfortable. Many of the cells previous inhabitants had actually chosen the hard, cold floor instead of the sad mistake for a bed, claiming it was cursed and the source of their horrific nightmares. The towns people could hear them at night screaming and crying. Their fate was that of true despair and horror. Poor bastards. What a way to die.

That's his fate now. He's got a few more hours, maybe a day max. I had to do it! He'd be a liability out here with the rest of us. Never knowing when he could turn. I had to do. Think of the damage he could do if he was loose. He looks like shit. Perhaps I should get him some water, before his body rejects it completely. Would it be a waste? We need every drop we can get for the able bodied. No... He needs some water. Without humanity all would already be lost. I have to do it.

The flakes of skin that made up what was left of the man's lips were dry grey and barely clung to his face at all. For the past few hours he had been waving in and out of consciousness; awakening only long enough to feel the intense sting in his hand and the cold burn of sweat against his skin. His attention diverts to the door of his holding and his eyes focus only for a second on the small confident figure shaded by the unusually bright sunlight behind it. The girl had brought a packet of crisps as well as a flask of water. She leans the man slightly up against the cold wall behind him and pours a little of the water into the mouth in need. A little cough and splutter but it goes down smoothly in the end and soon enough the entire contents had disappeared. Regaining a little strength the man manages to let out a short gasp that the girl understands to be gratitude. 'I brought a little food...' before she can even finish her sentence she notices the man has passed out. Unconsciousness: eternal bliss compared to his living hell.

The girl notices a heavy exhalation and pauses in anticipation, waiting for the man's chest to rise again to mark his continuance. But it doesn't come. After examining the empty flask still in her hand, she holds it above her head and lets the last few drops fall onto her tongue. It wasn't a complete waste. At least the man's last experience was that of compassion. Standing a few paces away from the inanimate body she remembers the serrated knife she pocketed on the way here. 'I have to do it.' She mutters as she locks the cell door; just in case.
On february 28, 2013
Coldflame

Home

na..me... ryan...

i...write what i can think

ryan forget most thing

ryan get bit

ryan not let in town no more

town no like ryan

ryan just want to go home

town try to hurt ryan

home do not want ryan

ryan try go home

ryan get home

ryan hungry

ryan eat friend


ryan dont think home good anymore

ryan find other town

ryan hungry.

ryan eat other town


ryan go home

On march 1, 2013
SaucyemmettC

Sorry it's so long... Damn thing just wouldn't end, kept stretching on and on...

Someone poisoned the water hole
‚ÄúWhat the fuck man! What the fuck is wrong with you!‚Äù
‚ÄúHey hey! It wasn‚Äôt my fault!‚Äù
‚ÄúOf course it was your fuckin fault!‚Äù
‚ÄúNo, the damn thing just jumped right in!‚Äù
‚ÄúYah, I fuckin saw the fuckin thing jump in you fuckin idiot!‚Äù
‚ÄúCalm the hell down! Maybe it missed‚Äù
‚ÄúMISSED! MISSED! IT CAN‚ÄôT POSSIBLY MISS!‚Äù Another joined the two men at the well.
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs going on you two?‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôl tell yah what the fu-‚Äú
‚ÄúShut up Frank! You can‚Äôt say a single freakin sentence without my ears bleedin. So Barnie, what‚Äôs happened?‚Äù Barnie took a step back, eyes on the verge of tears. Before him stood his hero; and how was he supposed to tell the hero in front of him, who stood up for him whenever he failed, who helped him whenever he hurt, who believed in him when no one else did, that he had failed once again. He had screwed up, but this was serious; he hadn‚Äôt just lost his water ration, or knocked over a construction, or got himself trapped‚Ä¶ No, he had royally effed up. And after all that the shining knight that stood before him had done, poured out all his faith, all his effort into Barnie, encouraging him that he could change, be less clumsy, be a hero, Barnie was still the same old screw up.
‚ÄúW-w-well you s-see Harry‚Ä¶ I was on the w-watch like you said I sh-sh-should‚Ä¶ And, well, I was s-sent with F-F-Fraank‚Ä¶ W-w-wee ha-haa-‚Äú Harry put his hand on Barnie‚Äôs shoulder. His eyes stared into Barnie‚Äôs easing his panic. They were a soft blue, and held the shine of an uncut diamond.
‚ÄúCalm down Barnie. It‚Äôs ok. Just tell me what happened‚Äù. His voice lulled the icy fear out of Barnie‚Äôs throat. His mind cleared. Barnie looked deeply into the blueness of Harry‚Äôs eyes.
‚ÄúI missed a zed Harry. It got in and got away. I chased it here with Frank, but the thing was quick Harry. I never saw one so fast before, you have to believe me Harry! It was like it was on a mission Harry, it weaved between all the tents, ignoring everyone, me and Frank, we lost it twice-‚Äú
‚ÄúYOU lost it you scatter brained-‚Äú
‚ÄúShut up Frank. Let him finish‚Äù
‚ÄúWell‚Ä¶ It just kept running farther and farther into town, and then it jumped in‚Ä¶ It jumped in here‚Äù Barnie‚Äôs voice broke at his last statement; he pointed shakily at the little well that the citizen had dug along time ago. They had been rationing 1 drink a day for the past month, and it seemed like they still had a month before the well supply grew worrisome. Harry bent over and looked down the well-hole. His teeth could be heard grinding together as he thought. Frank glared at Barnie in disgust. Harry turned and left without another word. Barnie watched in horror, filled with guilt and despair.
‚ÄúThis is all your fault you little shit. I told you you couldn‚Äôt handle it. I told you you would fuck up. That‚Äôs all you ever do Barnie. And you fucked us all this time‚Äù. Frank stared hatefully into Barnie‚Äôs tear-streaking eyes, and then too turned and left. Barnie stood beside the well, crying. That‚Äôs all he could do, cry. That‚Äôs all he was ever good at.

‚ÄúListen up everyone! This is important!‚Äù General stood in front of the well, his dark leathery skin crackling in the heat of the morning sun. A rather unhappy mob of thirsty people had formed around the well. Water was one of the only comforts anyone could ask for in this wasteland, and no one was pleased that this rarity was being postponed. ‚ÄúListen everyone listen! You must all calm down. Wait until everyone is here, I will only say this once, and I expect you all to hear my every word‚Äù. General often started his ‚Äúspeeches‚Äù with, ‚Äòlisten to me people‚Äô and ‚ÄòI‚Äôm only going to say this once‚Äô. He hated repeating himself, and his temper was re-knownly avoided; but perhaps it was from that same fear that he was unspokenly elected as their commander. No one questioned him and no one disobeyed him, he would discuss all his plans with a small group of townsfolk, but beyond that he had absolute reign. Fear trumped all, and he was feared more than all. And so the mob quieted and patiently awaited his orders. Bit by bit drowsy and confused townsfolk shambled out of their tents and toward the well. Soon everyone was waiting in the mass, staring hungrily at General. When he was sure that everyone had accumulated in at the well, he spoke: ‚ÄúGood morning everyone. I hope you slept well. I have some troubling news to give you today, but before I do I want you all to know that I will do everything in my power to find a solution. I also want you to know that this is no-ones fault! We will NOT be having a witch-hunt, we will NOT be having a hanging. What happened last night was merely a case of bad luck.‚Äù The mass quivered nervously. ‚ÄúLast night the zed broke through! Shhh, do not worry, no one was injured. Only one made it into town, but this one zed hit us hard. It made it right here, to the well, and jumped in.‚Äù The mass jolted. People began whispering frantically, muttering paranoid fears under their breaths. Barnie was among them. He stood with them, not saying a word, he just put his head down and cried. ‚ÄúSo, comrades, we all know what happens when you ingest the disease that plagues corpses. You become one. And so, until further notice, the well will be off limits. So please, everyone should continue with their duties as normal, I assure you we will have this crisis fixed soon. But first, could‚Ä¶‚Äù General called out his council, ordering them to speak with him after everyone had dispersed. Barnie was not among them, and soon followed the crowd away, back to his daily duties. He felt no relief that General had blamed bad luck, in fact he felt worse. He knew that he was being protected by General‚Äôs equivocation, knowing that the town may thirst for blood when it‚Äôs thirst for water grew unbearable.
On march 1, 2013
SaucyemmettC

Part 2
The day was done, the sun down and the sky black. Barnie sat upright in his bed, staring blankly at the starless sky. His head throbbed in pain, and his body ached in exhaust. He was thirsty. Everyone was, and it was all his fault. How long would this go on, General promised to fix it but how? The only thing people feared more than General was infection. Death was mercy compared to General‚Äôs public punishments, but infection was the most frightening experience anyone could imagine. Death with no release, the body bound back to life, burdened with intense anguish, burning hunger filled thoughts... The infection fear had spread across the town, plaguing sleep with nightmares of re-animation. Barnie had had his fair share of nightmares, but the worst by far where always ones where he re-animated. He would shamble about and slaughter everyone he knew, watch their pain, the pain which he was causing, burst out in blood. He would rip them all to pieces and then sit up screaming in the night, joined by others sharing similar nightmares. Everyone had witnessed the infection first hand, their mothers, fathers, sisters, brothers, cousins, nephews, aunts, uncles, friends, acquaintances, hero‚Äôs, enemies, everyone! Everyone everyone had known had become infected, and to see such a transformation; staring into your mother‚Äôs eyes and glimpse a portion of pain she felt‚Ä¶ It was too awful for the mind to handle. No one would touch that water. And soon people would need it. The heat was too much to go for more than two days without water, how would General do it? How would General save everyone? He had saved the town hundreds of times before, he truly was a genius, but what if he couldn‚Äôt this time.
‚ÄúAnd it would be all my fault‚Äù, Bernie said silently under his breath. He began to sob before the darkness of the night sky overwhelmed him and he faded away‚Ä¶

Days past and the well remained untouched. General ordered the emergency reserves to be used, using chunky water found from a nearby pre-Z water purification facility. They had tried for days to get it working again when they first found it, but it was deemed far beyond damaged beyond repair. Fortunately it had a stockpile of weak water tablets, which could make the water soft enough to slide to slide down your throat, and had gallons of mucky ‚Äúwater‚Äù in rank tanks. But how long could it support forty people? The General continued every morning to ensure everyone that the issue was being solved, but rumors quickly spread. Drinking vile water every day can make a man mad, and many of the men around town had become violent. Paranoia grew in the hearts of the townsfolk, and tools and weapons from the bank began to disappear. Barnie spent most of his time working, no one spoke to him, no one accused him‚Ä¶ Except Frank, who was subtle about it, glaring menacingly at Barnie while he worked, stalking him about at night. And soon new rumors spread, about how Frank knew something. A little whisper here about how Frank was on duty that night, and a little whisper there about how Frank had been seen chasing something that night. It‚Äôs funny how word spreads, ideas form in one man‚Äôs head, and they spread to another‚Äôs, and then they jump again, and again, until everyone has the idea.

‚ÄúWakie wakie Barnie‚Äù
‚ÄúEr.. wha? Frank?‚Äù
‚ÄúSh sh sh sh sh shhhh‚Ä¶ Quite now little fucker. You make another noise and I‚Äôl plunge this into your skull.‚Äù Barnie felt a sharp metallic point jab him in the forehead. He opened his eyes to see Frank‚Äôs nose only an inch away from his. Frank was sitting on his chest, pinning him to the ground. He had one hand smothering Barnie‚Äôs mouth, and another jabbing a knife into his forehead. Barnie began to cry fearfully. ‚ÄúHow is it that you have enough water in you to cry so often little fucker? Hmm‚Ä¶ You‚Äôre always crying, I swear you‚Äôve wept out more water than I‚Äôve ever drankin, hmm. So, you holdin out on me? You got some water hidden away? You planned this didn‚Äôt you? Hmmm‚Ä¶ Yah, that‚Äôs right isn‚Äôt it, you wanted us to dry up, you let that zed in, let it get to the well. Didn‚Äôt you. Bet you stole a gallon or two of water before. Don‚Äôt try to hide it, I see it in your eyes. You little fuck, you‚Äôre trying to kill us? Hah, well little fuck, you can‚Äôt kill me. Tell me where you hid it!‚Äù. Barnie looked past Frank into the night sky. He tried to say something but Frank‚Äôs hand muffled his words. ‚ÄúOh, you want to talk now, now that little fuck doesn‚Äôt have big fuck to protect him.‚Äù A dark silhouette smashed into Frank‚Äôs skull, knocking him off Barnie. Someone jumped onto Frank and began beating him across the head. Barnie crawled away hurriedly. What the hell was going on, who was that, what was happening. Barnie continued to cry, great globs of tears slid across his cheeks. The man stopped beating Frank and stood up, in the darkness of night it was impossible to tell who it was.
‚ÄúGo back to sleep Barnie, your safe now‚Äù. Harry‚Äôs voice.
‚ÄúHarry?‚Äù
‚ÄúYes‚Äù
‚ÄúIs this my fault‚Äù
‚ÄúNo Barnie, it‚Äôs mine‚Äù, Harry turned and left.
General announced that morning that Frank had been killed. The mass gathered in front of the well shook. Screams of protest erupted from them, General stood watching, as they grew excited. It was only a matter of time before his fear was not enough. He explained how Frank had tried to kill someone, and how a third party had arrived and rescued the victim. He left out Barnie‚Äôs and Harry‚Äôs names, perhaps again out of fear of an upcoming riot. The people were tired of the wretched water they were drinking, they were tired of General‚Äôs speeches, but most of all they were tired of their boring, labour-filled lives.
On march 1, 2013
SaucyemmettC

Part 3
‚ÄúHey Barnie boy‚Äù
‚ÄúEr, wha, Frank‚Äù
‚ÄúFrank? You hear that boys, he lookin for Frank‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat a laugh‚Äù
‚ÄúI knew it‚Äù
Bu-u-wha? Who‚Ä¶ Wha-‚Äú Barnie opened his eyes, feeling a powerful feeling of Deja-Vu. Sitting on his chest was a man he knew, but did not know, pointing something into his forehead. Around him huddled seven figures.
‚ÄúFrank told us the night before he died that he gunna get ‚Äòimself some real water. Hmmm. We all knew he was there that night, yah, and after a little lookin we find that he came here that other night. Night he died he payed you a visit. So that must meen you killed him, yah. You did didn‚Äôt yoooo Barnie boy. Hah, so where is it? Where‚Äôd you put the water?‚Äù
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have any water guys. Frank was mad caus-‚Äú The man crammed the point into Barnie‚Äôs arm.
‚ÄúNo shit Barnie, Mr Fuckin Frank hated you like no one else, but we KNOW you have water, so fork it up buddy.‚Äù Barnie cried silently, unable to speak. He began choking, quickly being muffled by a large grimy hand.
‚ÄúWhat do you guys think you‚Äôre doing?‚Äù Harry, again. Always Harry running to Barnie‚Äôs rescue. Barnie‚Äôs eyes erupted. The man let go off him, and then stood up and faced Harry.
‚ÄúSo you in on it too, huh, yah, you got the water with you? Bet he does bet he does‚Äù. The others took up the chant too,
‚ÄúBet he does, bet he does‚Ä¶‚Äù Barnie watched as the men gathered around Harry, and then, in the darkness of night they fought. Barnie was horrofied; it looked like a bunch of people shadow boxing, only with splashes of black blood spraying about. More people approached, watching the fight. One man tried to stop it, approaching drowsily and mumbling about idiocy. One of the shadows turned and clubbed him over the head, and a solemn ‚Äúumf‚Äù shot out of his lips. That‚Äôs when the madness started. Everyone in town exploded, jumping on the shadows. Barnie watched as a beast formed, a shadow-monster screaming and flailing about, knocking over tents and smashing constructions. It began stampeding around town, smashing everything in it‚Äôs path, leaving a line of corpses and rubble in it‚Äôs wake. Barnie watched as the corpses twitched, and then wiggled, and then eventually stumble back onto their feet. They formed together and created another shadow-monster. The two monsters looked into each other and then charged, colliding into one giant blob of death. Barnie stood up and watched as the blob grew and grew, stretching across the town, consuming everything in it‚Äôs path.
‚ÄúThe people‚Ä¶ They stood back up‚Ä¶ But‚Ä¶ But they weren‚Äôt infected‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúNo Barnie‚Ä¶ They were‚Äù. Barnie gasped and turned to meet the eavesdropper. It was General.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all infected Barnie‚Ä¶ Infected with the same thing the corpses are‚Ä¶ We‚Äôre infected with hunger. We all feel it, the need to kill, to hurt, to consume. We repress it, but the dead don‚Äôt‚Äù
‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt understand s-sir‚Ä¶ What do you mean?‚Äù General put his arm on Barnie‚Äôs shoulder, looking deeply into his eyes.
‚ÄúWe did this to ourselves son. We did this. We wanted the perfect soldier, and we got it. A man without any fear, without any restrictions, without any feelings at all. But what we thought was wrong. Behind all those feelings is evil. We all have it, and we all fight it, every day. But we gave in, we stopped fighting, we stopped feeling. And now‚Ä¶ We are all going to die‚Äù. Barnie watched the General carefully, uncertain of what he was being told.
‚ÄúS-s-sir‚Ä¶ What d-do you mean‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúI had to stop them, I saw how much effort it put in to saving us, and I couldn‚Äôt let it‚Äôs sacrifice be in vain. He was a brave man, and our saviour. It‚Äôs ok son, join them, it will all be over soon. No more fighting, no more fear, just give in, let it take you‚Äù. Barnie tried to pull free from General‚Äôs grasp, but it was no good. He twisted and turned, but General‚Äôs grip was too strong.
‚ÄúLet me help you Barnie, understand what I mean. Our brother sacrificed himself to the well to save us all. Do not let his death be in vain! Join us!‚Äù General sunk his teeth into Barnie‚Äôs neck, his tongue furiously licking the boy‚Äôs wound, urging the disease into the corpse.

On march 1, 2013
SaucyemmettC

Part 4
The crow above watched in content. It would feast in the morning. A phenomena below caught it‚Äôs keen eyes. The fighting had stopped. But everything was still, nothing moved. The crow watched, intrigued. Had all the corpses been smashed by the living? They‚Äôre should have been a few left shambling about. It flew from its perch on the wall and landed on a corpse. It was headless. It hopped over to another. Headless too. It continued examining each body, noticing that all their heads had been severed. But where did the heads go? The tongue was quite a delicacy. Something moved over by the well. The crow took flight and circled the well, searching for the flash of movement. It found the source quickly, a man carrying a decapitated head marching toward a pile of heads.
‚ÄúNumber thirty-nine‚Äù the man mumbled sadly. The crow was curious about this strange mans strange actions. The sun began to rise over the horizon. Light illuminated the strange man, revealing him as blood stained and wound-infested. His brown clothes had been torn and clumps of his long hair had been torn out. His eyes were a beautiful blue, with a shine like an uncut diamond. ‚ÄúSo‚Ä¶ Looks like it‚Äôs the last of them‚Ä¶‚Äù He stood, staring into the pile of heads. ‚ÄúWell, General‚Ä¶ Never would of guessed you were infected. And you‚Äôve been feedin us all your disease eh? Guess the water in the well just killed your disease, but the water from the plant was too dirty to dilute it huh. You clever fiend. But I also guess that means the water in the well is fine, correct. The head on the top of the pile smiled,
‚ÄúWhy of course, boy‚Äù.
‚ÄúWell, I think this has gone on long enough, sir. We‚Äôre all thirsty, and we‚Äôre all half crazed from your poisoned water, right?
‚ÄúWhy of course, boy‚Äù
‚ÄúWell, then it can‚Äôt hurt to have a drink, can it?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhy of course it can‚Äôt, boy‚Äù. The man smiled.
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I thought, sir‚Äù. The man plucked the head up and dropped it in the well. Ploosh. And then he picked up another, Ploosh. And then another, almost getting bit by it‚Äôs snapping jaws, Ploosh, ploosh, plooosh, plooosh‚Ä¶ The crow watched, entertained by the man. The man picked up the final head. It‚Äôs eyes bled tears.
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt cry buddy. This was all my fault.‚Äù
Ploosh.

Again, I apologize for the size. Hehehe.
