On march 3, 2013
MadDonut

Cheers

Reese leaned against a long stout wooden beam that served as a buttress for the tall wall that loomed over his head. The wall created a large shadow that gave Reese protection from the sizzling sunlight that baked the sand roughly a yard from Reese's feet. Reese's meaty fingers reached over and pried a small brown canteen from a worn rucksack that lie against the wall. They then unscrewed the small stopper and held it to his mouth. Reese lapped was left of his water in a few rapid gulps. Letting out a refreshed sigh, Reese sealed the canteen and placed it back in his rucksack. Reese then grabbed and hoisted the rucksack over his shoulders. He proceeded to pull out a black hard plastic stub protruding from one of the rucksack's many pockets. Beneath the plastic stub slid the glistening blade of a well used machete. Reese aimed the machete that he now wielded with both his hands in front of him. He stepped carefully forward along the wall, trying to not make a sound.

Within just a few steps, the wall to Reese's left began to disappear, leaving a large gaping hole. The hole wasn't in the original blueprint for the wall, but some rather violent demolition experts made it otherwise. The town Reese was passing through had been idle for months, as the poorly maintained grounds and damaged buildings (like the wall Reese passed by) suggested. The townspeople were still around however. They were mostly clumsily stumbling about from shadow the shadow and occasionally, if they were feeling particularly perky, beat against the shambled remains of their homes. Sometimes one would stumble outside and sometimes they'd begin wandering off from town, distracted by a windblown Plastic Bag, the shine of the sun, or for no real reason at all. Reese suddenly stopped. Before him stood a woman in bloody clothing that stared mindlessly into the sky with her back to Reese. Reese slowly stepped forward and lowered his machete horizontally around his right side. He slowed his breath and glance out the corners of his eyes for any other threats. The woman's head lowered, and whether if she had noticed him or became tired of staring at the dull sandy clouds above, Reese rushed forward and swung his machete.

The woman's head launched several feet to the side and her body stood still for an instant before lifelessly falling on the sand. Reese inhaled deeply and looked around to see if he had stirred anything. Not seeing anything, he moved his machete back to a resting position and he moved past the woman's head which gasped and snapped at him. He leaned against the wooden rear wall of a hovel on the outskirts of town and peered through a small hole in the wood. Inside, though it was very musty and difficult to see, he saw a worn bed on the floor and a small oven placed on a small wood nightstand. Reese guessed this must of been the town's cook's home. He hugged the wall and shuffled his way around, looked for any threats, and snuck into the battered door of the hovel. The hovel smelled stale, but there was no aroma of any unhappy home owners. Reese relaxed and looked about. In a corner, he noticed a small Beer Fridge. He leaned forward and opened it. Inside he found a lone brown bottle and a note. Reese had to lift the bottle to read the note which said:

Dear visitor,
My name is Elliot and welcome to my home. The whiskey, if it is still there, is my gift to you. I am sitting here in my abode during the night's attack writing this note. The men and women that were called upon to serve on the wall are screaming not too far from here at the main gates. I fear tonight will be my last. I have been saving this whiskey for when I die, but I sat here for several minutes thinking about drinking it and failed to do so. I decided instead that I will enjoy my life and quit drinking so much alcohol, like my wife (God bless her soul) always told me. So I write this note that I will leave with this whiskey for you. I don't know who or what you are, but to you I say "Cheers."
Your loving host, Elliot.P.S: you can have my clothes that I left on my bed if you want

Reese smiled a cheeky grin and yanked the cork off the bottle of whiskey. He plopped himself on the bed, avoiding the pile of dirty clothes, and took a sip. "Well damn. Either I just haven't had any whiskey in a long time," Reese admired, "or this is some damn good whiskey." Reese took a few more sips to get used to the strong flavor before finally chugging back the bottle, quenching his thirst temporarily. After releasing a refreshed sigh twice as refreshing than the one he had with his water, he placed the empty squarish bottle back into the beer fridge. He then found a pencil on the dirty ground and flipped the note over, placing it on his thigh. In a hearty font, Reese wrote a big "Thanks, Elliot" and slid the note back under the bottle. With a newfound cheerful demeanor, Reese sealed the Beer Fridge again and headed to the door. He peered out and, with haste, headed off to loot as much of the town as he could before nightfall.
On march 3, 2013
Hawager

Finding Hope

The desert sands shifted in the wind. Grains whipped the man across the face, almost as if the desert was reprimanding him for taking up this futile search. The man leaned on his trusty shovel and wiped his brow. The sun was lowering to the horizon but still its scorching heat went on.

Hope. No, Hope.

The man‚Äôs thoughts were consumed by it. Hope. It was his mantra he repeated it over and over in his mind.

Hope, why. Why Hope?

He couldn‚Äôt wrap his mind around the cruelty of his situation. He continued digging away at the ruin surrounding him. The sound of sand running over metal was the only thing to be heard other than the man‚Äôs grunts as he continued to chip away at the sand.

So little, little Hope.

The man‚Äôs work continued, second by second, minute by minute. Soon an hour had passed and the man took a break. He sat in a rickety Ektorp-Gluten Chair it squeaked as he put more weight on it. He closed his eyes. He felt the stress run out of his body, he sighed.

How could I? How couldn‚Äôt I? I abandoned‚Ä¶ Hope‚Ä¶

A low groan, the man was on his feet. The sun had set as he dozed off. The man took his shovel in hand and moved to the front of the ruin. Two zombies, lazy, no problem. The man clanged his shovel against a metal support to get the zombies attention. They both began shambling towards him, one of them pulling ahead of the other. Too easy. A vicious uppercut with the shovel beheading the foremost zombie. The man charged past the first and buried half the shovel into the brain of the second. The man panted with effort.

Why am I here?

Looking‚Ä¶ Finding Hope‚Ä¶

The man shambled back into the building and began digging. He dug quickly and furiously. The sun had set; he knew he had little time. He dug and dug, sand flying out of blown out holes in the wall, debris being thrown out as well. Thirty minutes and 3 zombies later the man sat kneeling in the ruin. He held a rusty bracelet; it had a red cross on it and emergency contact info.

Hope, yes Hope. Please‚Ä¶

The man dug quickly now, insanely. He was close. So close‚Ä¶ close to Hope‚Ä¶ A minute later the man found what he had been looking for. In the small hole the man had excavated lay a small skeleton.

The skeleton of a child‚Ä¶

The Skeleton of my Child...

The Skeleton of Hope‚Ä¶
On march 3, 2013
DaryleDixon

On march 3, 2013
TheStaff

I know right these stories are pretty good.Almost novel-book good too.
On march 3, 2013
TOShokking

I've been getting so bored recently that I actually started writing a mini-story.
I say started - I've written 3 A4 pages and I'm maybe half-way though Day 1.
If I go by my plan for the full thing, it should be about 50 to 60 pages long. That's A4 - most current novels and story-books are printed on paper around A5 size, so that's about 100 to 120 pages.

To be fair though, most of it is just fluff to pad it out while I try and find a way to link ideas together.

I think Die2Nite isn't the "gamer's game" with lots of buttons to push in quick succession, where you sit down for an hour ot two to play the game itself. It's more the "social game" where a large part of it is the conversation side - brings in more creative people over hardcore gamer types.

But what do I know??

*Goes back to two well-known First Person Shooters for a bit*

On march 4, 2013
Sniluey

That dog

That dog has been sitting there for a while now. Pretty darn spooky for such a little bastard. Sitting in front of the door like it owns me. Wonder when it starts pissing on me thinking I`m useless. Well, luckily I didn`t have anything special to do today anyways. I guess a staring contest won`t hurt either of us.

..................................................... "sigh"

Those big darn eyes. makes me happy I didn`t actually own a dog before ending up here. Or family for that matter. I had nothing to lose and I guess this dog didn`t either. I wonder if it is just trying to get some attention...

"whimper"

Yeah, definitely. It wants some love. Those fricking eyes. They look so hopeful, like a kid waiting for his mama and papa to come home. A darn poor kid with 3 legs and a dirty natural puff of fur, that looks like a "bow." It doesn`t really seem to care. Even in that bad state it just walks on. Waits and stares, wanting to make some new friends...

Is it just his personality? Is he born naturally like this? Is there some bald head idiot giving birth to these ugly beings with two even uglier dogs? It doesn`t care. It just looks towards the future, knowing that someone will love him. Someday, some time, maybe even after death...

Well, doggie. I will give you a friend. You can join me in my adventures. Maybe neither of us needs to hope for the future to be better with eachother by our side. Now where did I put that stick...

"Woof!"

Oh, here it is. Now, who wants to play fe...

"Gnarl"

HEY! That is my steak! You have to atleast share it with me! HEY! COME BACK! You stupid 3-legged ugly limping, glue drooled, thieving Fatso Of an ugly dog you are...

Well, here's my next story...

Hopeless

Hot‚Ä¶ So hot‚Ä¶ I can‚Äôt take it anymore‚Ä¶ My body‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm done‚Ä¶ This is hopeless‚Ä¶ No-one will come to save me‚Ä¶ But then why do I still feel it‚Ä¶ That nagging feeling pulling at my insides, eating away at my fear‚Ä¶ Desperately it claws to my throat‚Ä¶ I clench my teeth, no, NO, this is hopeless, it doesn‚Äôt matter what I do‚Ä¶ It pry‚Äôs my teeth, persistently squeezing out of my lips, spilling out into the world‚Ä¶
‚ÄúHEEELP MEEE!‚Äù
Why‚Ä¶ Why would I bother‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs hopeless‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm done, dried up‚Ä¶ Soon I‚Äôl be nothing but sand‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm so hungry‚Ä¶ So thirsty‚Ä¶ And so is the sand‚Ä¶ But why‚Ä¶ Why did I scream... Why do I feel this strive... This was suicide wasn‚Äôt it... I knew I was done, that‚Äôs why I left‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm so thirsty‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs so hot‚Ä¶ But then why did I scream... I‚Äôm done, I‚Äôm dead‚Ä¶
‚ÄúHELP ME!‚Äù
Again‚Ä¶ Where did it come from‚Ä¶ Why‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm dead‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm done‚Ä¶ But this feeling‚Ä¶ I feel it pounding out of my dried heart, slinking through my blood, striving against this suicide‚Ä¶ It was suicide wasn‚Äôt it... I knew I didn‚Äôt have the supplies to come back‚Ä¶ Did I really think I‚Äôd find any out here‚Ä¶ This is what happens‚Ä¶ When you hope‚Ä¶ I know now that hope is false‚Ä¶ But why‚Ä¶ Why does it still urge me‚Ä¶
‚ÄúHelp‚Ä¶ Me‚Ä¶‚Äù
I‚Äôm wasting my breath‚Ä¶ But I can‚Äôt help it‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs overpowering me‚Ä¶ What the hell is wrong with me‚Ä¶ I can‚Äôt help it‚Ä¶ I am going to die‚Ä¶ But I don‚Äôt want to‚Ä¶ Want doesn‚Äôt matter‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm going to die‚Ä¶ This is hopeless‚Ä¶
‚ÄúH.. Help‚Ä¶ Meee‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúHey‚Ä¶ Clark is that you? Jesus buddy are you ok‚Äù
This is an illusion‚Ä¶ A false image mocking my lucid mind‚Ä¶ This thing before me is only a conjuration of my unsatisfied hopes‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm done‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm dead.. It‚Äôs hopeless‚Ä¶
‚ÄúH‚Ä¶He‚Ä¶Help‚Ä¶ Meee‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry Clark. I‚Äôm here now. What the hell were you thinking, I‚Äôve been looking for you everywhere. Where the hell did you go? Clark? CLARK?‚Äù
No‚Ä¶ He can‚Äôt be real‚Ä¶ He is not real‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm dead‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm done‚Ä¶ This is hopeless‚Ä¶
‚Äú‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúCLARK! Stay with me buddy. You‚Äôve lived four days out here you are NOT dying now! Here, take my water‚Äù
AARRRGGH WATER! PAIN IS REAL REAL IS PAIN I AM NOT HOPELESS I AM ALIVE AND HE IS REAL AND I AM SAVED!

GULP

On march 10, 2013
Deblyn
Dances with zombies

Hope is in the eye of the beholder.

I quickly gathered the supplies I thought I would need. A blanket, water and a handful of sweets. It was dusk I wouldn‚Äôt be able to leave until midnight. I had a long evening of inactivity in front of me. I knew I should sleep. Rest. The coming night would be busy.

I tried to lie down. Tried to relax, but I was too restless. I forced myself to close my eyes.
Bright flashes on the inside of my eyelids ‚Ä¶..remembering.

Last night I was not on watch. For the first night in 3 days. I had been exhausted and had fallen asleep early. Right after a meager dinner of a canned food ration. It had tasted like dog food. Heck, it probably was dog food. A bunch of us had holed up in a town that had been ransacked long before we had arrived.

I had been asleep for just a little while when I was jerked awake by the feeling of pressure on my face. A hand covering my mouth. In the dimness of my tent, lit only by the torchlight the watchmen were carrying. I saw a woman. Maybe in her 20s? She pressed harder on my mouth, pushing my head harder into the thin mattress of the cot.

‚ÄúPlease‚Äù she whispered. ‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt scream‚Äù
I managed to nod my head.

She tentively, slowly removed her hand.

She was squatting beside my cot‚Ä¶

I could easily push her back, make her topple backwards and with one scream have most of the men running to help me. One perk of being the only woman in our camp was that I always had men wanting to play hero. Even in these horrid times.

I sat up slowly.

‚ÄúWho are you?‚Äù

She maintained eye contact with me as she sat on the floor. Crossing her legs Indian style.

She whispered. ‚ÄúI have been watching you the past few nights. On the wall. I thought, hoped, you would be able to help me‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you have been watching me‚Ä¶.that means you were out there, in the desert. Why didn‚Äôt you show yourself?‚Äù I too, kept my voice low.

‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt‚Ä¶.‚Äù

For the first time I could smell her‚Ä¶..the rancid, decaying smell of death. I inhaled sharply. When you want to get used to a smell and not vomit the best thing to do is take a deep inhalation so all the particles of scent are in your mouth , nose and lungs. This helps your body adapt quickly to the physicality of the stench. Her scent tasted of death.

‚ÄúYou have been bitten‚Äù I whispered harshly.

‚ÄúYes‚Äù, she replied., ‚Äú2 days ago‚Äù

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt help you.‚Äù I swung my legs over the opposite side of my cot and started to stand.

She reached out a hand to me.
‚ÄúPlease, please listen‚Ä¶.‚Äù

In her hurried whisper I heard desperation. I also heard a whimper.

Instead of standing, I turned sideways to her.

I thought it was her that whimpered‚Ä¶.
It wasn‚Äôt.
She pulled a makeshift papoose from behind her. A baby. Maybe 9 or 10 months old. Swaddled in an old blanket. In the dim light I could see the sleeping baby‚Äôs face. I could also smell it. It smelled of death too.

I gasped. Oh no, I thought. Not only would I have to kill this woman that was shape-shifting into a zombie, but I would have to kill this zombie child too.

She heard my gasp‚Ä¶. ‚ÄúNo, NO! She‚Äôs not been bitten‚Äù

‚ÄúThe smell‚Ä¶.she smells of zombie.‚Äù

The woman-zombie replied. ‚ÄúI smeared her with the scent. To keep her safe from the horde‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat do you want from me?‚Äù I asked

‚ÄúPlease, please let me explain‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Äù

She was on her third day. She knew all the signs and symptoms. She only had until tonight before the infection ran its course and she turned completely. She wanted me to take her daughter. Care for her. Give her protection so she could live.

She wanted to leave the child with me while she returned to the desert through a hole in the wall that she had been small enough to slip through.

Her eyes were desperate, large and wet.The pain in her voice was heavy. A weight I didn‚Äôt want to hear or be responsible for.

But a child! A child meant hope. Hope for our future. A symbol‚Ä¶‚Ä¶that life would someday be ok again. Bearable again. I looked at the sleeping child‚Äôs face. She frowned and another soft whimper escaped her rosebud lips. My heart melted.

I made the decision quickly. I would help this mother, I would help her child.

I asked her how she wanted to do this.

The mother said she would leave the child at the opening she had come through. At midnight.

I knew I couldn‚Äôt tell the rest of the camp that I had made this deal. They would never understand why I had let the woman-zombie stay in my tent and even have a conversation with me. I knew also that they would take the baby into the desert and leave her. She was weak, would be nothing but a burden to the camp. Just another mouth to feed. I would tell them I ‚Äúfound‚Äù her. Convince them I would be the sole person responsible. I could do this. My heart had already softened towards the baby. My arms already imagined the weight of her.

After discussing the details and finalizing the plan. The mother carefully lifted the sleeping baby, still swaddled in the papoose and carefully made her way to the tent opening,

I stopped her with a question. ‚ÄúWhat if you turn before midnight?‚Äù

She replied almost fiercely. ‚ÄúI will do anything to provide for my child and to insure she thrives‚Äù

I had nodded solemnly.

After replaying the previous night‚Äôs event in my mind I dozed fitfully. Waiting for midnight.

A few minutes before midnight I stealthily made my way to the area the woman had told me she would leave the baby. The child was right where she said she would be. My eyes filled with tears at the sacrifice the woman had made for her child.

The child was sitting up‚Ä¶..playing with her toes. No longer swaddled in her papoose. When she saw me in the moonlight she smiled. As I reached to pick her up I was cooing senseless baby words to her. To calm her. To soothe her if she suddenly realized I was a stranger to her and cried for her now zombie mother.

The baby laid her head on my shoulder with a bubbly sigh. As I turned to walk back to my tent I felt her nuzzle my neck. I would need to bathe her as soon as possible!

Then I felt a searing pain. A tremendously hot pain. I felt blood pour down my chest, Over the baby as well. As I fell I felt the baby twist and felt her mouth bite into my breast. Ripping a large chunk of it away.
I realized I had been tricked! I dimly remembered the mother‚Äôs last words to me.

‚ÄúI will do anything to provide for my child and to insure she thrives‚Äù

With my last coherent thought I realized the child was the zombie. Not the mother.

On march 12, 2013
PaperScratcher

I wanna share this story of mine



The Shaman's Plan

It was a peaceful and coordinated town. But Chaos will come in a most convenient time...


It was dusk when a mysterious man passed by the town. He was wearing a weird orange mask. The citizens did not suspect him and asked him if he want to stay with them for the night.

He said, "I won't stay here. I see that you are all busy scavenging and building defenses. I would help you. You can get this revolvers for free. But I will come back here tomorrow at dusk, and you will pay me."

Most of the citizens didn't think it was suspicious that a masked man was selling them weapons, even if the town mayor told them to be cautious of other people who didn't lived in the town, but they took the guns.

Little did they know that the man was a Shaman, who lived on magick and souls. The man laughed like a maniac when he left the town. The citizens were laughing with glee, because they have guns that will help them defend the town against the Horde.

The spell put by the Shaman on the guns took effect while they were scavenging in the World Beyond , and the citizens started to shoot each other. It was a massacre. The remaining survivors returned to town when their handful of bullets run out. One of them still had a bullet, but he didn't used it.

At the town gates, the town mayor who was an old man and smelled like Pine Fresh became angry. He expected them to bring things from the World Beyond, but they just stared into him. They started to beat him and then someone shot the mayor at the temple.

The remaining people panicked, as they heard the famished cries by the Horde. There was no one who could lead them, so they all hid in their own homes.

The Hordes were miraculously kept at bay. The town mayor, even with his arthritic knees and wriggling arms, finished creating the thick walls around the town. The others were relieved and paid their respects to the mayor.

Still, the mysterious man returned at dusk, like what he said. The same people who were brainwashed by the spell, sold the soul of their town mayor and the man gave them machine guns. And then the started shooting each other, as the town became devastated. The shaman laughed, and got all the souls, and went to his own town, muttering,
"Now our mayor won't get angry at me for being lazy. And at least my hands were not stained by the blood of these stupid pigs."

They sat around the campfire after a hard days work. Laughter and silly conversation echoed throughout the nights air. People from all walks of life were there; the young, the old, the weak, the strong. People that would never have even looked each other in the eye before all this but that didn't matter now. Telling stories of their lives, true or false, it wasn't important. For the time being they were lost. Lost in each others eyes, lost in each others smiles, in each others happiness. Nobody wished for morning. Nobody wished they would ever be found.

On may 9, 2013
MadDonut

The Wasted Traveler

A long brown robe fluttered in the wind. A mysterious pair of brown eyes peered out from the rags at the glow of the sunset. The man was leaning on a large, well-crafted staff, wobbling with the breeze. The dirty rags on the front of his torso were dark brown, stained recently by a thick liquid. His eyes drooped with a drunken stupor. He stood erect from his staff and looked down the sandy hill. He then smiled drunkenly and swung out one tanned, scrape-covered leg. Unfortunately for the wasted traveler, he had terrible footwork and gravity was not very kind to him.

"Whhooooaaaa! Ow! Ouch! Ompf!"

His foot landed awkwardly on the sandy slope, immediately loosing its traction and collapsing the side of the hill. He fell like a tumbleweed, his rags fluttering wildly as he rolled down the hill. His grip loosened on his trusty staff in the process of his decline of both height and dignity.

Thup!

He came to an abrupt stop at the base of the hill, causing the sand to scatter beneath him. His legs were sprawled out before him and he felt twice as disoriented. He sat there idle for a second trying to compose his thoughts when suddenly a wooden knock sounded from his skull.

THONK!

The staff bounced off his head onto the sand in front of him in a comical manner before rolling on the floor laughing. It didn't really laugh but it would of if it could. It would have felt happy about getting back at this dope it had been forced to assist all week long if it was a sentient being. Sadly, it was just an inanimate staff that gave no giggle as it merely rolled on the sand in front of its owner who grumbled slurred swears from under his raggedy cloak.

"Blasted fcuhing stick. I.. I hate this stu- *hic* stoopid thing. If I was that fcuhing thing I'd.. I'd uh.. shit. *hic* Wait.. yeah! I'd shit myself! Just like I did yesterday!
...
So fcuh- *huc* -ing embercing that I did that when they were.. the fcuhers.. threwing me out.. Grah!"

The wasted traveler then angrily punched the sand, disrupting the sand which retaliated by flinging itself in his mouth.

"Plah! *hic* Stoopid sand..."

The wasted traveler spat out the sand in disgust, making sour faces, and grabbed his staff. He stood up again and continued to march forward, only occasionally loosing his balance and stumbling again.

He wandered for hours in the dark while on his noble quest. His quest was to find more booze and get more drunker. He may be a worthless bottle worshiper, but you have to give him credit on his effort. During his drunken traveling, he encountered a large old scrapyard and traversed this treacherous terrain by staggering around, tripping painfully into piles of hard steel, and stomping on different items from rusty screws to the old highlight of a time-forgotten Harley. He stumbled into the small office shack of the scrapyard. He was missing one brown sandal and his other had a collection of small metallic bits protruding uncomfortable around his toes. Somehow, he had not been seriously stabbed by any of the sharp, rusty objects laying around. He thanked his very calloused feet and decided to reward them by allowing them rest. He laid on the floor of the small building and immediately fell asleep.

That night was very unpleasant but the wasted traveler paid no mind as he snoozed right through it, cuddling a paper filled binder close to his chest and sucking on his thumb. The building, however, was much more displeased. It swayed and creaked in defiance of the sandy storm's mighty roar. The wind was so intense that large pieces of shrapnel punctured the thin walls of the shack. By the time the storm ceased, the shack looked like a giant wooden pin cushion and a wall had partly collapsed.

"Mwwwwuuuuuuuuuuuuaaaaahh... Ouf.. me head."

The wasted traveler awoke from his sleep with a yawn and examined his surroundings with a very blurry and confused gaze. He had little to no remembrance of being kicked out of town and wandering for hours upon hours. He had no idea how he got here and why he was clutching a drool-covered white binder. He dropped the binder and picked up his valiant staff. He put his feet down and raised himself with the staff and then proceeded out the door.

"The sun, me old nemesis. Grhh.. I hate headaches."

He was oddly fine with his lack of information about his surroundings and predicament. He looked at the wall of metallic spikes while holding his head with his right hand.
Interesting decor to say the least.
He managed to find a way out of the scrapyard rather quickly when it was bright and he wasn't as drunk. He continued to keep going forward, shielding his eyes from the the sun and stopping a few times to vomit. Eventually, he spotted a truck on the horizon and went prone. He squinted, causing his headache to increase in pain, and could barely make out a figure near the truck. He pondered whether or not he should make contact with the man when suddenly he heard a moan from behind him.
On may 31, 2013
MadDonut

Me and BlackVoid are sorting out documentation to take over Die2Write: the passing of the keys, legal reviewing of foot-thick folders, and worshiping of the great and honorable Epoq for treats..

But, while we sort that out, we need judges! Three in fact. First come first serve.

So this all means...

THE GRAND RETURN OF DIE2WRITE!

All the same stuff, but with new themes! Get your pencils sharpened, your typewriters oiled, your blood pouring from your finger tips, 'cause we 'bout to rock the boat!

Which is a really difficult thing to do since it's sitting on sand so we're going to have to use a lot of force, which shouldn't be too hard for me for I am The Almighty Pastry..

I'm figuring 6 days to write and 1 day to give judges time to judge for each of the three rounds (judges can also judge whatever entries are already provided, of course).

If you're free for roughly four weeks from now, then welcome to the judge panel! If not, maybe next time.

Writers, feel free to write before and after each contest! There will be brief breaks between each contest because I'm pretty sure Epoq doesn't want to keep giving out free rewards all the time.

On june 1, 2013
Rellik147

Day 3
we've been out here for 3 days now searching saws he saw buildings in the west he did! I haven't seen any bloody buildings and I'm so thirsty! He's one of those big shots you know the guys that swan around town carrying people back from the wastes, returning from the furthest reaches in the blink of an eye, even when they get tired sometimes if you see them fall from exhaustion from fighting off zombies with their bare hands! they just look at the brown dirt they have fallen too for a moment, then they stand bolt upright and continue with a new fire in their eyes. well this ones name was Daryl he was a survivalist he's a hero I must trust him.

Day 4
even while I wither away in the wastes he can find food and water, but just enough for himself he says, puddles and roots, puddles and roots. that's all they ever look out for you know! Number one! I feel so weak

Day 5
I collapsed today, near another body, a fellow traveller, Daryl didn't care much, but I tried eating the dirt near him today, it was wet, my hero told me not too, that is was dangerous but I needed something, anyway this is the man who's happy to see me die of my basic primal needs! it tasted bad at first it was a kind of congealed blob, I say dirt because I have no other word for it, but it burst and sweet thick liquid enters my mouth, I feel better now.

Day 6
I got so thirsty and hungry and he would not share, he sleeps now so I took it from him, in the night, while he slept, didn't see it coming, didn't want me to have it! he sleeps now
I drank deep of what he provided and feasted on the bounty of food! There was much more than I had expected it began to fill me as I ate from him. I'm tired now

Day 7
gonna go back to town, there are lots more of puddles and roots there!

On june 2, 2013
Scrimshaw

So there I was, fighting off three zombies at once when I noticed Vinnie's pinky ring at the top of a zombie dung heap - proving Vinnie had been eaten at least a few days before. This is what I needed to get the town off my back, now they couldn't justify hanging me the next morning. Problem was, I was too busy fighting, chopping, blocking, and running out of strength.

Then it happened, the inner wall fell, right on top of the pile of festering dung and Vinnie's ring. I was fighting to live but if I lived I would die by the hands of my town's residents. Did it matter if I won even if I lost in the end? About that time one of the hero's came over and tore through a couple of the zombies with a machete, and then threw an exploding water bomb - there was a tremendous steam cloud that quickly spawned and I could barely see in front of me.

Confused, I started twirling around and slashing with my Box Cutters in each hand just hoping to rip at anything too close. My left hand suddenly went into what felt like jello - I had punched through the gut of a zombie and yet could not pull it back out quickly, as my knife and hand were inside the zed's ribcage, and then his mouth came toward me, snapping his blackened teeth and pulling me closer, so close that I, that I...
On june 2, 2013
Fineous

So I had a random bout of insomnia the other day, and decided to write a short story for the town telling a story from a rather different perspective, and it turned into a story of how the zombie plague came to be. A couple of my fellow townies told me to post it into the world forums, and since this thread is here it seemed like a good place to do it. I hope you enjoy.

The Confession -

There is something that no one ever seems to think about as the world is ending. What happens afterwards? Now this is a pretty understandable mistake to make, as the whole concept of ending usually implies that there will not be anything afterwards. And yet, there is. Is it hell? Did the end of the world actually kill us all and now we have wound up in a hell not full of pitchfork wielding demons, but shambling hordes of brain eating zombies?
I know the truth, however. I know what caused it.
It was me.
Allow me to introduce myself. My name is Dr. Albert Curie Tesla Smith. No, the name isn‚Äôt a joke, my parents decided that I would be a scientist even before I was born, and they decided that simply being Dr. Smith wouldn‚Äôt be sufficiently ‚Äòsciency‚Äô for lack of a better word. So they decided to name me after 3 of history‚Äôs greatest minds. And then they forced me into the mold they had chosen for me. And I was a good boy. I did what my parents told me.
My doctorate is technically in Nanomechanical Bio-Engineering. Which means I built little tiny‚Ä¶ well, you can call them machines, but the word breaks down when you get into things that small. Is it a machine if it is really just a string of proteins and RNA inside a cellular wall? We did have a different word for them once.
We called them Viruses.
And I built one, piece by meticulous piece. I built one to order. I designed it to heal. It would do everything that our own bodies couldn‚Äôt do, and do it on the cellular level. It would find wounds, and heal them by constructing individual cells and linking them together in a latticework, just as our own bodies do, only thousands of times faster. And I solved the issue of making them figure out how to do all this, by networking them all together. One, or one hundred, or even a hundred thousand was pretty much useless. But a billion? 10 billion? 100 billion? They could follow simple programs.
Ahh, hubris. I thought I could make humanity immortal with my machines. We would live forever. The virus did what it was programmed to do, and it made sure that we didn‚Äôt die. We couldn‚Äôt. The virus would prevent that from happening. But I made my mistakes. It wasn‚Äôt ready to be used, I did understand that, I am a scientist after all. I knew that the virus was not ready for human testing, though I had high hopes. It worked in a small scale test in laboratories, on rats, but that was a long way from human testing. But I forgot about two ‚Äòlittle‚Äô things. The purpose of all viruses is to reproduce, and I had used a virus as the core of my ‚Äòmachine‚Äô. So it reproduced. The second thing is that a rat that is pissed off from poking and prodding will bite, and rat teeth are really good at chewing through things. And so it bit me, and I made my third mistake. I swore, cleaned out the wound, and went home.
My virus operated at a greatly accelerated rate. It used up the resources in a human body very quickly, building cells, repairing damage. The human body is a complex machine after all. And it needs a lot of resources. That first day it spread through my body rapidy, using my own body‚Äôs resources to reproduce itself, causing horrific damage to me on a cellular level in the process, though that took the better part of a day to occur. So when I washed out my bite at home I didn‚Äôt know that anything was wrong, though I felt a little under the weather. The virus did what viruses do, however, and it spread into the water supply, and then of course inexorably the virus spread into the food chain, quickly breaking down anything it came into contact with, and then doing what it was programmed to do. Build a human body. From the ground up.
Do you know how much of the human body is water? How much is used up when you build a human out of raw materials? That is what most of those poor wretches are out there, human bodies created virtually from nothing by a virus doing what it is programmed to do. Only there is one problem. The human mind takes time to develop. Years to reach the point where it is really capable of anything that could remotely be conceived of as thought, and that is only if the brain is taught. The virus, however, is not a loving parent. All it can do is keep the poor wretch stumbling around, constantly hungry, looking for food, as any baby would be, and since most of the food has been eaten already, well actually dissolved into component parts would be a better term, the only readily available source any more is humanity. Because the virus can‚Äôt think, you see. It can‚Äôt reason that the person its host is eating is a human being that it should be protecting; it is simply a source of food. But within a few bites, the virus settles into the new host, and then it starts to breed when it discovers something that its programming recognizes.
At this point you might be thinking, well, why is that so bad? Admittedly the poor wretches that were created virtually from nothing had no minds to speak of, but what about a thinking human being? We already have minds. And the virus is designed to make us immortal. Why would that be so bad? And the simple fact of the matter is that when the virus spreads throughout the entire body it gains enough processing power to override the nerve impulses in the synapses of a human body. And then you get to the true horror of it all. You see, I specifically designed this version of the virus to leave the brain alone. I am no neural scientist. I intended to work with an expert later on to work on a way to help victims of brain trauma, but I hadn‚Äôt gotten that far yet. I was still in the preliminary stages after all. So the virus can‚Äôt modify the brain, though it seems to do a decent job of building a basic one. But it can control the body readily enough. Control it enough to search out more sources of food, and more ways to breed.
The remaining uninfected humans have discovered that pouring water onto one of the infected dissolves the body. They think that it is a good way to kill the infected, but they are wrong. What they are seeing isn‚Äôt destruction, but actually growth. The water gives the virus more raw materials to work with. Yes, the body will break down immediately, but the next day there will be more growing up in its place, once again created from raw materials, using the extra water that it needed. The poor remaining uninfected humans think they have the perfect weapon, but all they are doing is speeding up their own destruction.
On june 2, 2013
Fineous

My body lurches forwards as the virus uses its poor control over my muscles to force me towards the walled fort. I can feel the others around me now, some kind of weird gestalt mind that is created when this many infected are around. We tend to move as one, in a swarm, like a cloud of gnats or a school of fish. I wonder how many of them are intelligent, people become prisoners in their own bodies like me, and how many of them are blank slates, created from nothing like horribly twisted caricatures of the mythic Titans.
We lurch towards the building, and begin slamming our fists into the walls. Eventually we will batter them down. We always do. A few brave souls stand out on the walls, attacking with makeshift weapons, not knowing that the wounds they inflict will be healed again by morning. A few throw some precious water bombs out into the horde, and I see a few infected dissolve down to components cells which sink into the ground as the virus strives to gather all the precious water, and find enough other raw materials to be able to create 2 infected bodies where there was once only one.
My fists pound on the walls and I pray that this time, finally, one of those water bombs will find me, and I will dissolve into unthinking, unfeeling goo, and my pitiful hellish existence will finally be over. Perhaps I have finally paid enough for my sins.
A small crack is developing in the wall in front of me. I hear arguing and bickering from inside. This small walled town is not ready for us, and the recriminations fly. I can hear people blaming one another. The crack in the wall widens slightly. Already it is at the point where if I were in control of my body I could simply slip my hands into the crack and rip it open. But the virus cannot reason that well. All it can do is pound on the wall, but that will be enough. Eventually. The horde cannot ever truly be stopped.
The sun comes up, and the town is still standing. The sun begins to beat down, and the horde retreats. I am not sure how it happened, but the horde has learned that the sunlight will eventually desiccate a body to the point where the virus is forced to go dormant, and so when the sun comes up we retreat to bury ourselves in the sand, or to hide in old ruined buildings, or any other place where we can escape the heat. A few remain active, again part of the primitive collective intellect of the virus having learned the uninfected will be out to search for useful supplies during the day. Today I am one of the ones that has buried themselves.
Hours pass, and I hear someone moving overhead, but the hive mind does not allow me to react. I can hear digging and scrabbling as the survivor looks for anything in the vicinity that they could use. I can also feel several of the infected lurching around on the surface, trying to fulfill their programming and spread to a new host. It sounds as though the survivor up there is able to keep away from them, however. Every now and then I can hear a loud thud, probably the survivor pushing over the infected on the surface in order to buy some more time to get away. I hope they succeed. The sounds of digging and movement stop after a while, and I think the survivor has moved on. I would breathe a sigh of relief if I could, but I am not in control of my body enough to even do that, and it is not as if I breathe any more anyway. Somehow the virus appears to be turning my body into a fully anaerobic machine. I try to work out how and why it is doing that, and the musing allows me to keep what is left of my sanity for another day.
Eventually I dig myself free of the sand, emerging into the night once again. Around me I see the rest of the horde clawing their way up out of the sand, in a horrific parody of birth, and as one we turn and lurch towards the town again. I hear screams and shouts, ahead. The gates have been shut, but there is still someone outside. There is also someone hanging over the wall on some kind of makeshift gibbet. The survivors are stupid. If they had tacked the body down somewhere outside they could have distracted some of the horde from the attack. The survivor that is outside keeps pounding on the door, screaming, but no one lets him in. The first of the horde reaches him. I wish I could look away, but I am still moving that direction. I wish I could shut out the screams of someone being eaten alive, but I can‚Äôt. At least this time I am not close enough to reach the body in time to take a bite.
The remaining parts of the victim are already beginning to heal as the virus spreads through what is left of the infected tissues. This one reached the threshold of infection very quickly, perhaps due to the large number of bites he received at one time, so his body was mostly intact. Luckily for this one, although he was eaten alive his brain was not left intact enough for him to be sentient when he gets back up again, so at least he will be spared that. The rest of the horde moves past the body, and begins pounding on the walls again. The cracks spread more rapidly than they did the day before. There is evidence of repair work, and now the walls have been studded with bits of razor wire and other assorted old chunks of metal. I watch as my flesh is shredded down to the bone time and time again, thankful that the blocks to my synapses also prevent me from feeling the pain. Again I hear the recriminations and threats being yelled back and forth inside. There are fewer guards up on the walls tonight too, perhaps the one left outside or the one who was hung had been amongst the brave ones fighting yesterday. Towards the dawn we have almost broken down the wall, but once again the town is saved by the dawn.
My body turns and I stumble away. Today I am mobile, staying out of the sand, looking for survivors. I tend to stay more in the shade, but I can feel my body stiffening up as some of the precious water evaporates from my body in some twisted parody of sweating. It is not long before a survivor from the town comes out looking for things to scavenge. This one is a woman, and she clutches a Super Soaker water gun slung from a strap on her shoulder. I lurch towards her, seeing my hands reach out towards her. Around me I feel the other infected that are in the immediate area doing the same. She looks at me, and I see the calculation pass though her eyes. She knocks me down with a quick kick to my knee. I fall over, unable to dodge even a simple kick. As my body begins to laboriously get to its feet I see her shoot a gout of water at a nearby infected. I want to shout ‚ÄúNO, SHOOT ME!‚Äù at her, but of course I can‚Äôt. That infected dissolves quickly, and she runs past the puddle of goo, shooting another as she runs. That one dissolves too. Then she is out of sight, over a hill. Unseen by her, the other infected in the area move towards puddles of goo trying to collect enough water for themselves out of the remains to be able to dissolve themselves. I finally manage to get to my feet and lurch in that direction as I see another of the infected in the area is apparently able to extract enough water to begin the dissolution process itself. Of course, by the time I get there, there is nothing left but a slight stain on the sand. At that point my mind finally snaps, and I give up trying to hold onto my sanity. I am cursed. I will be trapped in this hellish existence forever, as punishment for my crimes.
I do not know how much time I lose, but when I come too again I am standing in the wreckage of the town. No one is left except for infected, and as one the horde turns and moves off to the north. Somehow we know that there are surviving uninfected in that direction.
There won‚Äôt be for long.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Ladies and gentlemen...
It is time to write, and to die!

The contest officially begins; judges are getting ready to judge, the MTPasses are being polished, pencils are being sharpened by blades..


To start off the trio of rounds, the first round's theme is The Almighty Pastry. Write anything relating to The Almighty Pastry and his lore. Or write new lore, folktale, origin, etc. It can be praising, silly, serious, bashing- I don't mind. I just wanna read some amazing stories.

Now some of you of course probably find it a bit egotistical of me, so there is a backup theme of Die2Nite-Based Religion. Write about any Die2Nite religions or make up your own. It just has to be within the Die2Nite universe.


And with that I say..
LET THE GAMES BEGIN!

6/21/2013
On june 18, 2013
Rosslessness

Blind Faith


We always idolise that which we desire most. In my time I‚Äôve wanted knowledge and fame, riches and beauty, fast cars and even faster women.

Then the world ended, and in the unrelenting chaos I realise I never stopped worshipping those precious things.

‚ÄúJust pray we find a hacksaw today‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd kill every single one of you to build that Aqua Splash.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust give me the Valium and I‚Äôll follow you to the end of the earth.‚Äù

Our saints became the scavengers, the butchers, the heroes. We admire the crow, pecking at the carcass of humanity in order to survive. We dream about the great pastry and believe his hollow promises of safety and the final victory over the horde. We worship anyone who promises us a full belly.

The Shamans were always there, hidden behind old shop fronts and deep in the woods. Now that civilisation is dust they can finally make their way out of the blinding desert, and into our towns. In a world where death is the only constant they bring a strange kind of peace. They are the confirmation that we have souls, and that there is a life beyond this one. They can promise us an escape from the misery and pain, and all for such a small price.

We pile reinforcements and sheet metal on their flimsy houses, protecting them so they can ferry our souls safely back to our loved ones. We protect their frail bodies with our blood and sweat. We make sure they‚Äôre the last person left, able to give last rites to entire towns.

We pay a heavy price to save our souls.

by Rosslessness

I also love my Atom Death and grow weary of each of these passing days that I have to suffer through until I again get to bask in the radioactive glow of a freshly imploded Reactor...

On june 19, 2013
Colette

The Great Spirits.
By Colette.

‚ÄúIf only this ocean of sand was an ocean of water...‚Äù

I mumbled that to myself as I reached the top of a sand dune, the tallest I could see around. From there, I started watching the landscape around me. Sand, and only sand, sand so far as my eyes could see. Not a single cloud in the sky, whose azure tones merged hypnotically with the mirage dancing in the horizon. But the only reply to my words was the high-pitched yip next to me feet. Itchykins, my dog, stared at me as he panted heavily. I took a gulp from my water canteen and poured some of the water onto the labradoodle's mouth. Feeling better, he wagged his tail and barked. I felt better too. From my position, I spotted something in the horizon. A number of big rocks were strewn around in the sand. I thought it would be worth investigating it, so we continued walking through the scorching desert.

A few minutes later, I felt exhausted. The rocks were close already, but all the weight of the junk I picked and now I carried around was definitely taking a toll on my undernourished body. I felt hungry, and I couldn't remember when was the last time I had eaten something that wasn't moldy, raw and/or alive. I was lucky that this natural formation of rocks in that place of the desert was tall enough that it gave a bit of shade if I remained on the side opposite to the sun. One of the rocks in the shade was large and flat enough so I could rest there. Although I heard a large snake hissing nearby as saw it coiled on top of the rock, I scared it off throwing a few small rocks at it. It quickly scurried away. I sat and, without thinking too much, put my bag around Itchykins' neck. I didn't have to say anything to him. He knew what that meant. He ran off at full speed, heading back to the town on his three legs, despite the scorching heat and the long distance to it. I wished I was so full of energy like that.

Sitting there by myself,I stared at the blue sky. Thinking. Once more, I made the same question I made to myself every day. Was it really worth living that way? But I reached the same conclusion as always. That was not living. We all were dead already. Some tried to deny that truth and kept clinging on to hope. Others refused to resign, saying that they would keep fighting to the bitter end. And others, like me, pretended to have hope and kept going, but knowing that we wouldn't last long. The rest were simply too drunk or too stupid to see our impending demise. They demanded citizens to keep building those improvised defenses, hoping they would hold out. I remembered something. A phrase I read somewhere, though I can't remember who said it, or when: ‚ÄúFortifications are a monument to the stupidity of man‚Äù, they said. I finally understood what it meant. With more of them coming every midnight, we were powerless. We couldn't fight them. Not all of them. The defenses would ultimately overrun and we all would get killed. But I couldn't blame those people for being blind in their ignorance. Nobody wanted to die anyway.

The biggest irony, however, was the true nature of those citizen's intentions. Of those who refused to die and kept demanding everyone to keep working. ‚ÄúIt's all for the benefit of the town‚Äù, they said. As they demanded citizens to keep risking their lives for the town, they all said it was for the benefit of the community. And for them, the death of a single citizen was of little concern. It didn't matter to the town's survival as a whole, anyway. They thought of me, of us, as a little more than expendable worker bees. But I had seen it before. I knew well what they really planned. With people like them, it is all about teamwork until the leave you to die by yourself as they take care of their own survival when things go awry. People are always the same selfish creatures.

I sighed loudly when a noise interrupted this moment of rest and reflection. It was the unmistakable groaning of a zombie. At least they were always kind enough to warn me of their presence, groaning deeply before they approached. It was a single zombie, and I certainly could keep it at bay if I needed to. But I knew that I would not feel easy as long as that rotter lurked around. I reached for my bag, but it wasn't there anymore. I remembered I had sent Itchykins with it back to town, and I had forgotten to take my Battery Launcher Mk.II out of it. I mumbled some impolite words as I tried to back off from the zombie. Building that Launcher had gotten me into trouble with some of the worst people in town. Jack, who thought of himself as some sort of comedian, making unfunny jokes at the worst time possible, had publicly affronted me for that. It was obvious for me that he was the kind of person that turns tail and leaves you to die by yourself if things didn't went as they wish. I had to endure all that criticism to keep myself safe, but all that would be useless if I got killed there.

However, I was suddenly blinded by a bluish flash of light. I had no idea of what had happened. I opened my eyes, only to see a bright blue orb of light floating in front of me, just between the zombie and me. It looked like a ball of blue fire, burning silently with an eerie glow. I felt too scared to even move. Was it one of those ball lightnings I had read about? It was unlikely. The sky was clear and cloudless. And that orb floated silently in front of me, as it appeared to be burning. But it disappeared suddenly, as quickly as it had appeared. It vanished without a trace, and I wondered if it had only been an hallucination. The zombie, however, also remained immobile. I could swear I saw some surprise in its dead blank eyes. In that moment of distraction, I pushed the zombie back with all my strength, hoping to make it fall so I could run away safely. I was lucky that the zombie hit its head against one of the rocks, and its skull cracked open. I have to admit that killing that zombie with my bare hands was as satisfying as it was disgusting.

Itchykins returned to me a few minutes later, with an exhausted stare in his eyes. Deciding that I had had enough for the day, we headed back home. I wasn't in the mood to keep searching for junk out in the desert. I was still puzzled about the incident that had just happened.

The next day, early in the morning. The sky was still dark and the sun was about to rise up in the eastern skies. I was awakened by a sudden series of bustling noises outside. For some strange reason I felt compelled to go outside and investigate. As I reached the town's plaza, I was surprised to see a murder of crows, a pretty fitting name for a group of such birds, feeding on the body of David, the man who claimed to be the town's shaman. He was dead, and it seemed like his death had been very recent. I could see that he was still wearing his wooden mask. I tried to scare the birds off, waving my arms menacingly. They took flight, crowing loudly and flapping their wings and flying off into the desert. One of them, however, a particularly large crow, remained standing over the corpse and stared at me, seeming defiant, before taking a piece of the corpse's liver on its beak and flying away. Witnessing that just made me shiver.

David had been the town's self-proclaimed shaman, who said he could establish a connection with the spirits. He claimed that to be able to cure sickness and problems with his mystical power. Nobody believed him, though, as we all knew that he was just a senile old man. But as I saw his corpse lying on the town's plaza, I noticed a book we was clutching tightly between his still warm arms. I got the impression that he had died defending that book from someone or something. I took the book and returned home. The last thing I wanted was to be found next to the corpse and end up being the scapegoat accused for his death.

I put my bedside lamp next to me and placed a battery inside the thing. I had managed to smuggle those with me from the desert without telling anyone, and if someone saw me using that battery, they would definitely get mad at me. With that faint light from the lamp I started reading the book. It was a very old book, with all its pages showing that yellowish color of all the decades it had survived. Some pages were torn, and others were missing. And someone had scribbled notes and corrections all over it, some looking newer than others. But one of the pages caught my attention. I read the title. A short story was entitled ‚ÄúGreat Spirits‚Äù and another was called ‚ÄúLost Souls‚Äù. I assumed that it was the reason why the old man David had become crazy, reading books about spirits and that kind of things. As I held the book in my hands to read it, I noticed a small piece of paper falling off from between two pages. A small paper sheet. The type of paper was completely different to that of the book. It was new and made of low-quality paper. I saw that it was some sort of sales report document from a PI-KEYA Furniture shop. What was interesting, though, was that someone had written recently something on the back. I assumed it was David's. The handwriting was small and difficult to read, but I managed to read it with a bit of effort:
On june 19, 2013
Colette

‚ÄúThe Shakano tribe of natives lived once on this desert. They had a very strong connection with the mystical forces that drive this planet. I heard from them when I was a child. My grandfather used to tell me the stories of the Shakano, and gave me this book. I always thought of it as a collection of mythological stories and the religious texts of a tribe that disappeared already. But now I know that it is all true.

I have seen it. The spirit of Or-Ateni is in this area. He flies around and perches atop of the watchtower, mocking me with its dark shiny eyes. I know that my demise is close. Those who find these notes, be wary of Or-Ateni. He and his army of fiends will definitely attempt to kill you. The mask I wear will show you visions of those who roam the desert. Use the power of the wanderers to aid you.‚Äù

I dismissed the text as the ramblings of a crazy old man with paranoid delusions. However, I was more interested in the book itself, so I started reading it in a hurry before dawn arrived:

‚ÄúThe Great Spirits

According to the Shakano folklore, The Great Spirits are the gods and goddesses who created this world. According to their legends, the Great Spirits are limitless as the stars, bigger than the sun and the moon, and stronger than anything the human mind can imagine. The Great Spirits created everything with their boundless power. They created the human race, and then created the lesser Spirits to guide them in their lives, and keep them safe as long as the humans worshipped them.

The four lesser Spirits were Ashanat, the spirit of water and life; Masati, the spirit of fire and war, Akot, the spirit of food and prosperity, and Or-Ateni, the spirit of night and death. They were represented by the eagle, the wolf, the snake and the crow, respectively, and they believed that the Spirits took their animal forms to watch their people closely.

The Great Spirits and the lesser Spirits were all revered by the shamans of the Shakano tribe, who used their connection with them to lead their tribe, and to make their most important decisions. The Shakano made great, complex ceremonies where they believed that the Spirits blessed objects and amulets, that would protect the wearer and would allow them to form a connection with them

However, at a time of crisis, a deadly disease appeared from out of nowhere, killing one third of the population of the tribe in just a few months. The survivors felt betrayed by the Spirits and placed the blame on Or-Ateni, the Spirit of death, who had failed to protect them from the plague, causing the premature deaths of many people. For this reason, they stopped worshiping him as one of the Spirits. And Or-Ateni felt deeply offended...‚Äù

The story continued, but I heard someone ringing the watchtower's bell. That meant it was time to get up and start working. I turned off and hid my lamp and the book, awakened my labradoodle and went outside to start that day's hard labor.

As I stocked up on supplies from the bank for that day's expedition, and as I hid my Battery Launcher from my envious neighbors' eyes, I couldn't help but keep thinking about the story about the spirits. Or-Ateni, the Spirit of death who took form of a crow, the note David wrote about seeing the Spirit in the area and knowing about his impending demise, and that murder of crows that were feasting on his dead body. And especially that crow that stared and me and creeped me out. Was it all a coincidence? I knew it had to be. Spirits and ghosts are nothing but fairy tales told to children to scare them, and the story was just a mythological tale from a tribe that didn't exist anymore, if it ever existed.

A few minutes later, as I headed towards the town's gates, I was readying myself to go out into the desert once more when I looked up to the watchtower and saw that big black bird perched at the top, staring at me, giving me the same creepy sensation I had felt previously. But trying to avoid relating it to the story I had read, I headed outside.

I took the same route as the previous day, as there had been places that I had missed or not searched thoroughly. But my mind was still thinking about the tale I had read early that morning. I could swear that I still could see the stare of that crow when I closed my eyes.

When I felt exhausted, I sent Itchykins back to town once more, this time making sure he only took the stuff I didn't need. I sat on the same rock like the last time. This time I closed my eyes to try and relax for a minute, which could hopefully help me clear my mind a little. But just a few seconds later, I heard my dog barking like mad. I had never heard him barking so desperately. I opened my eyes and took my weapon, ready to help my dear friend if he was in danger. But I saw how that bright blue orb of fire had appeared just in front of him. The orb disappeared after ten or fifteen seconds, and the dog's barking ceased as soon as it disappeared. Then Itchykins returned to town like nothing had happened. I wondered again if that had really happened, or if I was just hallucinating. Was I losing my mind, just like David had lost his?

Later that day, I found myself back in town. All of my thoughts revolved around that old book and its story. It was starting to obsess me. With little regard about what my neighbors thought, I didn't even place the junk I picked from the desert on the town's bank. I locked myself up in my shack and took the book from where I had hidden it. I kept on reading the same story that I had read in the morning:

‚ÄúOr-Ateni, the lesser Spirit of death who took the form of the crow, was chased away by the Shakano people. He retreated into the desert, to plan his revenge. As the years went by, as he started putting all of the mankind under a curse. That course would befall onto the descendants of those who had offended him, and it would then spread to all of the humanity. The curse says that the day when people have lost all their faith in the Great Spirits, the dead will rise from their graves. His army of the dead sits silently in the netherworld, until the day of the awakening, in which they will drag all of the humanity into the ranks of Or-Ateni's army of the dead, until no person is left alive.‚Äù

That was the end of the first story. I quickly read the second story:



‚ÄúThe Lost Souls.

It is said that those who fall before the curse of Or-Ateni will transform into monsters. Shambling monsters seeking to feed on the living beings. The only way to stop them will be to use the powers of Ashanat, the spirit of water and life.

However, those that fall victims to the curse of Or-Ateni will be trapped between this world and the netherworld. Their bodies will belong to Or-Ateni, but their souls will roam in the world for eternity. They are called the Lost Souls, or the Wanderers. It is said that they will take the form of an eternal blue flame, moving though the desert for the rest time. Only those with the holy mask of the Shakano shaman would be capable of reading their movements and use their mystical power to form a bond with Ashanat and destroy Or-Ateni's curse. When Or-Ateni's curse is broken, the army of the dead will stop and the Lost Souls will be able to have their eternal rest.‚Äù

I stopped reading after this. I could see why David had become obsessed. The zombies being destroyed by water. The crow lingering around the town. The orbs of blue light wandering around the desert. It was too much to be a simple coincidence. My mind was overwhelmed by that. My eyes had seen it all.

I went to the town's small cemetery. I knew David's corpse would not be there anymore, as it was dumped out of town as per the town's rules. But I found that his mask and his useless belongings had been placed over his improvised grave as a sign of respect. It was a round wooden mask, that seemed to be very old.I put it on, but I didn't feel anything unusual. But when I closed my eyes, I saw something, like an image projected directly on my mind. An image of the desert from above, as if I was flying and could see everything from above. As if I could see from the eyes of an eagle. And those orbs of blue fire moving around in circles. If I concentrated enough, I knew I could predict their movement.

I smiled and brought the mask to my home. I knew that trying to convince people about what I had seen would be impossible. They would think of me as a madwoman, like I had thought of David. I was the only one who could use that power. I went outside, and saw that big crow perched on top of the watchtower, staring at me. But I didn't feel afraid. I smiled at him. As long as the Shakano shaman's mask existed, we would have hopes of destroying the curse. I just needed to find a way of reaching Ashanat, using the wandering souls of the dead, so the zombie curse could be lifted. Now I could cling onto hope myself. And have faith on the Great Spirits. I just had to survive long enough to see that day arrive.
On june 19, 2013
Rosslessness

‚ÄúIf only this ocean of sand was an ocean of water...‚Äù

On june 19, 2013
Colette

On june 20, 2013
Fineous

‚ÄúBrother Robert, are the monsters coming to eat us?‚Äù I pulled my cassock slightly tighter around myself, tying my belt tighter to give myself one last moment before I had to answer that question. Oh, how I wished sometimes that the abbot were still alive to release me from my oath to tell no falsehoods.
‚ÄúYes Lizzie. The monsters are coming.‚Äù Her brave little face, smudged and dirtied by the harsh existence we had followed since I found her 2 weeks ago, scrunched up in fear. But she gripped my hand tightly, and looked up at me with her trusting eyes.
‚ÄúIt is o.k. Brother Robert. I know you will save us.‚Äù I looked down at her, wishing that I could do just such a thing. But I did not know how. What could I do to save us? There were dozens of zombies outside the building. They battered on the walls tirelessly, and I could see the cracks forming already. From time to time one would try to force its hand through the crack to reach us, but so far there was no way for it to reach us. I didn‚Äôt hold out much hope for us surviving the night, however.
I pulled Lizzie close to me, and crooned gently to her, trying to rock her to sleep. Despite the terror of being inside a building that was slowly being battered down, her exhaustion showed through. It took only a few minutes of gentle rocking and tuneless singing for her to fall deeply asleep. I smoothed the hair back from her forehead, and leaned down to kiss her gently. And then, carefully, just the way I had been taught all those years before in the Rangers, I snapped her neck.
The tears rolled down my cheeks. I had sworn, when I took my vows all those years before, that I would never kill again. I had done that too much in the past, killing for my country. Killing because I was told to. Killing because I had grown to like it.
The abbot took me in, saw me for the broken soul that I was, and taught me to seek the Lord‚Äôs forgiveness for all that I had done in the past. And over the years I had grown to believe that perhaps, just perhaps, I had managed to earn a little of that forgiveness.
That was then. And now‚Ä¶ Now I had killed once again. Killed an innocent girl. Ended her existence in this world because I felt that her being eaten alive would not serve God‚Äôs plan. Yet truthfully, how was I to know what God‚Äôs plan was? Who was I to second guess the ineffable? Did I truly do it for her? Or did I do it because I did not want to see her suffering? I buried my face in my hands, and waited for the end to come.
I am not sure how long it was before I noticed the soft blue radiance around me. I looked up in wonder, seeing a shimmering blue flame that hovered in the air in front of me. I reached out to touch it, and was astonished when it leapt towards my open hand, and nestled within my cupped palm. And then I felt it. I knew what it was. It was Lizzie. Beautiful, pure, innocent Lizzie. Her very soul was cupped in my hand. I felt no recrimination. I felt no hatred. I felt only her trust, and the simple all-encompassing love that only a child can possess. I smiled through my tears. Dear little Lizzie wanted me to know that I was forgiven, before the zombies came to eat me. I wiped my tears away with the back of my hand, and cupped the essence of Lizzie‚Äôs soul in both hands. I closed my eyes, and bowed my head in prayer.
‚ÄúYea though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death‚Ä¶‚Äù My words were drowned out over the splintering of the wood around me. I closed my eyes, and thrust Lizzie‚Äôs soul upwards, wanting her to be free from here, not wanting her pure soul to be forced to watch me being eaten. I clasped my hands in front of me and finished my prayer. ‚Äú‚Ä¶I will fear no evil: for thou art with me; thy rod and thy staff they comfort me.‚Äù I opened my arms wide, and waited for the end.
It was a moment or two before I opened my eyes again, wondering why I was not yet dead. The pure blue radiance of Lizzie‚Äôs spirit had changed to a deep red, and the zombies all around began to melt as it somehow began to rain inside the wreck of the building. I stood, staring around myself in amazement. This truly was a miracle. Or was it? Was this truly a divine miracle? Somehow I had always thought that the feeling would be different. This did not have the feel of God to it. No, it was different from that. Not God, but certainly... something.
As I stared around myself, wondering, the red glow began to fade from the air around me. It seemed as though the light began to pool onto the splintered wood that lay all around me. The light grew for a moment, pulsing, and then faded away completely. Though the glow was gone, not everything was as it had been before. Where there had been only splinters of wood, now there was a mask of some sort. Odd whorls and curls covered the surface in an intricate design that my eyes could not seem to follow. Staring at it made me slightly dizzy, yet I could not look away. It was as though those strange designs were some kind of message for me, instructions on what needed to be done.
I don‚Äôt know how long I stared at the mask, communing with‚Ä¶ something. But I did suddenly know when I was finished. Staring at the mask no longer hurt me. My confusion was gone, and my perceptions were sharp. I picked up the mask, and put it on. I knew my purpose. I was resolute.
The first aimless soul was drifting only a few meters away, and with my new abilities it was child‚Äôs play to reach out and grab it. The soul flowed up my arm, and settled into my mask, becoming a part of it. I knew, without looking at it, that a new whorl had appeared on its surface. The next one was slightly further away, but I reached it easily enough. The third was a much longer hike, but it was right where I knew it was. And then I sensed them, a whole town full of souls. I crested a dune and saw a town that was more of a walled fort than simply a town. I moved forwards, seeing all the souls within. It took me a moment to realize that these souls were still encased in flesh.
I walked towards the town, hearing the lookouts shouting about the horde on the horizon. They did not believe that they were strong enough to survive the night. In the last minute rush to close the gates I managed to get inside. I walked to the town square, drew water from the well, and collected other supplies that I somehow knew that I would need. And then holding aloft a rough shaped sword constructed from scrap metal I screamed out some words in a language that no human mouth had ever before spoken, and thrust the sword into the ground. There was a pulse of light, and a red radiance settled over the town. Cries of joy came from the walls, as they saw what I already knew. The zombies could not even pass through the radiance, let alone reach the walls.
They straggled in from all over town, a few at a time. They clutched makeshift weapons, but were too afraid to lift them. I stood in front of the Sword of Bokor, raising my hands in the air.
‚ÄúI bring the tidings of the Lord of Spirit. The bondage of your flesh is coming to an end. Give him your obeisance and he will grant you the protection that only he can bring. Kneel down and worship him!‚Äù
My words held power, and without hesitation they all bowed down. These few here would be my first disciples. They would go out, and spread the word, and we would free spirit from the bondage of the flesh. It would take time. We had to interact within the physical world, but eventually all would be freed.
I reached up to caress my mask, the mask created with the last of Lizzie‚Äôs essence. For a moment I almost felt as though I could hear a little girl‚Äôs tortured scream. But then I once again felt my Lord‚Äôs power rush through me, and felt the rightness of my actions.
There was much work to be done.
On june 20, 2013
Lynnette

Sis, that was a lengthy but creative story. I see you've spent some quality time honing your lore and legends.

On june 21, 2013
