On june 22, 2013
SaucyemmettC

Fun In The Sun Part 1

Four men sat around the fire. It was dark. It was quiet. They were alone.
‚ÄúWell‚Ä¶‚Äù, meekly huffed the first man.
‚ÄúWell?‚Äù, sarcastically puffed the second.
‚ÄúGrunt‚Äù, sadly grunted the third man.
‚ÄúFuck‚Äù quietly whimpered the fourth man.
‚ÄúWell‚Ä¶‚Äù, repeated the first man, cautiously turning his head to meet the second man‚Äôs glare, ‚Äúwhat now?‚Äù The second man chuckled villainously.
‚ÄúNow?‚Äù, he asked, ‚Äúwe wait‚Äù.
*Grunt*
*Whimper*
‚ÄúFor?‚Äù asked the first man cautiously. The second man let out another malicious chuckle.
‚ÄúWhat else‚Äù.
*Grunt*
*Whimper*
‚ÄúNo‚Ä¶‚Äù, pleaded the first man, ‚ÄúNo no no no NO!‚Äù. He stood up in defiance, eyes consumed in panic.
‚ÄúSit down and shut up‚Äù, ordered the second man, his voice suddenly humourless.
*Grunt*
*Whimper*
‚ÄúYes sir‚Äù the first man muttered in defeat.
‚ÄúGood‚Ä¶‚Äù, said the second man more lightly, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had a good life haven‚Äôt we?:
*Grunt*
*Whimper*
‚ÄúBut sir‚Ä¶ Why? Why now? We can still run‚Äù, pleaded the first man desperately.
‚ÄúWhere?‚Äù responded the second man mockingly.
*Grunt*
*Whimper*
‚ÄúAnywhere‚Ä¶‚Äù exhaled the first man,
‚ÄúDrop it. And don‚Äôt worry boys, it won‚Äôt take long. I even have some marshmallows and sticks to pass the time‚Äù, jeered the second man.
*Grunt*
*Whimper*
‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been planning this day all along haven‚Äôt you old man?‚Äù, the first man questioned sadly.
‚ÄúHush now boy. And listen. We have a fire. We have marshmallows. All we‚Äôre missing is a good story‚Äù, teased the second man venomously.
*Grunt*
*Whimper*
‚ÄúWhen did you start planning?‚Äù asked the first man suspiciously.
‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt matter now. Does anyone have a tale to tell?‚Äù
*Grunt*
*Whimper*
‚ÄúNo‚Ä¶‚Äù admitted the fist man meekly.
‚ÄúWell then I‚Äôve got one‚Äù, confirmed the second man, eye‚Äôs full of glee.
‚ÄùThere is a ruin out in the wastes, farther out than any sane man would venture. It is said that a wise man lived there, giving wisdom to those who risked the sun and sand for some of his knowledge. The man‚Äôs name itself is unknown, but what is known is that the man is mad. Many a mad men met their end attempting to meet the mad wise man. A nameless child made his way to meet the mad wise man, in hopes that the mad wise man could tell him who his parents were. The nameless child had no memory of mother or father, and had no other cause in life but to find out who they were and to learn who he was. And so the boy left his cardboard box house in the small town of Grotesque Thatch with his pet pig. The nameless child thought it unfit to name his pet pig, he having no name himself, and so never referred to it by anything. The nameless child strapped up everything he owned to his pet pig, two rations of water, a tasty steak, and a staff; and after stealing one last jaffa cake from the withering old woman whose shack he lived behind, he rode north, on the bag of his pet pig. They traveled five days without break before coming across their first ruin. A burnt out schoolhouse. The nameless child dismounted his pet pig, which after being ridden for five days took the opportunity to fall over and slip into sleep. The boy approached the scorched entrance cautiously. The old woman had told him stories of monsters that lurked in such dark places. ‚ÄúHello?‚Äù No answer. The nameless child whistled to his porky friend, and entered the poorly lit place. The school was only one room, with wooden rubble scattered across the floor, but light only entered through the entrance and the sides were completely engulfed in shadow. His pet pig cautiously followed the nameless child into the eerie room, grunting nervously. The nameless child tightened his grip on his staff, slowly scanning the darkest parts of the room from the little lit spot from the entrance. The nameless child‚Äôs pink pal oinked and curiously approached the darkest corner of the schoolhouse. The buy felt a shiver of worry as he followed. As he left the light he saw clearer in the dark, and what he saw mad his knees tremble. A humanoid figure slumped in the darkest corner where his fat friend headed. The nameless child‚Äôs pet pig sniffed it‚Äôs boot. The figure was bulky and still. The boy poked the figures head with his staff gently. Nothing. His pet pig oinked and nudged the figures arm. Nothing. The boy reached out to feel the strangers weirdly flat face but all at once the figure burst to life and snatched the child‚Äôs arm. It stood up on its feet, it‚Äôs joints clanking as they shuffled. The child felt no warmth of the strangers grip. Only cold steel. The child dropped his staff, and stared in horror as the stranger looked down upon him. The stranger dragged the child into the corner, switching spots so that the child could not run. The boy shook all over, tears streamed down his face. The stranger lifted his clunky arms so that its cold steel clamps could grip its head. The child watched as the stranger lifted, pulling its head AAAAAAAAAAHHHHHHH!!!‚Äù

The first, third and fourth man shot up and screamed. The second man burst into gleeful laughter. The third man burst into tears and sat back down, crying into his hands. The fourth man sat back down and picked his oozing marshmallow from the sand. The first man cussed and sat back down last.
‚ÄúThat was cruel old man. You‚Äôre vile‚Äù.
‚ÄúIt was just a joke. The story isn‚Äôt over, and we should hurry, we don‚Äôt know how much time we have left‚Äù. The second man sighed.
‚ÄúFine then old man, pass me another marshmallow‚Äù.
On june 22, 2013
SaucyemmettC

Fun In The Sun Part 2

‚ÄùThe child watched as the stranger lifted, pulling its helmet off. The stranger backed up, into the center of the room where the boy saw him for the first time. The stranger had short blonde hair and ghostly blue eyes. The stranger was coated in poorly forged pots pans and cans, forming a suit of sketchy armor. The stranger stared wildly at the boy, his eyes darting between him and the pig. After a few seconds he commanded, ‚ÄúBoy, come closer so I can see you‚Äù. His voice was clear and smooth. The child stayed glued to the wall. The man smiled calmly. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs ok boy. I mean you no harm. You surprised me is all‚Äù. He still stayed stuck to the wall, his heart pounding so fast his whole body throbbed with it. The nameless child‚Äôs pig let out a loud oink and positioned itself between the man and the child. The man saw this as amusing and let out a humble laugh. ‚ÄúHey boy. I mean it. I was just sleeping I woke up with some strange person in my face. Come on out of the darkness so we can talk face to face‚Äù. The nameless child moved past his pink pal and approached the stranger. The strangers knelt down to meet the child face to face. ‚ÄúHi there‚Äù.
‚ÄúH-h-hello‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd what are you doing out here by yourself little one‚Äù
‚ÄúI-I-I‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúCalm down kid. Nothing to be afraid of here‚Äù. The child took a deep breath, trying to control his heart rate.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not alone‚Äù. The man raised an eyebrow and turned his gaze toward the pig.
‚ÄúNo you aren‚Äôt, hmmm. So what are you two doing all the way out here? Where are your parents?‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking for a man who can tell me that?‚Äù The man tilted his head.
‚ÄúWhat do you mean by that kid‚Äù.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking for the mad wise man out in the desert‚Äù. The man frowned, his eyes becoming a little darker.
‚ÄúHe‚Äôs just a fairy tale kid. He doesn‚Äôt exist‚Äù
‚ÄúThe old woman said he does‚Äù
‚ÄúWell the old woman was wrong kid‚Äù
‚ÄúBut I have to find him. The old woman says he knows everything and if you find him he will answer one question you give him‚Äù. The man sighed.
‚ÄúSorry kid but there aint no man out there like that. Only the cultists‚Äù The nameless child fumed.
‚ÄúHe has to exist! I have to find him!‚Äù The man hung his head and stood back up onto his feet.
‚ÄúCan‚Äôt let you do that kid. You must be from Grotesque Thatch. It‚Äôs the closest town from here. I gotta take you back kid, people are probably worrying about you‚Äù The child grew furious.
‚ÄúNo one cares about me! All I have is with me here!‚Äù The child pointed at his porky friend, who took his cue to oink in defiance. The man sighed.
‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt last 3 days out there‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôve already been here for five‚Äù The man looked at the kid in surprise. His smile came back to him.
‚ÄúYou know kid. You remind me a little of myself when I was your age.‚Äù The man slumped the pack he carried off his back and let it thud onto the ground. A monsterous crash bellowed from the impact. The man unclipped the pack and ruffled through it, pulling out a serrated knife, a water ration, and some duct tape. ‚ÄúLet me see that twig you were poking me with‚Äù. The child went and fetched it from where he had dropped it and gave it to the stranger. The stranger used some of the duct tape to attach the serrated knife onto it, and then handed it back to the nameless child along with the water ration.
‚ÄúDo what you want kid. Just hear this. Avoid the crow cultists. Don‚Äôt listen to a word any of ‚Äòem say. You see any strange person wearing a bone necklace you run and hide‚Äù. The child nodded, and his pink pal oinked. The man walked back into his corner, slumped, and fell back asleep. The kid took the opportunity to steal a doggy bag out of the strangers pack before heading back out. The strange man giggled when he was gone.
‚ÄúHe may just succeed where I failed‚Äù.

‚ÄúHey old man‚Äù, asked the first man, ‚Äúdid you hear that just now‚Äù. The second man giggled.
‚ÄúHush now boy. Time is running out, they‚Äôll be here soon‚Äù. The first man frowned and shoved a burnt marshmallow into his mouth.

‚ÄùThe nameless chilf rode his pig out in the sands for 7 more days. They ran out of food and water on their sixth. He and his pink piggy pal discovered another structure on the seventh. It was a small stone crypt with it‚Äôs door long ago shattered and dispersed. The child dismounted the pig, and peered into the crypt. Inside were a steep set of stairs leading into almost complete darkness. Deep down the boy saw shadow of a dancing light. The boy took his spear off the back of his porky pal and together they descended into the smothering darkness. The farther they went the fouler the air became, and by the time they reached the end of the stairs the child‚Äôs eyes were watering. The room the child and his friend had entered into was a suppressing darkness. The walls, the ground, the ceiling, all were consumed in an impenetrable darkness. All the child could see was a fire sparkling in what could likely be the center of the room. Sitting with it‚Äôs back to the child was a man in a black dustcoat and weathered wide brimmed hat. The child approached the man with his spear extended. When the boy had his spear within a meter of the man, the man shrieked out a horrendous slur of laughter that chilled the boys blood. His pink pal grunted nervously and pushed in front of the child in a meek attempt to defend him. The man turned to face the boy, the fires light illuminated his back , but masked the mans front features from the boy. All the boy could see was the man‚Äôs grotesque smile and his sparkling eyes. ‚ÄúHello there child‚Äù, he giggled, ‚ÄúHow delicious that you would meet me here‚Äù. The boy kept his spear pointed at the man. The man took no notice and instead looked down at the boy‚Äôs pig. ‚ÄúMmm mmm mmm isn‚Äôt that a mighty morsel of pink you got there kid. If I weren‚Äôt full from this family I‚Äôd be suckling on his toes by now‚Äù. The child was horrified by the man.
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt talk to my friend like that!‚Äù
‚ÄúFriend? All friends are food kid.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt eat him I won‚Äôt let you‚Äù The man tilted his head back and let loose another gruesome bellow of laughter.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not gunna eat ‚Äòim kid. I‚Äôm only messing with yah. I got plenty of food down here. You hungry? I got plenty to share‚Äù. The kid looked down at his porky pal to make sure he was all right. His friend was shivering but still stood against the man. The man walked off into the darkness, leaving the child and his pink pal alone by the firelight. The child moved closer to the fire, fearing what may be lurking in the veil of darkness. The man returned several minutes later with a large wet sack. He reached inside and pulled out a mangled piece of flesh, and handed it to the nameless child. ‚ÄúGo on kid, toss it on the fire‚Äù. The child did as he was told, putting the slimy slab of meat on the fire. It sizzled and popped and spit and schlurped. The man handed the kid the slimy sack and said, ‚Äúfor you kid. It takes a brave soul to come down into these depths. You are burning. I can smell it on yah‚Äù. The child sat down across from the man, his pink pal wobbled over and rested it‚Äôs head on his lap. The man kept his face in the shadow of the fire. ‚ÄúSo kid. Have you ever seen it?‚Äù
‚ÄúSeen what sir?‚Äù
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt call me sir. I ain‚Äôt ever earned that title.‚Äù
‚ÄúO.K.‚Äù The man grinned, his smile expanding from ear to ear.
‚ÄúSo kid, have you seen the eye in the sky?‚Äù The child shook his head. The man nodded. He licked his lips and turned, revealing his heavily scared face to the boy. It was smothered in cuts and blood. His lips were cracked, his hair melted to his face. He was disgusting. ‚ÄúListen to me child and listen closely:
‚ÄúIt's all in the eye of the Demon God,
So hide in the light of day!
Beware, don't stare at the Demon God,
At night, you better stay away!‚Äù
Poem By: TheUltimateWarlord
The boy stared at the man. His eye‚Äôs full of awe and terror. The man hid his face in the shadow again.
‚ÄúRemember those words child. And fear the crow. Take sanctuary here anytime, I have to leave soon. The King calls. I‚Äôl show you the way out when you‚Äôre done cooking that meat.‚Äù The child thanked the man and did as the man said, taking hunks of soggy flesh from the bag and cooking them piece by piece. The man watched, giggling and muttering every now and then. When the boy was done the man stood and put his hand on his shoulder, leading him to the staircase.
‚ÄúGoodbye kid. And remember my words!‚Äù The kid nodded and ascended the stairs, his pink pal in tow, both silently agreeing to never go down another flight of dark decrepit stairs.‚Äù
On june 22, 2013
SaucyemmettC

Fun In The Sun Part 3


The first man poked the fourth man. ‚ÄúFuck, he‚Äôs dead‚Äù. The second man nodded.
‚ÄúTook him long enough I surprised he made it this long with the amount of blood he lost.‚Äù The first man scowled at the second man. The third man grunted sadly.
‚ÄúIs the story almost over?‚Äù
‚ÄúMaybe you should shut up and find out you ungrateful bastard‚Äù. The first man sighed.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre out of marshmallows‚Äù.

‚ÄùThe boy rode his pink pal without water for three days before finding an abandoned well. He and his porky pal camped there the night, drinking as much water as they could and bottling as much as they could carry. But when the child awoke the next morning he realized his dire mistake. Water was the most valuable commodity of the sands, and such a store of water would have been found and fought over by many before him. He awoke in a wooden cage being carried by two burly men. He looked around to find a caravan of people, all wearing no shirts, all wearing bone necklaces. The strange armour wearing man‚Äôs words rung in his head, his warning against the bone necklace crow worshipers. And even the strange fiend he met in the tombs warned against the crow. The child looked around for his pink pal but couldn‚Äôt find him.
‚ÄúHey Deagon. The boy‚Äôs awake‚Äù
‚ÄúIs he now‚Äù
‚ÄúYah‚Äù. The two men chuckled.
‚ÄúHey Luth!‚Äù, one man called to another who was walking beside them, ‚ÄúGo tell Stefany the boy‚Äôs awake‚Äù. The third man nodded and ran off. The child observed the caravan, he had never seen so many people before, all wearing no shirts and all wearing bone necklaces, men women and children, there must be hundreds of them all walking in a line. A few minutes later the third man returned with a young woman. She smiled at the nameless child, her eye‚Äôs large and blue, her teeth clean and white. She was beautiful. ‚ÄúHello there boy. How are you feeling‚Äù. The child squirmed in his cage.
‚ÄúWhere is my friend?‚Äù The woman frowned.
‚ÄúWho are you talking about dear?‚Äù
‚ÄúMy pig? Where is she?‚Äù
‚ÄúOh dearie. That beast was put down. It bit poor Deagon, it was evil. We left it‚Äôs body for the glorious crow.‚Äù The nameless child felt tears well up through his eyes. Stefany smiled calmly and moved her hand to his cheek. ‚ÄúShhh dearie it‚Äôs ok. All your pain will be over soon. The CrowCaller has chosen you for something very special‚Äù. The nameless child continued sobbing. Stefany kissed him on his forehead and began caressing his hair. The two men stopped and put the cage down. They opened up the cage door and allowed Stefany to pick the boy up and cradle him over her shoulder. Her warmth calmed the nameless child and he buried her face into her shoulder. A booming voice echoed throughout the caravan, ‚ÄúWE STOP HERE FOR NOW FOLLOWERS! THE CROW IN ALL HIS GLORY DEMANDS US ANOTHER CELEBRATION! TONIGHT WE GIVE HIM ANOTHER GIFT, AND HE SHALL GUIDE US AS HE HAS ALWAYS! ALL HAIL THE CROW!‚Äù A single voice from every man woman and child boomed ‚ÄúALL HAIL THE CROW‚Äù! The boy lost track of time in the woman‚Äôs arms. He felt her carrying him somewhere, but he did not know where. All he felt was her gentle hands caressing his back and her soothing voice humming in his ear. The nameless child had never been held like this before, he had never known his mother, never known his father, and the old woman who had raised him was brittle and weak. The nameless child kept his eyes closed and let Stefany‚Äôs embrace soak up all his fear, all his worry, all his pain.
‚ÄúI have the child master. When will the ceremony be?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhen the setting sun kisses the sand‚Äù
‚ÄúI see‚Äù
‚ÄúUntil then Stefany, the boy is yours to care for‚Äù
‚ÄúThank you master‚Äù
The boy did not understand their words. He tightened his grip on Stefany‚Äôs bare chest and snuggled his chin over her shoulder. She cooed to him, lulling him into a trance-like state. The child cried and cried letting everything pour into Stefany, occasionally snatching words and conversations.
‚Äú‚Ä¶so lucky‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶crow‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶he is so young. How did he make it this far all by‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú..when is the ceremony?‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶he‚Äôs perfect‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶jealous‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶beautiful‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶kind‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶Raven King psycho‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶monster‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶he‚Äôs just a kid‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶name‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶lucky bugger‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶his swine put up one hell of a fight‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶Grotesque Thatch‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶he reminds me of‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶sack of human‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶another one got in yesterday, killed‚Ä¶‚Äù
The nameless child awoke in the woman‚Äôs arms, still being cradled and cooed. He whispered into here ear to let him down, and she complied. He clutched her hand tightly, observing his surroundings. The sun was setting quickly, almost touching the sands in the west. Stefany was with a group of woman, all looking happily down at him. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your name little one?‚Äù asked one of the women.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have one?‚Äù The women looked at him, shocked.
‚ÄúWhere are your parents?‚Äù asked another.
‚ÄúI never met them.‚Äù Again the women looked at him in shock.
‚ÄúWho is taking care of you?‚Äù
‚ÄúMy pig‚Äù The women looked at him full of empathy.
‚ÄúPoor child, having been stolen by an evil swine away from his family at childbirth. It‚Äôs o.k. dearie, the monster is dead now‚Äù. The boy opened his mouth to protest but a man behind him interjected before he could.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time Stefany‚Äù All the women smiled warmly and shook the boy‚Äôs hand and kissed his forehead before letting Stefany lead the boy after the man. Her hand calmed his fear as he noticed everyone staring and smiling at him as he passed, falling in behind him and following the man and Stefany to wherever they were leading him. Stefany and the man brought him to a large altar where a shirtless man wearing a bone necklace, a gass mask, and a wide brimmed hat that had a medal stating ‚ÄúSherrif‚Äù on it stood. The man gestured Stefany forward and she brought the nameless child up ad sat him on the altar. The man nodded to her, in which she kissed the child on the forehead one more time, quietly wished him good luck, and skittered off into the growing crows.
‚ÄúFOLLOWERS OF THE CROW! HERE ME NOW! THIS YOUNG BOY WAS FOUND DRINKING FROM THE WELL THE CROW CONJURED FOR US! THE CROW HAS BROUGHT THIS CHILD TO US TO TAKE INTO OUR OWN! WE CELEBATE JOINING ANOTHER WITH US IN OUR QUEST FOR THE PROMISED LAND!‚Äù The people cheered, the child frowned. The masked man‚Äôs voice was so loud it was giving him a headache.
‚ÄúFOLLOWERS OF THE CROW! THIS BOY HAS HAD MORE MISFORTUNE IN HIS SHORT LIFE THAN MANY OF US HAVE IN OUR OLD ONES! THIS BOY NEVER NEW A MOTHERS LOVE, NEVER NEW A FATHERS PRIDE, THIS BOY IS MORE WORTHY THAN ANYONE HERE TO BE THE NEXT GIFT TO THE ALMIGHTY CROW? DOES ANYONE CHALLENGE MY DECISION TO GIVE THIS BOY THE ULTIMATE GLORY A FOLLOWER CAN BE REWARDED?‚Äù The crowd shrieked in approval.
‚ÄúTHEN LET THE CERAMONY BEGIN!‚Äù The child‚Äôs head throbbed from the noise, he was scared and confused, he wanted to be back in Stefany‚Äôs arms. He looked into the crowd for her and saw her smiling at him. This calmed him and he looked at the masked man. ‚ÄúCongratulations kid. Only the most worthy of us get to meet the crow‚Äù. The opened his mouth to ask the man what he meant but an unholy light burst in the distance, blinding the boy and knocking him off the altar. A second of mute white passed and then it was as if the hands of god had come together, an unearthly clap shattered the silence and smothering the boy. The boy was consumed by the light and noise, completely and entirely‚Ä¶‚Äù
On june 22, 2013
SaucyemmettC

Fun In The Sun Part 4
‚ÄúI know the rest of this tale old man. So this is what you two talked about‚Äù. The second man chuckled.
‚ÄúYou caught me. Carry on then‚Äù. The first man cleared his throat:

‚ÄùThe boy woke up at a rough bump. ‚ÄúDammit Doughnut I told you to keep the van from bumping. You woke the kid!‚Äù
‚ÄúThe Almighty Pastry doesn‚Äôt take orders from you Sherlock.‚Äù
‚ÄùOh yes he does!‚Äù The boy opened his eyes, his vision clearing.
‚ÄúWelcome to the world of the living‚Äù pronounced a new voice.
‚ÄúHey kid, how‚Äôs your head?‚Äù The kid looked around, he was in some metal box moving quickly through the desert. The moving metal box had dusty glass windows he could look out at. Not like there was anything to look at, only the endless sands. The boy took observation of the inside of the metal box. It was dirty with snack wrappers littering the ground and empty bottles of alcohol. Beside him sat two strange men and across from him sat a third even stranger one. At the front of the metal box sat two even stranger looking men. His head throbbed, out front tied to the front of the metal box was a dead deer with a rotting red nose.
‚ÄúWhat the‚Ä¶‚Äù he called out‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúHey kid‚Äù, said the first man, ‚ÄúThe name‚Äôs MrCreeper‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd mine‚Äôs BlackVoid‚Äù, added the second man.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm Otocan‚Äù, the third man shouted with a smug smile.
‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm Draink‚Äù said the fourth man, turning around in his seat to shake the kid‚Äôs hand. The fifth man let go of the wheel and turned to the kid, making Draink yelp and jump at it.
‚ÄúHey there kid‚Äù, the fifth man giggled, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúStory times over‚Äù, interrupted the second man.
‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm not done. What about the explosion! And how we found the kid! And where we lost-‚Äú
‚ÄúThey‚Äôre here.‚Äù

On june 24, 2013
MadDonut

Just as you were typing that, I was typing this.

And so here are the results!

Round One Results (author/story/points earned out of 300)
Colette The Great Spirits 288/300
SaucyemmettC Fun in the Sun 283/300
Fineous(no title) 271/300
Rosslessness Blind Faith 254/300

This is the Overall Leaderboard. How the Overall Leaderboard works is that the scores from each round are added together and averaged. Then, for each round you participate in, you get a +10. For each round you win, you get +5 and adds one per round to your name. This should make it easier for later contestants to win, but it's currently an experimental way of judging. If it doesn't work, I'll figure something else out.

Overall Leaderboard
1st - Colette 303
2nd - SaucyemmettC 293
3rd - Fineous 281

So congrats on winning the first round Colette!

The second round's theme is Friendship.
In a barren wasteland, one is often forced to work with and trust other survivors. This can cause hostility or frustration, but sometimes it can blossom into companionship and, maybe, even love. What kind of simmering stories can you think of?

On june 24, 2013
MinerX

Can I participate in round 2 even if I didn't participate in the first one?
On june 24, 2013
MadDonut

Yes, you can join at any point during any round.

It's added after averaging (which is rounded to the nearest one's place unless there's a tie) but it doesn't matter for the first round since you only have one score.

Basically, say...

You win the first round with 280, lose the second with 250, lose the third with 272.
The math for your overall is like this:

r = rounds participated in
w = rounds won
[(280 + 250 + 272) / 3] + (10r + 5w)
(802/3) + 30 + 5
267 + 35
302

And sorry.
I was thinking it be simpler to show the first three, but then it'd make it hard to keep track of the points of the rest of the contestants.
No disrespect meant.
And to remember how many rounds you've been in, I've added a icon to represent your writings, as to remind myself in the future how many +10's you are owed after averaging.

Overall Leaderboard
1st - Colette 303
2nd - SaucyemmettC 293
3rd - Fineous 281
4th - Rosslessness 264

On june 30, 2013
Rosslessness

Eighteen
 by Rosslessness

In the dusty town square the seventeenth tally mark was drawn in the sand. I can‚Äôt remember which of us started this tradition, but every day since a line had been drawn in the sand.

That‚Äôs all this town was; a simple line in the sand. We had decided that for once, the zombies would fear us, and declared that they would never truly beat us if we were united. None had crossed our threshold since.

On this very spot, over two weeks ago, we had named our little scrap of civilisation, The Fierce Monolith. At the footing of a half built watchtower I had signed up to the town register with my friends. We were strongest when we were together, and we had met other likeminded groups in the wastes.

We had done well and above me now great monuments to our cooperation loomed. There were rusting walls within walls to frustrate even the most determined attacker. Drilling rigs and search towers creaked and swayed awkwardly in the dry air. The gallows twisted idly, thankfully unused, save as a warning.

We had hit the swarming zombies with a renewed strength, knowing and trusting that others had our backs. Heroic rescues and feats of bravery had given us the will to drive the hordes back to the horizon.

At nights the winds had risen and reshaped the desert unveiling new treasure for us to reclaim. Our bellies were full and our spirits high. For the first time in many a town I felt the flicker of hope in my heart. Our collaboration was the strongest force in this damned world.

Even tonight I knew that wood and iron, bolts and tape would be stronger than teeth and claw. The defences would hold and the ravenous throng would wash across them like waves against the cliff.

But all was not right. Attrition had taken its toll. Ill-advised camping trips, malevolent infections, even suicides had weakened us. My friends were long gone, consumed as brave watchmen, or lost in abandoned bunkers. Slowly, painfully, one by one they had returned to the great desert.

Then there was the other problem, which was that the water was all gone.

Well, almost.

Here, in the square is a battered leather flask. Its original owner is a mystery. It‚Äôs far older than the town, stoppered with cork and wrapped in a dirty rag. As I lift it in my rough hands I can feel the weight shift as the liquid sloshes around inside.

Who brought this with them? I cannot remember anyone ever showing me it before. Is it a trap? Is it poisoned? Why wasn‚Äôt it placed in the bank like the others? As the sun rises over the battered walls I‚Äôm joined by the other survivors of this once great town.

Three figures approach from the shanty town of personal huts. I hastily return the ration to the ground. I don‚Äôt want to be accused of stowing supplies away for my own personal benefit. I have no idea how the others will react.

Four of us stand in a loose circle around the thing. All of us are from different coalitions. Here with me stand Bragg, Gofer and Michaels. All of us are little more than strangers to each other. There‚Äôs been little time for group bonding.

We‚Äôre all so thirsty, our sunken eyes and rasping voices betray the fact we haven‚Äôt drunk in days. I had been resigned to my death this morning, but even the thought of gulping down the cool, clear water gives me new energy.

Bragg is the first to speak, pointing a shaking hand at the flask, he licks his lips and exclaims, ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs been hiding THAT?‚Äù Even through his dry throat, the last word is a shout. Up to this point in town that‚Äôs been my overwhelming impression of him. He‚Äôs a loud mouth, short of temper and brash in his actions. His manic energy and spasms confirm what I‚Äôve suspected for a while. He‚Äôs hooked, no doubt on that small cache of Hydratone that vanished from the bank last week. He seems to be the embodiment of bad decisions. His arms are streaked with scars, his teeth misshaped or missing. His boots are untied, the laces ragged. It‚Äôs impossible to ignore the fact his uniform is missing an entire sleeve. I wonder how normal he had looked at the founding. Was he there when I signed my name? I don‚Äôt remember him.

Gofer walked slowly around the ration, before crouching down, his head tilted to one side. ‚ÄúWell‚Ä¶.,‚Äù he slurred in his southern drawl,‚Äù it seems we‚Äôre not dead yet.‚Äù
Gofer was a tech. His uniform was missing both sleeves, but unlike Bragg‚Äôs ragged uniform, he had unstitched his. Here was a man who always wanted his sleeves rolled up. He scratched his tidy beard with the palm of one hand. He looks first at Bragg, then at Michaels before staring straight at me. Then bluntly, he asks, ‚ÄúSo‚Ä¶. Who gets it?‚Äù

In my mind Gofer was a true hero. He‚Äôd saved me on the third night, dragging me back to town when I had become lost and desperate. He‚Äôd found the hacksaw that still hung from his utility belt. Without his knowledge this town would have been torn asunder a week ago. As the casualties started to mount he was steadfast, level headed. He always spoke calmly, presenting solutions, solving problems. I was proud we had helped build this place together. I almost regretted spending so much time outside. I would have liked to known him better. I knew I could have learned a great deal from him if I‚Äôd ventured into his workshop more often.

Then suddenly, a dark thought crossed my mind.

If I could just grab the water, I could run. If I reached the gates, I could hide in the desert. If I could hide for just one night, this town would be mine.

If‚Ä¶

Michaels raised his hand. It was a small gesture but in that empty town it drew my attention back to the moment.

Michaels was small, maybe half the height of Bragg. I don‚Äôt even remember who he used to hang around with. He had medium build and a very plain face. If anyone was doomed to drift into the background it was him. The only reason I even remember him was because he‚Äôd built his house next to mine. Every morning after the attack I‚Äôd greet him with a nod and ask him how he was. He always smiled at me and replied, ‚ÄúSurviving‚Äù, before setting out to work. Three days ago he had handed me my last drink after dragging in that final jerry can. I remember thinking the town needed more residents just like him, and less like Bragg.

He stammered, looking at the floor, ‚ÄúH‚Ä¶.ow do we decide?‚Äù

Round and around we went, shouting and threatening, reasonable and calm, serious and sarcastic. All day we sat there, watching each other like hawks. We all realised that each of us was too weak to take it from the other three. By mid-afternoon the madness had overtaken me. For some strange reason I felt it was hilarious that at least three of us were wasting our final hours in the remains of this great town community, squabbling over something so small.

Gofer suggested we drew straws. Bragg immediately rejected this, arguing a tech could easily guess how long each straw was. I suggested a lottery, but no one could decide who would draw the number. We couldn‚Äôt think of a way to trust each other.

The late afternoon sun beat down, burning my neck as we wasted hour after hour. We were wasting our final moments together over petty squabbles.

I felt myself drifting in and out of the rambling conversation. I remember closing my eyes and thinking this was the end. But, then it happened.

I heard a gentle thud, as something hit the sandy ground. Opening tired eyes I saw the water ration, dropped between my legs.

Michaels stood over me, rubbing his neck as he coughed to clear his throat. Then he turned to the others and pointed at me. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs my friend. He can have it.‚Äù We stared at him in stunned silence for a long moment. The silence was a welcome moment of calm. Michaels looked into my confused eyes and said, ‚ÄúKeep on surviving,‚Äù before walking back to his hovel.

‚ÄúNo‚Äù hissed Bragg as he pulled himself shakily up onto one knee. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs mine. ‚Äú With a low growl he staggered to his feet. ‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs mine. You can‚Äôt have it. You. Can‚Äôt.‚Äù He raised his hands and stepped awkwardly forward. ‚ÄúMine!‚Äù

He made it four hurried steps before Gofer was on him. I have no idea whether he was stopping him or fighting him for the water. As dusk fell, with its merciful coolness all I could see was their silhouettes as they grappled and twisted. I sat there watching the two gladiators‚Äô clash, first Bragg swinging a twisted plank, then Gofer grabbing a pathetic penknife from his belt and slashing wildly. In the end with a roar like an enraged tiger Bragg slammed the tech bodily into the half-finished spikes outside his own workshop. We should have finished them today, but we were too selfish.
On june 30, 2013
Rosslessness

With Gofer still twitching awkwardly in his death throes, Bragg turns and begins dragging himself back towards me. He limped awkwardly and blood covered his exposed arm. He looked like a bloodied Viking intent on murder. I was too afraid, and too exhausted to move.

He dropped to the floor in front of me. Picking up the flask in one hand, he grinned at me, proud of his victory. But, all was not well.

The pathetic, stubby penknife was still stuck into his wrist, and thick dark blood ran down his arm. His hand was slick with blood, and try as he might, the sealed flask wouldn‚Äôt open in his weakening grip. Tears of frustration rolled down his face and as he held the final ration close to his chest he buckled, falling to the ground, dead.

As if on cue, from outside the zombies began groaning. I blinked and tried to focus. Grabbing the flask I gripped the cap in my teeth and pulled as hard as I was able. It opened with a loud pop in that darkened town. In swift gulps I swallowed the water as quickly as I dared, ignoring the death around me as the cool liquid ran down my throat. I felt alive again.

Reaching into my pack I took out my last few matches and with whispered prayers I burnt the two bodies. The thick smoke from the cooking flesh was blocking out the stars above me and I suddenly I felt so alone. I decided to sleep in the workshop. Walking home past Michael‚Äôs final resting place was too much to bear. Finally I understood the meaning of friendship.

-

When I awake the world is changed. Above my head the sun no longer beats down. As far as I can see is cloud. Thick and black, the entire sky looks angry, and as I walk back into the main square I hear a rumble of distant thunder.

In the dusty town square the eighteenth tally mark has been drawn in the sand. I can‚Äôt remember which of us started this tradition, but every day since a line had been drawn in the sand‚Ä¶.

Eighteen.

Eighteen lines in the sand

Now, suddenly, I know.

Turning around slowly I see Michaels, leaning against the gallows. Now I know why he kept so quiet, shunning the crowds. I understand why he returned with that jerry can, rather than using it himself.

He starts walking towards me.

Lightning splits the sky, earthing itself in the metal chain behind him. It explodes in a shower of white hot metal, but Michaels doesn‚Äôt even flinch. He just keeps on coming.

I shout at him over the rising storm. ‚ÄúWhy me? Why did you give it to me? Why am I last?‚Äù

The rain comes now, more than enough water for everyone. As the large drops hit Michaels his skin burns, but he ignores it. His eyes are locked on me. I know I'm going to have to fight for my life.

He‚Äôs now 5 foot away, and in his quiet voice he replies,
‚ÄúBecause you were my friend.‚Äù

As the eighteen lines in the sand fill with water and begin to wash away, we lunge at each other‚Ä¶
On july 3, 2013
Lynnette

Yup, it took me days before I mustered my courage to read yours, Ross. And even then, I read only the 2nd post, because I'm bad with a story with too many characters. I tend to forget who is who. *lol* And I don't want that handicap to distract me from reading a good story.

A question then:
The rain comes now, more than enough water for everyone. As the large drops hit Michaels his skin burns, but he ignores it.

But water is lethal to them, right?
On july 3, 2013
Rosslessness
Lynnette

Yup, it took me days before I mustered my courage to read yours, Ross. And even then, I read only the 2nd post, because I'm bad with a story with too many characters. I tend to forget who is who. *lol* And I don't want that handicap to distract me from reading a good story.

A question then:


But water is lethal to them, right?

Eventually yes, but in the moment, whilst consumed by hunger it matters little. A zombie can lose a lot of skin before it no longer functions. Besides, in game a ghoul drinking water only suffers a wound, not death.

you should have read the first part. It explains who the 4 characters are.

On july 3, 2013
SaucyemmettC

My Friends

Alone? Alone? I‚Äôm never alone. They‚Äôre everywhere, my friends. I can hear them singing. Singing and calling out for me, they‚Äôre beautiful chorus cheering for me to join them. The people I live with shun my friends, my family. They fear them. They hate them. I fear and hate the people for fearing and hating my friends. My friends fear and hate the people for hating them. They only want to embrace the people, and convert them. I know now we are all the best of friends. And tonight we meet again. I will show the love my friends have shown to me to the people who have shown nothing but fear and hate to us. Once we are converted we can all be friends. Then I will be alone‚Ä¶ Alone with all my friends. I can hear the people, smell their filth, see their disgust, taste their fear. They barricade the gates from the outside to keep my friends out. Shame on them, why can‚Äôt they understand. I try and try but they only hit me. They hurt me. So I must show them. The darkness has come. My friends are coming. Oh beautiful night entrances my friends, fills them with soul, and sends them to me. I giggle at thought as I approach one of the people at the gates. The gates are open. He stands and watches my friends approach, fear etched into his shudders. He turns and scowls at me. I smile at him and bow. He tells me to leave. I bash him over the head with one of his friend‚Äôs bones. Drugs took his friend, and I took what was left. The person grovels on the ground at my feet. I giggle at the thought. Soon they will all grovel. My friends are coming and they will all convert. They will all see the way they see and they will see me for what I am. I bash the man again and again and again. Raspberry filling comes out of his ears. At least that‚Äôs what mother called it. She had a little rhyme she used to sing me:
‚ÄúRaspberry filling,
is coming out of me.
It looks like jello,
or chocolate ice cream
Raspberry filling,
awfully tastes like blood‚Ä¶
WHEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE!‚Äù
I miss mother. She left me alone. Alone with these people. How could she. But then I met my friends. They found me outside when I was very young, I went outside the great walls to find my mother. They picked me up, and brought me home. And their reward? The people slaughtered them all. The people are mad. The people are ignorant. But the conversion will make them happy. The conversion will make them see. The person at my feet stops moving. His chest rises and falls. Rises and falls. I feel his rugged face and kiss his cheek. My friends are almost here. Soon. Soon. Noise behind me. I turn to see a person running away. ‚ÄúDo not fear! Do not hide! All will be over soon!‚Äù The person returns with more persons. They all carry sticks and stones, perhaps to break my bones. I smile and pull out the bone. They beat me. I beat back. They grab me. I smile and sing. ‚ÄúMy friends are coming! My friends are coming!‚Äù The people hurt me. They hurt me bad. I stop singing. They put me in a big cage. I sit in the ekrupt gluten chair unable to move. I hurt too much to move. They drag my cage outside, in front of the gate. My friends are very close. The people don‚Äôt even take the time to spit and curse. They run back inside and close the gates. My friends rush past me and smash at the gates. My friends smash open my metal cage. One picks me up and carries me in his arms. I smile up at him. He smiles back at me. A few of mother‚Äôs little helpers slip out of my pocket. Little needles of clarity she left me in my tent, enough to keep my eye‚Äôs open all these years. With them I could see the beauty of my friends behind their rot. My friends lick me, they kiss me, they embrace me, they convert me.

On july 4, 2013
DrJamez

Endless, for too many, that is how the desert must seem. An endless land of sand and heat, the shuffling corpses of the undead, relics of times forgotten buried just beneath one‚Äôs foot‚Ä¶ But there is more to the desert and shuffling corpses of the undead than one would think, the shifting dunes tell stories and let us know where the things that many search for are actually hidden‚Ä¶
The man walked slowly, the rising sun hitting his back as he left quickly erased footprints in the sand that he walked upon. He wore an old, dark hood over his head that also doubled as a cape that he had wrapped around his body slightly. The land beyond the safety of the wall of the town were actually quite chill at this time of day, that would change as the sun would reach its peak ascent, and probably would change before that actually, but it didn‚Äôt matter to the citizen, his hood actually doubled as an insulator for the heat‚Ä¶ No need to try and waste the water rations on a shower, he spared a glance back at the town that wasn‚Äôt too far off, having to shield his eyes from the sun they had been hitting his covered back.
They were all rowdy, not that he hated their company, they were just too loud and celebration sometimes, and other times they were bitter and resentful of one another, drinking away their fear and pain, some even taking drugs‚Ä¶ They all tried different ways to occupy their minds from the terror and fear of certain death at being eaten alive. Whether they decided to bicker among themselves or play rather intricate games, it was none of his concern, as long as he kept his head down and didn‚Äôt cause any trouble, he was sure he was fine‚Ä¶ The only one like him was the odd fellow with a ‚Äòsurvival‚Äô book, apparently he was in the town for some time, and then one day he found the book and was gone for a whopping five days, many considered him dead and started to write something in the log, but he was seen that day coming back perfectly fine and much wiser about the dunes.
He was too weird, and too much of a hermit for the cloaked citizen, and thus, he turned away from his town and continued walking‚Ä¶ He didn‚Äôt always leave this early, he was a man of secrecy and had built himself drapes, and a lock so no one but him would see the nice, soft Mattress he had‚Ä¶ Although he didn‚Äôt sleep long, and not till the zombie attack was over really, he did sleep better than most and was content with just taking the time to read over his notes and work in the lab, build something for the town‚Äôs people‚Ä¶ The talk of someone improving their own house and being possibly hanged made him leave town though, he didn‚Äôt want to partake in something like that, wasting resources and deciding if someone should live or not‚Ä¶ That should be left up to random chance and probabilities‚Ä¶
He stopped not only his train of thought but his movement as well, and he glanced at a dune ahead. He had yet to explore this area, but just from being this close he knew there were zombies on the other side‚Ä¶ How many though? He lowered himself to a crouch on the ground, the distant moans sounding in his ears like the slight wind‚Ä¶ He counted in his head, and did so many times over, and came to the conclusion that there were five of them shambling about; perhaps one was a fool that had gone missing the night before? It didn‚Äôt matter, but he was going to check anyways.
He climbed over the dune, and, now at the top, was able to see that there was actually only four zombies instead of the previously estimated five, he could take these four on if he wanted, but he instead simply slid down and walked right past one, almost brushing shoulders. He was a ghost, invisible to them, and many questioned why. Many said it was because he smelt different‚Ä¶ They were wrong, he smelt just as bad as everyone else, but it was two things that saved him from the undead caring about him, he didn‚Äôt touch them, he covered as much as he could with his nasty looking green cloak, and he walked silently. They were not hound dogs, although some could smell if he got too close, the one he had gotten close to had his nose apparently missing, he had to only worry about their other senses.
Now in the middle of the group, he sat down on the sand and took out a small notebook and a pen, starting to scribble notes down in it about the area. Many seen this as him studying the undead, which he sometimes did, but this was actually to take in account how much sand seemed to be where, if a hidden road was buried, and any almost gone drag marks made by the undead. These things told him how long the zombies had been here, where they had come from, and if there was a possible building nearby, something forgotten from the time before‚Ä¶ All of this.
He frowned slightly as he was able to trace the zombies from two directions, on the right of him, and in front. Ahead of him many more moans than before, it was almost an orchestra of noise from there‚Ä¶
And walking to their revealed a tangled mess of a building, it was hard to tell what it was, but it had foliage all over it and sand, to most, no one would be able to tell what it was‚Ä¶ The nine or so corpses walking around it also discouraged anyone from getting near it, but not this man, this cloaked man merely shrugged at the zombies and walked closer to the buried building. He weaved his way past zombies and odd sand piles before coming to another crouching stop by the building, taking out his notebook and starting to scribble down notes. The size of the building and the shape, the parts of the sine he could see, maybe a few things that he could see past the foliage like labeled bottles‚Ä¶ It was obviously a store, maybe a medical one? He got up started walking around it, sometimes there were clues on the side of the buildi-The hood came off and the branch scratched his face slightly.
Instantly he whipped around, muttering a curse at himself for being too close to the building and getting his hood knocked off by an old dead branch, it didn‚Äôt matter, if his hood came off and he was near any zombie, they‚Äôd know, and soon enough, they circled around him and began moaning even louder. The rotting meatbags would attack unless he got closer to them, it was odd, but they only attacked at one time of the day‚Ä¶ But sadly for them, they were circling around a citizen that always came prepared, he knew the land he traveled and understood the dangers, even considered a superhero with powers due to his ability to survive, and as he reached to his backpack that was hidden by the cloak, he pulled out something he was sure the town wouldn‚Äôt miss for a little bit, he‚Äôd give it right back once he returned‚Ä¶
It didn‚Äôt matter if it was a bloodied chainsaw or not after all.
This, this is something I said I'd write eventually and is about the , I hope it wasn't complete rubish.

On july 5, 2013
Colette

The Watch.
By Colette

The moonlight and the starry sky of midnight were the only lights our eyes could see. Almost blind, and facing a horde of monsters every night, the watchmen held their position. Like a phalanx of desperate citizens, holding their improvised weapons, and hoping they could bash the skull of a zombie without having to face their teeth. Everyone saw them as heroes, who risked their lives for the benefit of the town.

For me, it was not about the glory. Or about the survival of the town. I simply had no other choice. Killing three or four before getting killed myself was better than waiting for my death at home, hiding under my bed. Wielding a machete, I stood in front of the town's gates, waiting. I could hear them getting closer. Groaning madly as they approached.

One, two, three and four nights. I had survived all of those battles before. I had gotten use to the panic and chaos of a hectic battle against the army of the dead. But it never became any easier. Zombies feel no pain or fear. They strike without any hesitation, with no doubts on their mind. With no mercy or remorse, they don't stop until their hunger is satisfied.

The silence of the night was then replaced by the symphony of chaos. Screams and shouts of the survivors, who cursed and insulted their opponents as they desperately wielded their improvised weapons. The zombies just groaned and moved forward, in their reckless attempt to enter the town. It was easy to get disoriented in the chaos. I slashed at one of them, and the machete's blade separated from the handle. My only weapon broken, and nowhere to retreat, I knew there wasn't much for me to do. Going hand-to-hand with one of those zombies would be suicide.

But before I could even make a plan, I felt something grabbing my ankle, and I lost my balance. The zombie I had slashed was still alive. If a living corpse can be ‚Äúalive‚Äù, that is. I struggled with the creature, trying to escape from its grasp while I kicked its head with all my strength. Its hand was cold, and its rotten flesh was covered in sort of disgusting slime. But it was too strong. Another zombie saw me and approached. I knew that they would overwhelm me and kill me in any second. However, the zombie collapsed suddenly. A figure behind it had stabbed it with a knife, which remained lodged in the creature's skull. The figure, a man, then took the knife out of the corpse and stabbed the zombie that had grabbed me, killing it. I remained on the floor, confused and still in panic. But the zombies, turned back and started fleeing. The attack was over, and the survivors of the zombie army retreated to fight another day.

‚ÄúYou're always getting in trouble‚Äù, the man said as he helped me stand up.

‚ÄúThanks again‚Äù, I muttered.

That man was Adam. A person that I had met just the day I arrived in town. He had helped me more than once before. Although he wasn't appreciated by the town for his defiant attitude and disregard for the town's rules, he was a nice person. The only person I could have really call a friend.

One of the surviving watchman ran to our location, asking me if I was injured. I told him I was just fine. Three of the citizens in watch had not been as lucky as me, though. They had brought down a dozen of zombies before succumbing to the hordes. In town, around thirty zombies had managed to enter the houses and devoured three citizens. That was worrisome. Now only half a dozen citizens remained in town, including us, and the numbers of zombies seemed to increase exponentially every night. We were in trouble. With nothing to celebrate, I walked to my home in silence.

Dawn. The sun was rising in the horizon. I couldn't sleep that night. After my experience of the last night where I had almost gotten killed, I was unable to keep waiting. The town was going to collapse soon. Everyone was going to die.

I got up. I walked around in town. Our improvised collection of shacks was now almost empty. The hammering and working at the workshop had ceased forever. The construction sites were just collecting dust now. During my walk, I found a citizen outside. I didn't know him, but I had seen him in town a couple of times before. And instead of greeting me, he eyed me suspiciously before leaving in a hurry. Everyone seemed so suspicious now. With no people left to enforce the rules, there would be no justice anymore. Ironically, at the time when everyone needed to stand together, all the trust among us had been lost. We didn't know if there was any saboteur around us. We only waited for midnight for our demise.

A minute later, I felt someone patting me in the back, and I turned startled to see. It was Adam again.

‚ÄúOh, Sophie, where have you been?‚Äù, he asked. ‚ÄúI've been looking all over for you. Aren't you joining the expedition?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat expedition?‚Äù

‚ÄúDidn't you hear? The survivors are planning an expedition to the desert. We need to find a good shelter. This town's a sinking ship, and we need to abandon it now‚Äù.

I sighed and turned away, and then replied:

‚ÄúI'm not going to dehydrate to death out there. I would prefer to stay and fight to the bitter end. Go and join them if you wish‚Äù.

‚ÄúBut Sophie... I can't let a friend stay like this.‚Äù

I walked away. I didn't care about friends. At that point, all the cooperation had been left behind. One had to take care of oneself, not relying on others.

Later that day, the silence was everything I could hear in town. Everyone had left on their expedition. I had been left behind. And I wondered if I had done the right thing by staying behind. Adam and the others would be killed by the desert in a matter of days, if the zombies didn't do their job first.

A few minutes before midnight I walked around the abandoned town, near the bank. The bank had been thoroughly looted already, leaving me just a small knife as a weapon. Several thoughts whirled around in my mind. Thoughts about the impending end. Nobody wants to die. I hoped that a miracle would save me. But as I went out of the bank and saw a figure standing in front of me, I knew my odds of survival had been reduced dramatically.

It was a familiar face. One of my neighbors. The same suspicious person I had seen that morning. But there was something odd in him. His eyes were blank, like those of a zombie, and there was blood on his face. But he walked and moved like a normal person. He was holding a disgusting piece of rotting meat in a bone. The bone of a human corpse. He stared at me, with a maniacal smile, mumbling something. ‚ÄúI... Hungry‚Äù

The ghoul, as half-zombified persons are usually called, pounced on me with inhuman agility. I cursed myself for being so clumsy. I regretted about my decision of staying in town. And I understood that the half-eaten corpses we had found in the town in the previous days had been left behind by that man. I stabbed the ghoul with my knife repeatedly, but he didn't seem to feel any pain. I accepted my fate and stopped struggling. And the ghoul stopped moving.

A battery pierced the head of the ghoul. I looked up and saw Adam, holding his battery launcher. I thought it was an hallucination.

‚ÄúI tell you‚Äù, he said. ‚ÄúYou're always getting in trouble, Sophie‚Äù.

‚ÄúI thought you were in an expedition‚Äù, I said, surprised.

‚ÄúI wouldn't abandon a friend‚Äù.

Before I could thank him, I heard some noises coming from the desert. The hordes were approaching. Adam loaded another battery into his launcher and helped me stand up.

‚ÄúWell, it's almost midnight. It's time to get on watch‚Äù.

On july 8, 2013
DrJamez

I'll actually try to fit the theme for this one, I guess.

Yes, it's 2 in the morning.
The ONLY good time to write horror or crazy shit.

They mock me, I hear their voices, they mock my futile attempts at survival.
They do it because THEY couldn‚Äôt survive like me!
They‚Ä¶ They didn‚Äôt think the water was poisoned, the water, it was! Who poisoned it?!
Not me.
It was the guy I killed, he didn‚Äôt say anything or have proof on him, when questioned, I said he was a g-no.
I won‚Äôt even mention that, they don‚Äôt exist.
ONLY I EXIST.
Everyone else is dead, but they still walk‚Ä¶
The shaman, he was the one, he was the one who started this all!
Yes!
YES!
YES!!!!!
It‚Äôs clear, oh so clear, I didn‚Äôt just kill him because I thought he was trying to steal my soul in the night, I killed him because my subconscious mind was WARNING ME, he started the zombies! His powers, they did it!
He‚Äôs working alongside the birds, oh, how I hate the birds, they poison the flesh I eat when I‚Äôm not looking, they make me forget how many drugs I‚Äôve taken, they‚Äôre the ones who wrote on my deck of cards!
THOSE BASTARDS!
The town, they found the plans, well, the Shaman did-his flesh was burnt twenty times over to be sure, to be very sure he didn‚Äôt come back like the others-but the plans to build a statue‚Ä¶
OF A CROW!
The madness, I played off of THEIR fear of one another!
The rusty chain, ironic that the person whom found it was the first one to meet their demise by it‚Ä¶.
No, now it makes sense‚Ä¶.
He‚Ä¶
HE BROUGHT THE CHAIN HERE ON PURPOSE WITH THE INTENT OF FINDING ME!
I‚Ä¶ I need to calm my breathing, I can see them now‚Ä¶ The shadows of the ghosts, their souls float around in the bank‚Ä¶
I must destroy them, they‚Äôre blue and they just float there, talking to me‚Ä¶
He wanted to be hanged, the struggling the whole time was just for show, he wanted to be hanged so he could haunt me. Mock me, laugh at how there‚Äôs no drugs left!
I‚Äôm tired, so tired‚Ä¶ The‚Ä¶. The ones I didn‚Äôt burn, they walk around the town now, I‚Ä¶ I can‚Äôt search, there was nothing in the trash, the Shaman took it all‚Ä¶
. . .
I need to be out of my fetal position, I can still survive, someone has a pill‚Ä¶
They‚Äôre all dead, they won‚Äôt mind me borrowing it.
I can‚Äôt handle it! I put on the Shaman‚Äôs mask, to try and ward the spirits off‚Ä¶
THEY CAME TO ME.
I‚Äôm the last man standing, they say I‚Äôm not, they say.. They say I‚Äôm a no good druggy who killed the town!
I was just testing them, to see if they had done it before. I saved the water for myself, and then‚Ä¶ The Shaman‚Ä¶ They questioned me‚Ä¶ I got away‚Ä¶ Hehe‚Ä¶ The mask became mine‚Ä¶.
. . .
It‚Äôs not me, the crow is doing it.
. . .
Not even midnight yet and I‚Äôm already suffering from withdrawl‚Ä¶ The crow‚Ä¶ And the Shaman‚Ä¶ Working together‚Ä¶ No one but me see‚Äôs the crow for the heartless overreacting monster it truly is! I‚Äôve seen it, helpless people, people who did nothing wrong, their tongues pecked out of their mouths, making it to where they can‚Äôt speak!
I was careful, I avoided saying much, lest the crow swooped by with the god damn Shaman.
Oh, how he was so high and mighty, leading the town and giving advice for the new souls‚Ä¶. He was obviously up to no good.
He wanted to build a statue dedicated to the crow!
An evil being that feeds off of misery and livers‚Ä¶.
. . .
They won‚Äôt go away‚Ä¶
I don‚Äôt care!
I laugh at them, they can‚Äôt hurt me!
Or..
Or can they?
Oh, they can, they sould‚Äôve been like me! They should‚Äôve expected someone LIKE ME TO POISON THE DAMN WATER WITH THE DEAD BODY OF A SHAMAN!
Why would I do it?
Simple‚Ä¶
Wait, you‚Ä¶ You‚Ä¶
YOU‚ÄôRE ONE OF THEM!
. . .
You.
Won't.
Get.
Me...
I.... I got me... I got me hooked....
I found the last one....
The last drug...
A...
A steroid.
. . .
It'll save me from you, from the dead, from the town, from the Shaman, FROM THE CROW!
But...
. . .
Did... Did someone like me poison this..?

On july 10, 2013
065tdsa

You know, they said that when things really went south, everyone was going to be equal, in the same conditions. However, some of us did have a bit of a head start.

It‚Äôs not that I was rich or powerful. I have my own ‚Äúrich and powerful‚Äù collection out back, mostly politicians and other people who made TV shows bad, but that‚Äôs beside the point. It‚Äôs just I was a bit more‚Ä¶ cautious.

You see, I never liked to run out of things. Well, no one likes to run short of toilet paper, that‚Äôs obvious. Except most people aren‚Äôt that worried about it. I was the guy buying toilet paper in wholesale, a year‚Äôs supply. I wasn‚Äôt a fan of shopping either, and being able to skip the mall for a whole year always felt good, so that was two birds with one stone.

Then there were other things, just to cover the rest of the basics. I never liked being sick, so I took preventive measures, just to avoid hospitals, which I didn‚Äôt like either. I didn‚Äôt like to be uninformed, so I had a TV which was sure to work, and a radio that wouldn‚Äôt break. I hated blackouts, so I also got a generator after that.

When I grew bored of canned food, I learned to grow some of my own, always underground so people or animals wouldn‚Äôt take it. People and animals, especially people, were always messing with each other. I didn‚Äôt like to be messed with, so I made it so they couldn‚Äôt get that far. And got what I needed in case they did get that far.

I didn‚Äôt like being alone, but I wasn‚Äôt the only one alone. We were alone together, at least as much as the radio allowed.

One day I didn‚Äôt like what I saw on TV. Other people said they never liked all of what they saw on TV, and they were right, I guess. But this was special, I thought, and I was right, I guess. Then I was alone, alone.

Then I wasn‚Äôt. Then They came. Not very talkative, sure, but still, it‚Äôs something, I thought. They wanted to mess with me, though. I guess my preparations against being messed with proved to be sufficient.

Then other people came. They didn‚Äôt want to mess with me, or at least not after they saw that I was ready for that. They asked for help, they weren‚Äôt ready to care for themselves. I helped them, so they helped back. And so I wouldn‚Äôt be alone.

And now I have it all. I am not alone, I eat the food I like, I get to see what I like on TV, and if not I have other things to do. No one messes with me, they don‚Äôt have the chance even if they want to. And I still have toilet paper.

It‚Äôs funny, how people react when I tell them my ‚Äúsecret‚Äù. One told me once ‚ÄúSo being a crazy paranoid works, huh?‚Äù It was funny. I laughed, and then I took him out the door, and showed him what was left of the last attempt to mess with me.

There were many of Them, stuck in holes, impaled in sharp sticks, with their legs or arms severed by blades. They all reached towards me and this one person, with whatever appendages they still had, even though they couldn't get to us.

Then I told him something I had read many years ago, a little phrase I always liked:

‚ÄúYou see, it isn‚Äôt paranoia when they are all out to get us‚Ä¶‚Äù

On july 17, 2013
Colette

Strangers
by Colette

Another normal day in your everyday life. Yes. A day in the life in the modern world, where the only boundaries are those that people create for themselves. Imaginary lines around the world. A world where any place you can imagine is just a few hours away. Where everyone lives their lives in a permanent hurry. Then you enter a crowded subway station. You look around, but don't care about anything at all. All your plans and ideas are filling your mind. All the people around you are just silhouettes. Ghosts with no names or faces. Ghosts you will never see again. Ghosts that can't be trusted.

You board one of the trains, along with other thirty-nine persons, and take a seat. You finally notice the people around you. You see how they all are different. There are women and men. Some are wealthier and some are poor, some are older and some are young. But in the end they are just the same as you. They all have their own plans in their minds. And for them, you are just one of those nameless ghosts, destined to be forgotten soon. They won't trust you either.

Those days of the past are gone now, though. The modern world is now just a memory of the few people that can remember. A funny memory. Memories are always better in your head than they were in reality. However, now those of us who survived the collapse of society and found shelter in this arid desert are facing a similar scenario. I am in a small town, located in the middle of nowhere. Surrounded by thirty-nine persons. Thirty-nine strangers. Strangers trying to trust each other. Strangers trying to rely on each other to fight for the survival.

At first, it was difficult for me to accept it. It was impossible to know what kind of persons those strangers could be. Trusting a stranger is impossible, especially under these circumstances. What are their plans? What's in their minds? What are they plotting? Will they betray me if I dare to trust them?

Two weeks since I arrived to this town, and it all has been chaos since then. People said they did their best to organize the town and start building defenses. Useless. An useless effort. Yes, useless. Every night more and more zombies arrived, as if they sprouted from the ground. Growling, and attacking the defenses with all their strength. But people can be as stubborn as they are selfish. They kept fighting. They kept building defenses. Knowing that all efforts would be useless, I decided to sit and watch in safety, somewhat amused as the town started to collapse.

By seventh day since I had arrived, seven citizens had died already. Three went outside to the desert and never returned. Two were devoured by the hordes when a crack in the defenses allowed a small group of zombies to arrive in town. And the other two deaths had been much more... interesting.

One of them was Murray. Nobody knew where he had come from, or what was his last name. Nobody knew if Murray was his real name. A man of few words. He had worked as a carpenter in his younger days, even if his hair was completely gray by now. Despite his uncouth and unrefined manners, he was valued by the community for his skills Such construction skills were greatly appreciated by people.

Murray had a younger brother called Mark. Known in town as a lazy good-for-nothing man that spent his days sipping something from a bottle. Vodka, he used to say, but we didn't knew where or how he got his booze. People said that he had been like that since he had lost his wife and sons to the zombie hordes.

In any case, Murray and Mark were found dead at their home a that day. A shocking incident for everyone in town. The midnight horde had been repulsed, and everyone could breathe with relief for that night, thinking everyone was safe, just to find that both men had died in that night.

I heard the commotion that morning, and went to investigate. Entering, I saw one body lying on the ground. Murray. His skin had a bluish tone, and it was clear that his death had been very recent. There were no signs of struggle, but I saw the panic in his still open eyes. He had probably writhed in agony before succumbing to death. On the shack nearby, where Mark lived, his younger brother showed the same symptom. Everything indicated they had been poisoned. Nobody knew if it had been accidental or not.

Three days later. Midnight. The bell in the watchtower ringed. That was the alarm that indicated that zombies had been spotted, and that they would attack shortly. The town gates were locked, and the watchmen took their positions. The rest of the citizens knew what to do. Sit tight and hope for the best.

However, we soon understood that something had gone wrong. I heard the noise of the zombies pounding and scratching the barricades with their hands repeatedly. And the desperate screams of people being eviscerated and eaten alive. It only lasted fifteen minutes. Maybe less. But as the hordes retreated, everyone realized the magnitude of the disaster. Fifteen citizens. In their homes, only a half-eaten corpse remained. And then we realized why such catastrophe had happened. The town's gates had been unlocked at the last minute, leaving them wide-open for the zombies to enter. The word ‚Äúsaboteur‚Äù began to spread .

And then, the witch-hunt started.

The construction of an improvised gallows in the town's plaza was the first sign of ill omen. Followed by suspicion. Everyone was a suspect of those crimes. The possible murder of two citizens by poison,
and the act of sabotage that killed fifteen. People finally understood that strangers cannot be trusted.

Fear and panic took control of the city. A tightly-united group within the city, ten persons who had been in town more time than anyone else, took responsibility of starting a court of some sorts, in charge of delivering ‚Äújustice‚Äù. Justice in the form of executions and death.

The first victim was Greg. The man that transformed his home into an improvised kitchen, which he used to transform rotten, moldy and potentially deadly food into edible dishes. Trusted by the community, however, he could not explain why his kitchen had a smell of bitter almonds. The smell that came from two vials full of distilled hydrogen cyanide. Two other empty vials were found hidden in his home. He claimed he didn't know anything about that, and that since the lock in his house did not work, anyone could have entered to incriminate him. But everyone was too focused on looking for a scapegoat to give him the benefit of the doubt. Beaten and dragged to the town's plaza by an angry mob, he didn't stop yelling about how he was innocent until he died hanged by the neck.

Strangers. Strangers that you can't rely on. Strangers that you can't trust. They all look so similar. Eyeing you suspiciously all the time. What are they planning?

Second victim was Julie. She had forgotten to put the tools back in the workshop after she had finished. The sentence was quick. She had to die under the charge of sabotage.

The third was Scott, that same day. He was seen prowling around the town suspiciously before midnight. Clearly in a state of mental confusion. Nobody knew if he was drugged, or if his mind had collapsed because of the stress. But he was summarily executed as well.

The state of chaos stopped the construction of defenses, and everything's crumbling apart. It's been almost two weeks since I arrived in town. Three were hanged. Two were poisoned. Twenty devoured by the hordes. Ten went missing. Today only five of us remain. Four ghosts. Four strangers. Soon they all will be forgotten. I will kill them before they get me. I cannot leave the gates open again. The strangers are watching. I cannot let them find me. I have prepared the poison already.

The poison I mixed with Murray's food, and put on his brother's drink. Mark had stared at me several times. I saw the malice in his eyes. I killed him before he could harm me. I put the poison in his drink, which he must have shared with his brother. Collateral damage. Greg was planning to poison me, so I acted first. Self-defense. He was a nice scapegoat as well. I poured poison on Scott's water before he could discover me. I saw him when he went outside, as his mind started to deteriorate from the hypoxia as his life slowly left his body. Now I have four doses of poison left for four persons. Doses I will pour on the well tomorrow early. They will not discover me. They cannot hang me. Not me. Because I am special. I shall be the last one standing when all those dangerous strangers are gone. When all those people that wanted to harm me are gone. When I finally forget them. I can't wait...
On july 18, 2013

On july 19, 2013
SaucyemmettC

The Grinning Skeleton

I like to smile. I don‚Äôt know why everyone looks at me funny when I do. I quite like my teeth. Sure I‚Äôm missing a few, but I try to make the best of what I have. I don‚Äôt like when people look at me funny, it makes me feel funny. But I like it better than when people hit me. I used to have more teeth, but whenever I smiled people kept knocking them out. ‚ÄúWhat you smiling at faggot‚Äù, one would say, or ‚ÄúGet the fuck out of my face retard‚Äù, another would say. Then they‚Äôd knock out a tooth, but I never stopped smiling. No one will steal that from me. It‚Äôs all I have left, and even if they knock out all my teeth I‚Äôll still have my lips spread apart in a gummy grin. My smile is mine and mine alone. The house ‚ÄúI‚Äù own is shabby, but I‚Äôm told that it is mine. But sometimes people break in and go through all my stuff. I smile at them and ask why, but then they knock out one of my teeth. ‚ÄúI know you‚Äôre hiding something retard‚Äù, one would say, ‚ÄúWhere the fuck is it‚Äù, another would say. I don‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre talking about. I only have a few empty cardboard boxes in my house, and I am told they are mine. But when people come they always break open the boxes and look inside. I don‚Äôt feel like I own this house. I don‚Äôt feel I own these boxes. If I did people wouldn't be able to just come in, and people wouldn't be able to just break open my boxes. But I have my smile. My smile warms me, my smile comforts me, my smile means I still own something. But if I keep loosing teeth it will be very difficult for me to eat. When I went to the canteen and asked for my ration, Vincent tossed me a very hard to eat piece of bread. I told him that I was missing a few teeth and asked politely if I could perhaps have a softer thing to eat. He grew angry and knocked another tooth out. ‚ÄúI know you have a stash of food hidden in your house somewhere you chummy retarded bastard. Ask me for more again and I‚Äôl bash out every god damned tooth you have!‚Äù I smiled at him and left. I think I should start counting my teeth. That way I will know just how many I have left. I wish I could get those teeth back. I have every one I lost in my right pocket. I asked Doc if he could re-attach them and he laughed and told me that‚Äôs not how it worked. Doc was a nice man. I don‚Äôt know why anyone would kill him. After I talked to Doc I went back to ‚Äúmy‚Äù home and sat on one of my cardboard boxes feeling my teeth. A bunch of people came in and knocked out another tooth and began tearing open my boxes. ‚ÄúI knew it! I knew that retard was a druggie!‚Äù one said, ‚ÄúFuck that smile gave him away! It has to be the drugs that give him that fucking smile!‚Äù I don‚Äôt know what they were talking about. When they didn't find anything they beat me real bad and dragged me to the centre of town. Lots of people were yelling about hurting me and calling me bad names. Hark walked up to me and asked me what I was doing in Doc‚Äôs house. I told him. He sighed and talked to the men hurting me about my house. Then he picked me up and carried me home. The next day they found Doc‚Äôs medical stuff in Necro‚Äôs house. I smiled at him as he hung. He didn‚Äôt smile back. I never liked Necro, but I tried my hardest to smile at him whenever I could. It was hard, he always tried to make me frown. His brother Frankie died and I think he thought that I had something to do with it. Frankie liked to smile too, but only when he drank. And when he drank he hurt me. Then one day Frankie‚Äôs insides melted. Necro came into my house and knocked out another of my teeth. ‚ÄúWhat did you do to him you evil fucking retard!‚Äù he asked me. I smiled and asked him what he was talking about. He hurt me so bad I had to go to Doc‚Äôs house for a few days. I heard Hark tell Doc that Frankie had killed himself. He left a note saying how he had run out of drink and had nothing left to smile about. Poor Frankie. I hope I never stop smiling. As long as I stay active I can keep smiling. That‚Äôs how I see it. Being of use is fun, and having fun makes smiling easier. But I am running out of things to do. I used to help build stuff. That was REALLY fun. I cut wood for the big tower and I pounded metal flat for the wall. But when the gates broke open one night and the bad people came in I think people thought it was my fault. People came to my house in the morning and knocked out another tooth. ‚ÄúWhat have you done you fucking retarded creep!‚Äù one said, ‚ÄúYou've done it now fuckface!‚Äù said another. They dragged me to the middle of town and lots of people came and yelled mean things at me and demanded me to be hurt real bad. Hark came to me and asked me what my job was. I told him I pounded iron and cut wood. He sighed and carried me home. The next day Jannie was hung. Jannie was the metal-cutter. I pounded the metal into sheets, but Jannie took them and cut them too thin. Poor Jannie. She wasn‚Äôt too smart. Everyone said so, always had. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm smart either. I don‚Äôt like to think. Thinking makes me sad, and when I‚Äôm sad it hurts to smile. Luckily you don‚Äôt need to think to work. Hark wouldn't let me cut wood and pound metal after they hurt me that day. He told me to follow him around in the desert. It was fun, but not as fun as my old job. He would tell me to dig and I dug. He would tell me to kill and I killed. He would tell me to carry and I‚Äôd carry. My smile doesn't worry Hark. Hark never smiles, and when I asked him why not he said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need to, you smile for the both of us‚Äù. I miss Hark. I miss Jannie I miss Frankie. I miss Doc. A week ago Hark went into a building. He told me to stay and I stayed. He hasn't come out yet. A few days ago men came and asked me where he was. I told them and they went into the building. Yesterday more men came. They asked me where the other men where. I told them in the building. They went in with the others. I hope Hark comes out soon. It‚Äôs very hot out here. I sat down beside the door, but I can‚Äôt hear anything in there. I‚Äôm very hungry. I‚Äôm very thirsty. I‚Äôm very tired. Every day it gets harder and harder to smile. Hurry up Hark‚Ä¶

BlackVoid

I feel like it's written from the point of view of a child in an adult's body.
My interpretation:
He keeps smiling, because he thinks that's good but everybody else gets creeped out and paranoid because he's an adult that's constantly smiling at everyone even during the zombie apocalypse, so he must be up to something.
