On july 25, 2013
Blaire

Have there been any changes in the rules/prizes since the first post?
On july 25, 2013
MadDonut
BlaireHave there been any changes in the rules/prizes since the first post?

How the Overall Leaderboard works is that the scores from each round are added together and averaged. After being averaged, for each round you participate in, you get a +10 and adds one per round you were in. For each round you win, you get +5 and adds one per round to your name for each one you won. This should make it easier for later contestants to win, but it's currently an experimental way of judging. If it doesn't work, I'll figure something else out.


BlackVoid was suppose to end this round and thus the contest four days ago whilst I was busy moving...

...but it's only going a bit of a setback to get the judge's judgings and start the long break between this and the next contest.

Thanks for participating and hope you enjoyed reading these entries. I sure did.

On july 25, 2013
Colette

Isn't there going to be a new round?
On july 25, 2013
MadDonut

Alas, that be untrue. The shalt be only three rounds in this current contest.


But not fret for a new contest will start not too long after this one ends completely.
On july 25, 2013
Rosslessness

Anyways...
The contest begins now!
May I present:

Die2Write Contest #3:
The Contest of Chaos!

This round's theme:
Obsessions
Humans are quiet fond of their little playthings. They hoard useless items and declare them to be of great value. Even in the barren wastelands, a little girl can't be without her Teddy nor can a hardened scavenger be without his lucky coin. Sometimes they obsess over other things, or each other...

What kinds of odd obsessions can you think of?

IT BEGINS!
On september 8, 2013
Jean-Ralphio

There were times, better times than these, when a man could share his bed with another person and wake up with a smile and satisfaction.
Smiles and satisfaction are no longer so easily won.
Sharing a bed is no longer encouraged, you may not wake up beside that which you closed your eyes on.

And there were times, better times than these, when a saw was just a tool. Just an object a man would cut with. And now that very tool, although rusty and bent, is more important than a daily meal. This saw, all rusty and bent, saved my life today. It saved all our lives today. I cut and shaped and made useless into useful. Its teeth are shallow but effective. Rocking my arms back and forth until they burned with stress I made logs into planks and planks into beams until the saw burned with stress.
We shared that.
That was ours.
Ours.
And so I took that saw to bed with me. To share my night of terror with the only thing in this god dammed town I can trust.
Rusty and bent, I heard those horrible groans and felt not fear while i held its mis-shaped handle, but I felt assured that tomorrow I would live and my saw would be here for me, for us all really, but especially for me.
Perhaps you are right, perhaps I should share old Rusty and Bent. And so with a heavy heart I will return it back to the bank, such an unfitting place for the only true hero our town has.
But I swear, by our wells death denying water, I swear: If i hear one more word of shunning me from this our Town of Tired Souls, I will take Rusty and Bent and we will run. Know that I value this town less then i value Rusty and Bent.
Sincerely
-Jeanp-Ralphio
On september 9, 2013
ImScared

I remember the day when I first stumbled into this town, it was an unusually warm winter day. I had just fled from a small horde of zombies and had gotten a deep scratch along my left calf. I drudged in with my blood staining the mix of snow and grass. I noticed a few people a few people shuffling hurriedly about, when a man glanced in my direction. He rushed over to my side and called to others.

I must have fainted because the next thing I knew, I was lying in some sort of makeshift tent. I saw no one around so I got up. No sooner than that I felt a sharp pain, a kind of stabbing pain, in my left calf where I presumed I had been scratched the day before. I looked down and saw a reasonably clean bandage, it was cleaner than the rest of the tent, wrapped around my calf. I managed to hobble around a bit and see the man who had saved me. He was around 30, with broad shoulders and the look of a person who was ready for the zombie outbreak. He had a short beard and relatively short hair, it wasn't as everybody had a sharp pair of scissors to cut hair with. I went up to him and asked where I was. "You're in the 'Asylum of Drunks', or at least, that's what we call this place." After thanking him for saving my life and engaging in a rather short conversation about how he dressed my wound, he excused himself to go fetch wood in the world beyond the gates.

For the next few days, I couldn't do much, so I stayed "home" to rest. When I felt like I was ready to go help out with placing spikes to ward off the zombies, I had grown to like most of the 30-odd citizens of the town. I learned a few tricks as well, for example, I knew how to tell if water was drinkable or not, and also where to look for materials in the world beyond the gates. When 5 or so days had passed, I decided to take of my bandage. By then, my scratch was healed to the point where I could do everything I could do before, except for running, I still couldn't run that fast. I stuffed my bandage in my bag and went exploring. And so it went for many days, I would fold the bandage neatly into my bag before heading out. It wasn't for any particular reason other than to give myself something to do, but after the 10th day in the town, I started worrying about forgetting the bandage at home.

What would happen if I left it at home? Would it be easier for the zombies to find me? Would they attack more viciously? These questions were haunting me day and night, so I carried the bandage everywhere I went, even inside the town. Others thought I was crazy but so what? I loved the bandage, from it's tattered and ripped look, to it's bloodstains and green-ish tints. I loved it's holes and loose threads, as much as I loved my mother. It saved my life, everything I have is because of it. The only feeling I have in this bleak time is fear, but not fear of dying, fear of my bandage being taken from me. Lost. Separated. I am obsessed with it. I need it. It has come to define me, for without it, I am nothing. It will stay in my bag until the day I die. If such a time, god forbid, when my bandage is no more, I will have nothing to live for, to live to. I will have no will to carry on, to drudge as I had done before. The bandage is me.

~The bandage
Macs96

Hope you guys enjoy my very first Die2Nite related story. I know I enjoyed writing it.

Edit-Sorry about the wall of text, but I thought that the story would be better with a "slight" backstory.

On september 9, 2013
Colette
Macs96Edit-Sorry about the wall of text, but I thought that the story would be better with a "slight" backstory.

Hardly a wall of text, really.
On september 9, 2013
SanguinisRose

[Carved into the back of a piece plank, an old story unfolds withered by the sands of time, and a bit from the desert. It lay, words tended with care as each was made with what seemed like a pen knife, dull and shallow though stained with a crimson substance that appeared to be smeared across the top in a light film.]

Pine...

That was the smell that comforted me...

The scent that drove me on night after cursed night...

This... is my confession...

They told me it was only for decoration, they could split it in half for fire, but would you cut apart a friend for such a silly thing? He was my diary, the person to confide in, even if he wasn't a person per se. As the day came to an end, my weary head hitting the soft folds of a coat that I had taken off a resident that had died a few nights ago, there sat my log. I had named him William in the days to come. As the zombie horde came each night he was my protector, my guardian. Cold nights he would share my blanket under the star filled night as our talks, though one sided, filled me with hope for the next sunset to come a little slower as I made haste with my scavenging trips always to come home to its finely sanded curves.

Like clockwork every day passed, the horde moaning against the wall once midnight came, the people buzzing like ants once the day broke. Like clockwork the gates opened and closed in a disturbing rhythm that made my head pound in such a way that only cyanide, with a side of red wine could cure. My days were lonely, spending most of it in the harsh winds of the wastes, spending the rest in the cold comfort of my tent, not even a welcome as I poured my treasures of the day into the stockpile that we had made in the middle of town.

It wasn't till my second day of gambling my life away to bring us one more day to live, going into the zombie infested lands to come back with a hand full of planks, did I meet my knight. He wasn't in shining armor, he was hardly noticeable among the sand that covered him, and I didn't think much of him at first. You know the routine, cluster the supplies, ferry them back to town, strapped to my back with the same jacket that I rested my head on at night, dispose of them into the collective that we had assembled. Something possessed me at the last moment, claiming the log as my own, something that I actually owned no matter how small seemed significant at the time.

Days end happened and a soulless corpse had slipped through our garrison, I had not a weapon at my side. Foreseeing my dreadful outcome in the corpse's eyes I closed my fingers upon the log that was tossed to the side hours ago carelessly, a soft crack came as the log masticated his head against the floor below my tent. He was dead, a second time it seemed, and my white knight had saved me from uniting with the hordes of dead that were now at our gates. As my pulse slowed to its traditional rhythm I let out a breath that I didn't even know I was holding, the sickly smell of death filling my nose as I took my first breath after seeing this creature, making last night's stale crackers spill along the floor as my body rejected the every ounce of that day. With that I broke, a taste of salt was my first clue that it had happened, precious water rolling down my cheeks as I held onto the log in not only affection, but need.

It wasn't long before the people started looking at me differently, their eyes avoiding my own, I knew they heard me talking to William, and they feared that my sanity was going to collapse. We had seen it before, the brothers who prayed that their souls would find a better place as they both drank from poisoned canteens wasting our water supplies. It was sad that we didn't see it as a loss of life anymore we were too desensitizing death to afford such a thought. As the horde hit the walls once again that night I knew what day would bring, as I took a piece of sandpaper rubbing at Willam's side affectionately to care for him in our last moments. It wasn't death, but to be shunned by the very community that I had supplied for countless nights, that I had supported ever since I wandered into this city. I thought that shunning wouldn't be so hash till they took him away, throwing him into the pile of planks that I had gotten them just yesterday. They had betrayed me...

These are my last lines, as this plank is coming to its end, and it is only hours before my retribution. I consumed part of.. We always called him Orphan in the town as a nickname, but aren't we all orphans now? He had died on watch the night before, and hadn't risen yet as one of them, I can only hope that I don't die before I kill them all, to smell the fresh scent of pine.......

[The last of the writing seems to fade out as if the person was losing strength, and one final line draws off of the last period down to the bottom of the plank]








My first attempt at a story, I'm a bit rusty but I hope you enjoyed it.

On september 12, 2013
SaucyemmettC

My Pain, The Stain

That stain‚Ä¶ That stain‚Ä¶ Is the cause for all my pain‚Ä¶ It won‚Äôt let me sleep‚Ä¶ It won‚Äôt let me eat‚Ä¶ It keeps me here, stuck, stranded, isolated, alone. Alone with it, the stain, my pain. I scrub and I scrub and it never even fades, the vivid red blotch that is all that remains. It‚Äôs been seconds, minutes, hours, days; all is lost to the stain that is my pain that is all that remains. My fingers are broken; my rags shredded, my arms limp, for that stain is dreaded. I tried to rest ten seconds ago, or days or weeks, oh, who knows. But when I closed my eyes that stain grew brighter, and it‚Äôs crimson red colour grew lighter. I made no attempt to shriek and shout, for he who I hide from would come here no doubt. This stain must be removed before then, or I shall be hung by those accursed men. I thought about pulling up the plank, but where would I hide my mistake? And what when they come meet me here, and there‚Äôs a missing board‚Ä¶ They‚Äôll find it no doubt and I‚Äôll be fed to the horde. How much time I have left, is up for debate, for this stain has splintered my mind state. No time to think, no time to complain, not until I dealt with this stain. My broken fingers bleed into my shredded rags as my limp arms wane and whine. I scrub scrub scurb scrub scrub scrub scrub! And the stain of my mistake still remains to bring me pain! I could flip the plank, put the sight of the stain out of my brain! But the fear for the day someone notices the upturned wood, my god I can‚Äôt do that which I should! I‚Äôll never rest until I‚Äôve got this stain out of my nest, for when the body turns up he‚Äôll come by with a test. And if he spots the stain on the wall, my grips on control will fall. Water‚Ä¶ Water is what I need, but to leave this stain here would only make the situation hotter. I knew I should have been collecting those rations, stocking up with no other reason then to fit in. But it hurt so much when I dropped some on my shin. Oh what horrible regret I now face, as after several assaults I have finally left a trace. And when the man comes by with his eagle eyes, he‚Äôll sneer at me and beat me till I die. So I scrub scrub scrub scrub scrub scrub scrub scrub scrub! And the stain that remains on the wall in my shack sparkles brightly, illuminating the pain in my brain. My arms give out and my hands withdraw, my fingers no longer flex, I‚Äôm due to meet law. I hear footsteps outside, the man with the plan, he‚Äôs been waiting for this day, the day I leave a trace, he‚Äôll confront me now, face to face, and he‚Äôll spit on my shoes in awful distaste. I‚Äôve got to scrub this stain away, I don‚Äôt want to have to pay. That single red dot, right there on that spot, it has to be gone by the time he comes in‚Ä¶ SCRUB SCRUB SCRUB SCRUB SCRUB SCRUB SCRUB SCRUB SCRUB‚Ä¶

Round two's theme: Origins

On september 23, 2013
SanguinisRose

On september 26, 2013
Winness

Saint Crow's

I look at myself in the mirror and note that I have a very big dick.

It's probably the only reason anyone ever talks to me, because of my dick. Except my wife, of course -- she talks to me because she loves me.

I grab a comb from the dresser and try to brush the hair off my face, careful not to touch the fresh stitches around my temples. The wound itself had been inflicted a long time ago by an accident with a machete (they thought I was a zombie), but I'd been saved by just a hair that the blade didn't dig deep into my skull. It hurts like a bitch, but it didn't kill me. Now my wife stitches the wound closed every other week because there's no medicine to make it heal.

Putting the comb down, I pick up the snowglobe I inherited from my father when he was alive. It wasn't exactly a snowglobe, though: the "snow" that once filled it turned out to be styrofoam, which was pretty useful stuff to insulate things from the heat. I gave it to the town because it was more useful there. I substituted it with sand instead, so it was a sandglobe now. The little town in the middle with high walls and fences was in a desert, just like me.

The sound of a door opening catches my ear, then footsteps. In the mirror, I can see it's my wife trying to sneak up on me. I pretend not to notice.

She wraps her arms around my body from behind, both her hands meeting at my chest, gently kissing my back and neck. I smile, but suppress it. She grabs the sandglobe in my hand and sets it down. Her hands follow the hair that trails down below, and I turn around. She finds a chair and makes me sit on it. We kiss, her lips hot on my skin as she sits down on my lap, straddling me. We make love on the chair and I fall asleep. She pricks me with a needle just before I lose consciousness.

When I wake up, my wife is lying down beside me, sleeping soundly in the knowledge that I will keep her safe. I kiss her lips and she smiles, perhaps unconsciously. The sky out the window is dark, and I know I have a few moments left before midnight falls.

Gently so as not to wake her up, I get out of the bed. I look in the mirror and find new bruises there, but those bruises weren't gotten from fighting anyone. I grab the sandglobe and toss it in the air, then place it in my rucksack.

I find my clothes, pulling on the pants first, then the shoes. Socks are hard to find in the wasteland, so my feet are calloused from the blisters you get from wearing leather army boots. My shirt is silk though, and it fits so snugly and comfortably that it almost makes up for how much my feet hurt when I walk.

I heft my shield for a while, testing it's weight on my arms, and then I leave the house.

Five people walk up and down the roads, members of the Watch like me. Two wore heavy cloaks, one had a dog with an amputated leg, one had an ugly mask, while the last one had no special things at all. She just wanted to be part of the Watch.

Above us, a gigantic crow is flying in the air, ready to eat the corpses of whoever doesn't survive tonight.

A cold chill waves over all of us, even those in the houses and shacks and tents, as the distant sounds of scurrying feet start to come from every direction. We all look at the gate, the five of us anxious but prepared.

I love my wife and I would protect her from this horde. I would give my life to protect her from it. I chant the mantra in my head ceaselessly.

I close my eyes as the crow squawks, as if laughing. The gates of the town burst open, and thousands and thousands of the horde come flooding in.



Earl drops the sandglobe when my team and I enter the room, shattering it. I frown and go to him, observing the devastated small town in the center, the sand all around it, and the water spill. He was starting to freak out, screaming and hurting himself on the broken glass. He thrashed around and made the four other guests in the room to act up from his tantrum.

"Someone clean this up." I command, and pick up Earl's ragdoll on the floor to keep it from getting wet. This one had a picture of his wife's face attached to its head, something Earl was extremely fixated on. I hand it to him and try to calm him down. "We'll get you a new sandglobe, okay, Earl? Look, your wife."

He accepts it and starts to calm down. I hand him a new sandglobe and stand him up. "Someone's here to visit you." I tell him. He looks at me as if he doesn't understand.

Looking around the room, I see the twins cloaked under a blanket. One of the interns was on the process of administering a sedative on them to get them to calm down. Another one, a man of 40 years old, was hiding behind an ugly orange mask as he was escorted out the room to meet his own visitors. The last one just sat in the corner, doing nothing.

I turn my attention back to Earl. "Your kids are here to see you. Do you want to see them?" Earl nods, as if he understands. I ask one of the staff to escort him out the room as I check up on his medical records on my clipboard.

"He's only getting worse," I tell my assistant when the door closes behind Earl.

"What happened to him?" she asks me.

I frown. "Something tragic. A breaking and entering. The criminals broke in specifically to hurt them. I don't know why, they weren't caught. The police report says it's possibly bad blood."

My assistant hands me some papers to sign, to verify that Earl is getting the correct dosage of medicine. "So they did that to him?"

"They found his wife first," I continue. "He tried to protect her, the poor man. They killed her in front of him, then beat him almost to death. The trauma did that to him."

I hand her the clipboard. I don't tell my assistant how Earl got castrated.

"He's always saying something," my assistant mentions. "It's a little freaky."

"Earl?" I say. "Yes. Something about an epoch."

My assistant rubs her arms, goosebumps breaking out on her skin. "I don't like this job."

I give her a pointed stare. Neither did I.
On september 26, 2013
Jean-Ralphio

if you would rather i just post it here i will be more than happy.
I call it "The Circle of Death"
On september 27, 2013
Colette

I don't know about MadDonut, but I'd rather if you could post it here. If the text doesn't fit in one post, split it in several parts.
On september 27, 2013
Jean-Ralphio

The only pain worse than death is rebirth.

Rebirth isn‚Äôt even an appropriate name for The Event. You are no babe, there are no children. Only adults eaten alive than mysteriously reconstituted. No one has seen The Event from outside their own eyes.

One moment you are fighting to keep the life you have when the soft teeth finally tear your flesh from your bones, your nerve endings on fire as you panic and fight harder as those teeth multiply and fingers pull at you. They always seem to find your navel, digging into the grip and pulling it wide, another cold finger pulls the other way and you hyperventilate feeling your body stretch and rip, if you're lucky you can‚Äôt see. But when was the last time you knew luck?

But that is just a stub of the toe compared to when your soul bolts from that body. You notice it‚Äôs joints stiffen and twitch and whatever is left of it stands as your consciousness sears across the globe.

A silent scream is held in your eternal self.

A thousand simultaneous pains too intense for any body to contain is your experience. You know it will be over soon, you have done this a dozen times before but the pain never callouses.

At last, The Event. Forcibly your identity is thrust into a husk and your new body awakens. As familiar as the last. As familiar as the next. Fresh, hot air fills your lungs at once and exits loudly. Tears stream from your new eyes onto your new cheeks and a black crow perches on an old post.

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù You whisper to the crow, the same crow you‚Äôve seen dozens of times with its distinctive white feather on the tip of its wing. ‚ÄúAgain?‚Äù

The crow caws at you and flies toward the north and you see the town. Always a town.

As you near the town you see silhouettes in the horizon. Your new neighbors have arrived.

40 crows caw as one from the town walls and fly out into the wastes.

Whispers greet you from the inhabitants. Complaining of The Event and of some familiar faces. Some hold each other quietly as you walk to an empty plot and claim it as your own. And you see her.

You‚Äôve never seen her before, her hair is tangled in knots and her eyes are all brown her pupils are like pinholes and she climbs.

She climbs over the sobs of the others.

She climbs over the fights of past lives done wrong.

She climbs past the finite water and the limited resources. She climbs over all our struggles to dodge The Event one more day.

And more literally she climbs on top of the heap that will soon be a workshop and she screams.

A long sustained wail ripples past her cheeks and she robs everyones attention. You know what happens next, you‚Äôve seen if a few times before, looking around you figure most the folks here have not seen it before.

As her siren wears out she takes a breath and a crow flies back perched on the ridge of our gates. She points to the crow and shouts at us ‚Äúwhat is he doing here?! Always following and always watching!‚Äù She throws a rock at the bird. At least you assume that is where she was aiming for the rock hit the gate at least 10 feet below the bird. He stares and blinks.

‚ÄúHe witness‚Äôs both ends of The Event‚Äù An audible gasp circulates the masses, The Event is rarely spoken of and only in hushed wimpers. Even you furrow your brow. And another onyx fiend flies in to join it‚Äôs brother. ‚ÄúHe knows why we are here! DO YOU?!‚Äù

Her arms outspread she pauses and waits for suggestion.

‚ÄúCell phones!‚Äù A cry from a corner offers and she spits.

‚ÄúMicrowave ovens!‚Äù She laughs with contempt for that idea. Shadows quickly pass over her as more birds join at the wall.

‚ÄúWe have all heard those fancy and convenient stories before I‚Äôll wager I‚Äôve heard them longer then most of you!‚Äù Everyones ears were hers as she lowered her voice to slightly more than a whisper. ‚ÄúBut what is the truth, why do we become zombies‚Äù She laughs a crackled laugh followed with coughing ‚ÄúZombies?! Really? Zombies were for movies and books in our previous days, before this nightmare begun‚Äù

Forgetting yourself, you stand up angry at her suddenly. You open your mouth to shout but someone beats you to it ‚ÄúHEY!‚Äù A stupid thing to say really. But you yourself don‚Äôt understand why you‚Äôre so mad at her you just know that no one EVER talked about the time before the zombies, before The Event before the dessert.

‚ÄúOH ho ho‚Äù She spun to meet the voice and hopped down to meet it‚Äôs owner ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt like thinking about that do you? There was a time when Zombies were fiction and reincarnation was not quite so literal wasn‚Äôt there?‚Äù The wall was blanketed with crows now and their caws made for a buzz. ‚ÄúYes and crows, crows were never on our mind‚Äù

‚ÄúHow many times have you died stranger?‚Äù The man asked the woman with profound fear.

‚ÄúI have lost track, well over 300, I once survived 2 months but never have I seen any rain other than the occasional shaman dance‚Äù She snapped her fingers and got along with her point ‚ÄúHow many of you have seen a natural rain?‚Äù And she was met with silence.

Deep in your gut you realize where you are. You‚Äôve known if for at least 3 lives, but you never let it surface to your psyche.

‚ÄúWhy are we here‚Äù She asks and looks at you directly ‚ÄúYou know, don‚Äôt you?‚Äù

You nod and everyone snaps to your location.

‚ÄúHow many times have you died?‚Äù She walks to you and you look up thinking, shaking with fear. The town is surrounded with crows now and you shrug your shoulders breathing in a shaky breath.

‚ÄúDo you remember your first death?‚Äù She touches your shoulder with sympathy and before you say anything she says ‚Äúyou don‚Äôt do you? it‚Äôs okay no one does.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Ä¶ I remember my first life‚Äù You manage to blurt out ‚ÄúIf i concentrate hard enough‚Äù

She nods absently and ignores that. ‚ÄúSo where are we now, friend? Where are we now‚Äù

The crows shout as one so that no one hears you. Well over 100 crows surround the town, ebony feathers falling on the towns 40 heads.

You shout at the top of your lungs where you believe you are only to be drowned in a symphony of caws. The woman looks around and some of the smaller crows take flight, circling the town. She looks at you earnestly and nods.

For a moment the noise pauses, the longest 3 seconds of your life and you repeat what you had shouted. ‚ÄúThis is Hell‚Äù

The crows did not want to hear that as they all take flight, no longer cawing only circling your town

She looks at you with sadness drawn on her face. ‚Äúdo you know what they call a flock of crows?‚Äù

Before you can answer the gates buckle and groans are heard on the other side. The town moves as one to push against the doors. You, yourself run to the doors when a bird lands on your shoulder. You look at the bird curiously, they have never touched you before and you see the telling feather on its wing. ‚ÄúI was right wasn‚Äôt I?‚Äù the bird caws at you as if to agree than darts at your eye ball.

You scream but no one can hear you as they push against the wall and try to stop the onslaught of zombies. Another peck with a sharp beak pierces your eye lid and you feel wetness run down your cheek. With your other eye you see a mound of black birds muffle a womans scream as the birds move back and forth around the town. Than you feel a needle sharp pain, than you see nothing. All you can feel is daggers over your body and wind pushing against you, your tongue is pulled out of your screaming mouth as you fall to the ground and suddenly your consciousness sears across the globe.

A silent scream is held in your eternal self.

A thousand simultaneous pains too intense for any body to contain is your experience. You know it will be over soon, you have done this a dozen times before but the pain never callouses.

At last, The Event. Forcibly your identity is thrust into a husk and your new body awakens. As familiar as the last. As familiar as the next. Fresh, hot air fills your lungs at once and exits with rasps. Tears stream from your new, whole eyes onto your new cheeks and a black crow perches on an old post with some red meat in its beak.

‚ÄúYou!‚Äù You say. but nothing comes out ‚ÄúYou‚Äù once again your attempt at speech is fruitless. Your mouth feels empty. An odd feeling for a mouth. The white tipped bird drops the red meat in front of you and you realize it‚Äôs your tongue. He caws at you again and flies to the west showing you your new home.
On september 27, 2013

On september 29, 2013
SanguinisRose

The Completionist

As a journalist everything I have discovered has to be put down, though I don't think the papers are running anymore, and the truth will probably not be ascertained. Maybe it‚Äôs just my way of dealing with what transpired, dealing with the fact that I'll never see the people I love again, and the terrible things I had to do up till now. These calloused hands now stained in crimson, just as others are.

From my research into the Hematopoietic Stem Cells (HSCs) facility, in what used to be Utah back before the government collapsed, I uncovered the corpses of mutilated rats littering the rooms of the laboratory. In most cases they were dissected, torn apart for further research, but a few had survived. They were barely hanging on to life or perhaps something bordering life and death, held in a paradoxical state of confusion that has yet to be rectified, and probably never will.

I should clarify the state in which I found them; most of them were missing body parts, their teeth pulled. Bodies pinned to a cork sheet with their ligaments spread, held in place by small metal rods, staring at you blankly with their black, soulless eyes. More unsettling then the human corpses, it seemed like they were only the first to be experimented on, tested with the HSCs. Furthering my investigation, I found rusted cages restraining the primates in the back portion of the lap, a time line laid out in front of me, beginning with rats escalating to more advanced species, foreshadowing the deepest corners of the facility.

Spending weeks in the confines this facility, although I spent that time researching, it was mostly stalling for the inevitable, when I would have to go into the deepest corners, to the mysteries that I am compelled to discover. It grasped at my most morbid fantasies, seeing the origins of this nightmare. I already knew what contributed to this anarchy; I already had my story why does this curiosity drive me so?

Ensuing two days in the last rooms of the facility, it was disheartening in a way, the offices were void of anything, and not even a single drop of blood contaminated the machinery. Collective stories and written testimonies cluttered these rooms, hinting at the fact that it never got as far as human research. Whatever happened must have transgressed before it could progress that far.

Under a pile of bone marrow biopsy needles there was a leather briefcase of files dealing with the experiments done here, code named Tithonus after the Greek lover of Eos, who was granted immortality. I found myself intrigued by their methods, a bio-engineered white blood cell that rapidly spread though the body donated by ‚ÄòPatient Zero‚Äô code named Workshop. The blood that was donated changed the properties of marrow inside of the new patient, making it produce HSCs at an increased rate; the only side effect of the treatment seemed to be that the marrow would wear out, needing a transplant of new materials every few days. The primates that were injected by the modified blood cells, named the ‚ÄòModified Workshop O type Blood Cell,' upon missing a treatment, the primates got violent attacking their cell mates. Injuries healed from the primates at an increased rate after the attack, the primates that attacked its cell mate consuming some of the other‚Äôs bone marrow.


The research went on without incident till one of the larger primates fell from his cage, impaling himself through the heart with a tree branch. Its body convulsed for a few minutes before going limp. Checking his body after, they found no activity in the brain or the heart, marking the test as only a partial success as they were looking for the key to immortality. An incident happened a day later as the primate seemingly came back to life, further research showed brain damage in the primate, the reasoning and empathy centers of the brain. Most of it seemed to have been completely destroyed, the area of the brain that held language skills was severely damaged. It makes sense from a ghoulish standpoint, hunting down the people they called friends, lying to them before the crack of a baseball bat sends them to their bloody demise.

Letting him back into the cages with another primate showed shocking results, the primate that came back from the dead, named Caesar, a single bite from the other primate made a festering wound. Examining the wound showed a slow acting virus in the blood stream, out of arrogance and ignorance they watched as the virus took hold of this new primate, it dying in only a few hours. This time they decided to dispose of the body, placing it on a tray to go into the incinerator. Unbelievably as they were moving the body the primate started to come back, thrashing against the restraints.


In the following hours, the head scientist went home sick, he sounded frantic saying that he needed to pick up his kid from baseball practice on the way home and spend time with him. His actions are written down as suspicious, and it calls for a team of security to monitor him without him knowing. Communications with the security team stopped the next day, the last transmission spoke of a child biting him in the torso, before shooting the child‚Äôs brains over the sidewalk. The report ends there, the date showing it was only five days before the epidemic spread across the world.


As I write this it makes me wonder if this is the immortality that they wanted, is this success in the scientist‚Äôs books? Either way it seems like I have spent too much time in this facility the horde seems to be banging at the door, all I can do at this point is open that bottle of Wake the Dead that I have sitting at the bottom of my backpack. This is a farewell to whoever might read this; hopefully this isn't the end of the human race. I can toast to that, to the last of the human race, hopefully you don‚Äôt get the Tithonus curse of immortality.


______________________________________________________



On a small computer in a laboratory somewhere, two men stood staring at the screen, their faces illuminated with the lights from the screen. Simple text rolled down it as they read. The last few words blinked on the screen as they spoke to each other, sweat rolling down the more heavy set of the two's forehead.

"Yes, or no Richard?" The heavy set man looked to his partner, waiting for an answer he wiped his brow with a napkin that lay next to the keyboard.

"No, one result is not proof enough, run the experiment again." The smaller man, assumed to be named Richard, turned from the screen after typing a single key both of them walking out.

Blinking on the screen were the final words, "Subject 4072 has accepted his death, a reasonable explanation has satisfied his curiosity, program end? (Y or N) N."

On september 29, 2013
SaucyemmettC

Cubically Contained

The smell of the musty shack was the first thing I remember noticing inside the ‚ÄúShady Bar‚Äù. The room was poorly lit, with light only coming in through the now open doorway and holes in the ceiling. The air was thick from cigarette smoke further hindering my vision, but my eyes quickly adjusted. The Shady Bar was a small shack, one room, one bar, one exit. The bar was at the back of the room, with a few stools set out front. A single table stood in the middle of the room with a few chairs. Three other men were in the room, two sitting at the table with their feet up, and one behind the counter going pulling out the bottles. They all turned their heads to me when I came in. I remember not recognizing any of them; they were all strangers to me. I took a seat at a stool in front of the counter, and the man behind it slid me a yellow syringe. I shot some of that yellow stuff up my arm, feeling a moment of blissful happiness before sinking back into my dreary situation. Next the man slid me a murky bottle with something twitching in it. I drank it back, then tossed the bottle into the wall. I was disappointed to see that it didn't explode. It just thunked off the wall and rolled into the corner. But the drink dulled my sense of reality, and I turned to look at the two men at the table. They were sucking back smokes as if they were part of a marathon. Light Suck Flick, Light Suck Flick, Light Suck Flick‚Ä¶ They stared at the sky as they smoked, eyes vacant of thought. I returned my attention to the man behind the counter, he had left two drinks in front of me and a few multi-coloured pills. I drank the washed the pills down with the ‚Äúliquid‚Äù, feeling my head finally let go. I remember resting my head on the table for a second, closing my eyes to try to get some sleep. When I opened them there was another bottle and a syringe. I shot one up, and drank one down, but I don‚Äôt think I did it correctly, because I remember spending the rest of the day with a stinging tongue, and some sticky foul smelling substance covering my arm. One of the men at the tables broke the silence. ‚ÄúShit.‚Äù It seemed at the time the most suitable word to start our conversation. The other man at the table continued, ‚ÄúShiiiiiit‚Äù. The man from behind the counter scurried over to them and dropped five or six bottles and a pile of smokes. They went back to their binge, and I waited patiently for more bottles to appear in front of me. They did. And I made them disappear. It began. My legs went dead, then my back went numb. I slumped over the counter, feeling the world slip away. But one of the men at the tables broke my transformation with a question. ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù. I groggily turned around to face him.
‚ÄúWhy what?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhy how?‚Äù The other man at the table chided in:
‚ÄúWhy why?‚Äù I heard a bottle slap against the wood behind me and I reached back and took it.
‚ÄúWhat why when how?‚Äù The two men at the tables looked at each other, then all three of us drank our drinks in unison.
‚ÄúI‚Äôll tell yah why how when who‚Äù said one of the men.
‚ÄúI never said who‚Äù, I responded.
‚ÄúHow can I say how and why without who?‚Äù He responded.
‚ÄúWhy say how and who at all?‚Äù I exclaimed. He looked at me funny, his face scrunching up.
‚ÄúWhy what you talk about?‚Äù he mumbled almost inaudibly. I sagged in my chair, a syringe appearing in my hand and penetrating my flesh. The other man poked back in, more audibly then the other:
‚ÄúIt ‚Äòas a govermint! Dey got us all tangle up in dis shit‚Äù. I sighed and sucked back more ‚Äúalcohol‚Äù. He continued:

‚ÄúWe was all livin good and fine. Big cities, big ladehs, big foods. Life ‚Äòas goin goood. But the govermint got greedy. It wanded moe. It build dese metal box thingies dat we all had to step indo. An experimint. We had to all go in dese medal boxes and‚Ä¶ and‚Ä¶ We go to a not real realidy. A luson. A dreem we can‚Äôt wakey up fom. We still in dose boxes. Ow bodies are. But we are here. Our mindz‚Ä¶ We dere but we heer. Government did ‚Äòis to us to see what we do. To see how we react. We supposed to get moe for dis, when we wake up. But we don‚Äôt wake up. Sometin wong. So we stuck here. They eyder forget or fuck up. So we wait. That‚Äôs who, why, how. When? When is no madder. All dat madder is won day we all wake up.‚Äù

I remember thinking that he was making sense. When I think about it now though, it doesn‚Äôt make a lick of sense. What the hell was he trying to say through that drunken slur? Hell if I know, hell if I care. The man at the table, when finished his rant, began drowning himself in the bottles laid out in front of him. I turned and popped some more pills that were laid out at the counter behind me. The man behind the bar was gorging on some meat. I remember asking him for some, and he gave me a slab. It was tasteless, and made me thirsty. I lumbered over and sat at the table with the man. He still had his feet up, and his head lolled back. The man from behind the counter wiped his mouth with a torn piece of fabric, and moved to give me another pill. He too joined the chat. ‚ÄúYou think this is an experiment? That this is an induced dream? That we are being monitored?‚Äù He shook his head and laughed. ‚ÄúWhat do you think is happening?‚Äù I popped the pill and looked up at his great big smile:

‚ÄúThe apocalypse‚Ä¶ We are the unforgiven men and women left to burn... Burn with... With the souls of the damned... The dead rise... And they consume... We are among them... We are among the dead... For we are damned... The crow is our tormentor... Watching above... Directing the play... We are trapped to this hell... Because... There is nowhere to move on to... That is why... That is how.. Who and when isn't important‚Äù.

The man laughed. I put my head down on the table surrounded by empty bottles. I remember being confused. I didn‚Äôt remember drinking all these bottles myself, and I didn‚Äôt remember the other man having anything to drink at all. My head was spinning. I closed my eyes, trying to gain control over all the substances swimming through my brain and blood. The sign that brought me to The Shady bar etched to the back of my eyelids. Beside the destroyed gates, written in blood on the wall, ‚ÄúTOWN DEAD. LETS GET FUCKED. GO NORTH.‚Äù Well I felt fucked. I remember hearing the man behind me talking. I think he said:

‚ÄúGovernment experiment gone wrong? Eternal damnation? So silly we are. So cynical. Why can‚Äôt we just accept our fate? This is where we are. It doesn't matter why, or who, or when, or how. All that matters is what we do now. You had your fun, now it‚Äôs time to sleep‚Äù.

The last thing I remember was the smell. The rancid smell of the ans breath.

‚ÄúSo what does it matter where we are? What does it matter where we are? What does it matter when we are? All that matters is life now and death later! Live! Lie! Love! Consume!‚Äù The men at the bar stared at me. Their faces showed they were unimpressed. I sat down and asked the bartender for another drink. No one wants to worry about questions, and no one wants to be told not to worry about questions. So lets just get pissed and pass out.

On october 1, 2013
Deblyn
Dances with zombies

This is a true story. I tried to stick with facts as much as possible. What if....the people survived this? What if they were turned into zombies? The viruses I described here are highly contagious. Almost always fatal.



In the 1980s, a new highway linked the small villages in the Congo, Uganda, Nairobi and others. The Kinshasa Highway is an informal name for the route. This route was carved out of thick jungle and paved in most areas. There were some areas that were just rough tracks. After this ‚Äúhighway‚Äù was built, Aids spread quickly. As the new access allowed carriers of the disease to travel from populated areas to more isolated areas. Prostitutes at truck stops helped spread the disease even faster. The highway is still known to this day as the Aids Highway. HIV is considered highly lethal, but not very infective. For instance unless you are sharing body fluids you will probably not get it. Biosafety Level 2 agent. No need to wear a spacesuit to handle HIV

In 1980 a man and his girlfriend, traveling the Aids highway, went camping in the rain forest of Mount Elgon National Park, on the border of Uganda and Kenya. While there they visited Kitum Cave.
The cave extends about 700 feet into the side of the mountain. The walls are rich in salt, and animals such as elephants have gone deep into the cave for centuries in search of the salt. The elephants use their tusks to break off pieces of the cave wall that they then chew and swallow, there is also a lot of guano (excrement) deeper in the cave from fruit-eating and carnivorous bats. Sadly, there is also a deep crevasse, which is filled with mummified young, baby elephants that have fallen in to it and were unable to get out.

While visiting the cave, the man and woman woke hundred of bats. The man either had a cut or other open wound, before entering the cave or he may have cut his hand on the cave‚Äôs salt crystals, but he somehow got guano from the fruit-eating bats into an open wound.

The man went home. He gets a headache several days later. Then a few days after that a severe backache, along with the severe headache. He stays home from work. By the 10th day he is nauseated, feverish and vomits so much he only has the dry heaves. His coworkers go to his house to check on him and take him to the local hospital.

Noted on the hospital records:
Patient Passive, He has an ‚Äúexpressionless‚Äù look. When asked to follow a light his eyes do not move side to side. The whites of the eyes are blood red. Skin is yellow with red spots. Memory loss but not delirious.

Unable to diagnose him, and in a move that will stun the world, they gave him antibiotics and told him to get on the first flight he could arrange and go to Nairobi Hospital.

On the flight. He was even more nauseated and everyone on the plane notices his condition.
He continues to vomit. Now its bright red (fresh blood) with black (coffee ground looking old blood). His eyes become redder. His face starts showing dark bruises as the skin and connective tissue starts to detach from the bone. Massive amounts of blood clots have formed clogging many veins and arteries. This causes a stroke and some brain damage. The vessels in his nose rupture and he has an unstoppable nose bleed.

Everyone on the plane watches him in horror and concern. The stewardess tries to help.

As soon as the plane touches down he is taken by taxi to the hospital. He is still conscious.

He gets to the hospital and has to wait, while he is waiting he gets dizzy, leans over, vomits only bright red blood now, finally losing consciousness, his intestines rip open and he begins to bleed out of every orifice.
The virus now looks for a new host.

The nurses quickly put him on a gurney and take him to see the Doctor.
The doctor only knows that the man is suffering from a massive hemorrhage.
During the initial exam the man stops breathing because he has inhaled the blood into his lungs. His pulse becomes weak and slow. He has now suffered severe brain damage. While trying to look down the man‚Äôs throat he vomits blood on the doctor. The doctor cannot replace the blood the man is losing because every time he tries to insert a needle it leaves an open hole for more blood to leak from.
The man died the next morning with the doctor at his side
He was bleeding from every opening in his body. The ears, eyes, mouth, nose, penis rectum, and IV sites. All of his organs had failed. The doctor did not know how to classify his death. He was buried in a waterproof bag.

9 days after the death of the man, the doctor began to get a terrible headache and backache. He thought that because he was turning 30 it was just aging kind of aches.
The ache moved throughout his body and still he thought nothing significant of it.
When he saw his eyes were turning red he thought it might be malaria, he started taking medicine for malaria. The shot should not have been painful but he noted it was extremely painful. He then got abdominal pain and thought he might have typhoid fever. Although in pain he still took care of his patients at the hospital.
When he started noticing that his face ‚Äúwas expressionless‚Äù he opted for exploratory surgery. During the surgery they could not stop the bleeding.
The doctor appeared to be dying for unknown reasons.
Finally one of the doctors caring for him decided to send the blood for testing of a new virus.

The results come back. A little known deadly virus was found in the doctor‚Äôs blood. The researchers don‚Äôt know much about the Marburg virus. A Biosafety level 4 virus.
This virus is so deadly and contagious that it is only handled with the biosafety hazard suits.

The suits when handling 4 of the deadliest viruses know to man.
Level room 1: Scrubs
Level room 2: socks
Level room 3: Taping of all the clothes together, making a seal beck to ankles. They put on spacesuits with its own air supply. They double glove with special gloves.
They check each other for tears

This is just the beginning of a tale that spanned a few decades

A 17 year old visited the Kitum Cave a few months later and died the same way, massive hemorrhage.

This could have been the end of the world as we know it if it was not contained.

In 2012 a funeral was held for a 3 month old in Uganda. The funeral practices include cleaning the body and dressing the child at home. At the funeral many others held the baby, kissing and cuddling the child one last time before burial. After the funeral 14 people died of the Ebola virus.

The Ebola virus reacts the same way as the Marburg virus and is also a Biosafety level 4 virus.

During one outbreak, the virus killed everyone in the operating room during an operation to remove an appendix from a man carrying the virus. There were also many patients admitted to the hospital with the same symptoms, including nuns that had worked at small clinics in the rain forest. Most of the hospital staff fled and didn‚Äôt come back to work. Doctors were seen carrying caskets to a communal grave to burn the bodies.

Currently there are 4 viruses that are are Biosafety Level 4 agents. Ebola, Marburg, Ravn, These viruses are extremely dangerous to humans, Highly infectious, high fatality rate, with no known treatments or cures.

There are other viruses that are ‚Äúrelatives‚Äù to these. Reston virus for one‚Ä¶.
Named because it was found in Reston Virginia. Less than 15 miles from Washington DC. It was found in a monkey house, 100s of monkeys were infected and euthanized immediately.
Monkey houses are near most research centers. And are used for testing because they are the closest to humans in DNA. Most of the time the Monkey houses are run by people not related to the research facilities. The houses typically have their own monkey doctors. And can hold 100s to thousands of imported monkeys, The most common monkey used for research is the rhesus macaqu

It is believed that Aids, Ebola, Marburg, Rvan, Reston originated from monkeys.
And spread all over the world by transporting the monkeys for research,
There is a similar fever that monkeys get, Simian Hemorrhagic Fever that mimics all the viruses mentioned. Most monkey handlers assume that is what the monkey die of.

So....what if?
On october 1, 2013
Colette

That was a very good story Deb, but I think that the HIV is actually a Biosafety Level 4 agent very much like filoviruses like the Ebola virus and the Marburg virus, as there is no known available cure for it. Too bad it was posted after the deadline, but it was very nice story anyway .
On october 1, 2013
Deblyn
Dances with zombies

HIV is not a level 4....it is not airbourne and you can't get it by touch Working with aids patients, which I have many times. We only need gloves unless they are actively bleeding. Or we accidently stick ourselves with a needle we used on them.

Level 4s are viruses so deadly that they have to be secured in negative pressure rooms. Only highly trained personnel have access to the rooms.
That is why I listed the steps for entering a room in a biohazard "spacesuit"

truth is worse than fiction sometimes.

And its ok about the deadline. I liked writing about this.
On october 1, 2013
Colette

Well, I'm not an expert on the subject, but I had read that level 4 agents are highly contagious and deadly (with no available effective cures), but not necessarily both at the same time. And also, the protocols of health workers that work with those patients are different, as an airborne-transmitted virus requires more safety procedures than one that is not. Then again, I might be wrong . But the story was very nice .

By the way, to our impatient contestants, judging is going on. Please be patient .

MadDonut

Agh! Sorry! Sorry! Sorry!

Bit late on the judgings, but here it is!

Round 1 Results
The Circle of Life and Death by Jean-Ralphio - 269/300
The Completionist by DJ-Crystal - 257/300
Cubically Contained by SaucyemmettC - 215/300
Saint Crow's by Winness - 146/300



Overall Leaderboard
1st - Jean-Ralphio 265
2nd - DJ-Crystal 263.5
3rd - SaucyemmettC 255
4th - Macs96 229.5
5th - Winness 156



Now onto round three! The final round!

Round three's theme:
Chaos
Panic, madness, craze. Terrorizing thoughts to those who seek order and delightful thoughts to those who don't. To be in it is one of the most horrid experiences ever, requiring split-second timing that often isn't even fast enough to keep up with the craze. From farther away, however, it can be devilishly amusing to see the complex ripple of chaos happen to a collection of people.


Round Three ends on:
October 12th, 2013.

On october 5, 2013
Jean-Ralphio

may i ask what the annotations after our name mean in the rankings?
On october 5, 2013
Blaire

The star indicates winning a round, which boosts your total score by 5 points. The speech bubble indicates participating in a round, which boosts your total ranking by 10.
On october 5, 2013
MadDonut

The icons?

's represent all the rounds you've participated in and are worth +10 points after all of your story's scores are averaged.

's represent all the rounds you've won and are worth +5 points after all of your story's scores are averaged.

EDIT: Ninja'd by Blaire.
On october 9, 2013
Jean-Ralphio

I found this weeks topic to be particularly challenging but i think I managed to tell a unique, yet familiar story.
I call it... Lures of our Lives
On october 9, 2013
Jean-Ralphio

Oh god.
They‚Äôre going to eat me alive.
It‚Äôs all I could think about today. Milk colored eyes and broken teeth desiring my flesh. They breached the gates yesterday and pounded at my door all night. When I finally left my barricade the sun was bright and hot, a deceptively perfect day to be enjoyed by me and seven others.
Without a word we got busy pouring what little water we had left on the festering remains of our past friends. I let the others repair our defenses, while I curled to a corner and cried. They‚Äôre going to eat me alive. They‚Äôre going to eat me alive.
They are going to eat me‚Ä¶ alive!
Alive.
There‚Äôs still time‚Ä¶ 7 minutes to midnight. The thought invaded my conscious like an army of groaning monsters exploit a hole in the towns wall, slow at first but quickly filling every void, devouring any other thought. That old school isn‚Äôt too far away, I can make it there. I know I can.
This town is nothing but breathing bait. Warm bread for the undead. Seven fools begging to be watered in the morning.
I can do it. They won‚Äôt stop me. It‚Äôs not too far away.
Quick as a snap I uncurl and run to the ‚Äòbank‚Äô. They all spent the day repairing our impressive walls with makeshift armements, impressive for sure but it won‚Äôt stop the fiends, the breathing bait will be tired and no one bothered opening the gates this morning. So they are probably all holed up in their fortresses of broken wood and rusted metal.
Yeah‚Ä¶ yeah‚Ä¶ YEAH! They want us alive, they want the living. If I give them living they won‚Äôt bother me.
‚ÄòI‚Äôll need water‚Äù I whisper as I rummage our pile of resources. ‚ÄúLots of water who knows how long until i find a safer town.‚Äù
I could carry maybe a weeks worth. The well has been dried for 2 days now but there should be some in our towns collective ‚Äòbank‚Äô.
‚ÄúWhat are you doing here, Amanda?‚Äù My head jerks up and I see some talking bait. He has a shopping cart filled with food and batteries, and over his shoulder: a battery launcher, it‚Äôs screws and bolts loose from use and neglect.
‚ÄúKy!‚Äù I‚Äôve been caught! but so has he, I think of a convincing lie but before i can say it he levels the gun to me. I sigh. ‚ÄúLook we can fend off more demons of the desert if we go together. There are 2 weeks worth of water here, we can get to another town in a week‚Äù
I don‚Äôt like the way his face looks. But he lowers the gun from his cheek. The bait still points it at me though. ‚ÄúAmanda where were you thinking of going?‚Äù
Far off in the desert a chorus of moans alert us to the time. ‚ÄúThe Library! we can get there in five minutes if we leave NOW‚Äù The lure nods and slings his gun behind him and helps me load all my water into his cart. I grab myself a machete from the bank and we run toward the gates.
They are heavy but we push them open and stare into the sands. The bait points and runs toward the library slowing the progression of monsters as he advances. Wasting all my batteries on beasts that won‚Äôt hurt us! I keep my machete close as i know I will need it soon.
When we arrived at the safety of the library we only had maybe 30 seconds to secure ourselves. That stupid undead enticement started finding anything he could to help board the doors. I loading my equipment into the moldy building.
And then we saw oblivion. A legion of zombies coming from all around intent on my old home. A box of snacks for those zombies. ‚ÄúAmanda it‚Äôs time!‚Äù I nod and run toward the newly reinforced doors. A zombie breaks its course suddenly and sees the piece of meat named Ky. Hobbling toward him the monster groans.
But it is prepared, and fires a battery at the predator and it‚Äôs head snaps off its neck. The body doesn‚Äôt seem to know that yet though as it continues to advance.
Running now, I grip my machete over my head. It‚Äôs surprisingly sharp but I‚Äôll need all the strength i have. Fresh meat screams as I remove his arm from his shoulder. He falls to the sand in pain and shock. I run past him kicking his arm as far from the library as I can.
‚ÄúNO AMANDA!!! NO!!‚Äù I slam the door behind me and breath deep. I can hear the agony of my bait. ‚ÄúKILL ME AMANDA KILL ME!!!!‚Äù
Panting I push my supplies to the middle of the library, the wheel creaks and my heart pounds but I can still hear that stupid lure.
‚ÄúAMANDA! YOU HAVE TO KILL ME! THEY‚ÄôRE GOING TO EAT ME ALIVE!‚Äù
On october 12, 2013
SanguinisRose

The Howl of Serpents

Sabrina sat next to the water pump, the last drop of water seemed to have been taken from it a day ago. The gentle breeze of hot sand making her thirst even worse, so she stayed next to the pump. It was surrounded by a small brick wall to keep the sand from getting into the well when it was just a well. Licking her lips she settled back, relaxing was all she could do, wait for dehydration or for more water. The cold night would be the only comfort in the next few hours as the heat became visible, like the rising heat off of a stove, it made the smell of bacon come to her mind. It was a lingering memory, not even worth mentioning from before the zombies, from before towns.

Silence moved in, the town becoming less productive as the day went on, a few people heading out of the town in search of water. She wondered how many would come back, its been eighteen days since they put up the walls so the zombies were gathering. Each person had along with them a battery launcher, and one a black tabby that seemed scared out of its mind. The cats seemed to be the key to their survival, natural predators to the zombies, it didn't make sense, but neither did the decomposition rate of the zombies should water get splashed on them. It was just knowledge that they had, it didn't need to make sense anymore, just needed to work. She held her glare too long though, the cat now staring at her its yellow eyes like devilish gateways to hell, and she looked away quickly, though not quick enough to swear that it smiled at her. She shivered at this thought, one of her fears since she was a kid, the zombies didn't even startle her as much as the cat that was being taken with them.

The full moon drifted slowly along in the in the starless night, and she frowned at it brooding over the lack of communication. They had not returned, she felt relieved that the tabi wasn't back but loosing more people was never worth the death of a cat. It was hours after the zombies left that one man came back, letting out a sigh of relief she saw what he was holding and gasped. It was a blue flame. How could someone hold on to fire? The question stood as a man, wearing an orange mask that she had only seen once before, but she had assumed long dead.

He leaned forward, what she assumed from her perspective to sniff it before he moved back raising a single hand in the air, "This... is a man's soul, collect more because tonight we shall have rain. If you bring me a map, I can show you where others are my body senses more."

The sky broke suddenly as he held the soul above his head, his body convulsing as if stuck by lightning the flame dissipated into the area, the strange man started to dance in the absence of it. A miracle happened that night, its touch so cold it burned a bit in contrast to the desert heat, you could see the dirt and grime of despair being washed away by the water, a new light of hope in people's eyes.

The days passed on, the zombie horde pressing ever vigilant at the town's gates, and for the first three days the supply of souls was coming in like clockwork. Friendships where now started to be formed again as everything seemed to be going well once more. Sabrina smiled softly, and waved back to Alexander as he left the gate each day, his blue bandanna covering the top of his head. He had told her the night prior that she was his only reason for coming back to the camp, he had everything when he was out there except her.

His dog always looked a bit jealous when they were together, and seemed a bit overly excited to leave the city when they did. She knew not to make attachments, it was one of the first unwritten rules that they had in this town, but there was no helping it the heart wanted what the heart wanted.

The Fith day came, the Shaman, as we have now started calling him, pointed out the next soul that our expedition team had to find. It was in a troubling spot since our watchtower had told us that over twenty zombies were in the area. As the talks of plans settled, a haunted ghost of a cat hissed as Alexander walked out with it, holding it in his arms wrapped in a blanket. The black cat was missing an ear, and an eye, its body twisting as if trying to kill all of us as it started at the group its eyes blazing in fury. My body physically recoiled at the sight of it as Alexander walked into the center of the group volunteering himself for the expedition. Four others volunteered themselves, and headed out without a word otherwise, Alexander giving Sabrina a reassuring smile as he headed out.

No communication, she thought as the gates to the town closed, the horde trying to slam themselves against the wall as the lock settled in. They had not returned at the same time they usually do, and the look of despair on the last ten of our faces you could see our thoughts. We had assumed this would work, just like every day prior, no one doubted Alexander's expeditions, no one doubted his capabilities, but truth was now settling in.

Two days passed, and the town had given up hope on the expedition ever returning, it was then that something seemed to snap inside of Sabrina. A smile ran along her face as she knew exactly what to do, and started to plan inside of her tent.

As the next day came someone had found a soul, laying in the center of the town blood smeared across the ground and dragged to the gates before disappearing. The record books had seemed to have been tampered with, no one knowing who was now gone till a headcount was done. A man, in his late thirties was now missing, Baldy was his nickname here though he always joked that he was just taller then his hair. Blood covered his tent, splashed like decorations, it wasn't too hard to imagine that Baldy was dead, the final nail was the blue flame in the center.

It was chaos, the world broke that moment, you could almost see it as all trust for the town became accusing eyes looking from one another. As darkness settled in, and the zombies were heard in the distance, they all heard something that chilled their bones. A howl responding to the zombie's cries, it was the sound that a wolf would make in the stories of their youth. They knew that wolves no longer existed in these wastelands, but something didn't settle right even if it was a human that made that sound.

As the sun rose, four more were gone, three from the wall and one laying dead his corpse turn to shreds the only thing that identified the man was his head. Laying on the ground staring into nothing as his hallow eyes seemed to smile at you, their only chance of survival, the shaman. Sabrina felt a little disappointed seeing the man behind the mask, his face not looking like something that her mind had fictionally made, not as fantastic, he was an ordinary man. Pudgy cheeks seemed to be slightly bloated, and his hair was darkened by the dirt layered in it, someone had taken quite a time to make sure his eyes settled on you the moment you walked into his tent.

She looked around suddenly, and realized how little were left in the village, only five of them still remained. All eyes were cast to each other, knowing that it had to be one of us six that had murdered Baldy, and the shaman. It would be tonight that the final wave of zombies would descend upon them, they knew time was up at the sight of the shaman. So they waited, in silence, they waited for their death to come upon them. Conversations began to idly sprout among them as they looked to the sunset, a smile softly coming to Sabrina's lips seeing the beautiful blood red of the sun. ‚ÄúIf only I could cover this world with this...‚Äù She mumbled to herself, it was the last thing she remembered.

They should have seen it, the change in her body language, the confidence that she now showed even with her impending death. She had pulled out a knife, which they assumed was to slaughter the zombies as she got turned into one of them. They didn't notice the blood dried at the handle, or the look of hunger as she spoke to them until it was too late to do anything. When the zombies came they would be disappointed, only one woman standing in a crimson garden of organs her eyes ablaze with madness as she howled to the full moon. Sabrina was gone, there was only the Queen of the Damned, the Lady of Lies, the Serpent's tongue.
On october 12, 2013
SaucyemmettC

Bing A Ling Ching Ding Boom Boom Boom

As the last lights faded all Billy Little could see from the slit of his tent was the town gate. It was quite a ways away, but Billy could see it. He stared at it thoughtfully. Is tonight the night? Billy was fascinated with death. He had died one-hundred-and-two times to zombies, sixty-seven times to infection, thirty-two times to cyanide, nineteen times to drug withdrawal, twelve times to dehydration, and four times to hangings. Billy was always looking for new ways to die. He had once jumped from the watchtower, but was caught halfway down by the crow. Billy liked the crow. Billy would often follow the crow around, knowing quite well where the crow was leading him.

CrooooAAAAAoooooo

Billy left his tent and immersed himself in the night, and looked straight up knowing quite well the crow would be flying directly above him. Billy waved to the crow.

CrooooAAAAAoooooo

The crow flew toward the gate; it‚Äôs black feathers disappearing into the night sky so that only its glowing red eyes could be seen. Billy locked his vision on the crow and followed. Billy had been bored with his last few deaths. He had tried jumping in a well, but the crow caught him and flew him out. He had tried slitting his wrists, but his skin grew back faster than he could cut. He had tried shooting himself in the head with a battery launcher, but had only received a headache. But the crow had summoned him from his tent this night, and Billy new the crow had something special in store for him. The crow always did. Once the crow had led him into the dessert far enough so that Billy died of dehydration. Billy had never thought of doing that before. Also, the crow had led Billy to open the gates seconds before thee attack. The zombies slammed into him like a tidal wave breaking every bone in his body. The last time the crow had led Billy, he brought him to a house where he had suffocated and died. Billy was ecstatic on where the crow would lead him tonight.

CrooooAAAAAoooooo

The crow shot into the town bank. Billy followed. Inside was a mess of random knick-knacks and animals. Tables of tools and boxes of food piled up against the walls like ivy. A few pigs and rats were in cages, and two giant rats were strapped to a post. The bank was illuminated by a single lantern, which hung in the middle of the room. The crow was standing on a table with semtex and detonators. Billy‚Äôs eye‚Äôs lit up. ‚ÄúThank you Mr Crow you‚Äôre a genius why have I never thought of blowing myself up!‚Äù

CrooooAAAAAoooooo

Susan Goodman hated that noise. The noise of the winged demon that plagued her eternal damnation. She watched the entrance to the bank as the last light faded from the sky. There was only a minute left of light. Her breaths started growing deeper. I don‚Äôt want to die anymore. Susan feared death, she loathed pain. Life was only prolonged death, but she planned on prolonging it as long as she could, hopefully forever.

CrooooAAAAAoooooo

There it was again. The chime of hells bells themselves. She shuddered in horror at the thought of what that ghastly monstrosity was doing here tonight. She considered poking her head out of her tent and searching for the monster, but was scared of a quote her brother had once told her. Be careful of noticing things. For when you notice something, it may notice you. She wished her brother were here now. He was much braver and stronger and wiser than she could ever be. She hadn‚Äôt seen him in an uncountable number of lifetimes.

CrooooAAAAAoooooo

She gasped in horror as the black beast shot into the town bank. Her mouth hung agape in horror. She lay frozen staring out of the slit of her tent, doubts starting to creep into her conscience. No‚Ä¶ No‚Ä¶ Just a trick of the mind‚Ä¶ But then a man she didn‚Äôt recognize entered the bank. The darkness had fallen quickly, and the man wore it like a cloak, masking his identity in it. Oh dear. What could he and the crow be up to? Maybe he was chasing the crow, maybe he was trying to capture or kill it. She crawled along her stomach out of her tent. Maybe he needed help. Maybe they could get rid of this monster once and for all. With her brother‚Äôs face in her mind, she skulked toward the town‚Äôs bank.

CrooooAAAAAoooooo

Lewis Crysler removed his eye from his peeking hole to scan the sky. The bird had shouted a word, and he feared the word might be shouting it at him. The night hadn‚Äôt quite settled across the land yet and he was still visible, but he couldn‚Äôt contain himself. He squatted beside his first victim‚Äôs tent. He had been fantasizing about it for days. Ever since that thing he found in the desert, he had been dreaming of this night. At first he was disgusted by his thoughts, but soon he was consumed by his desire to consume. He had been watching her all day, and when she ducked inside her tent to rest for the night he had moved in for the kill.

CrooooAAAAAoooooo

Another demand. Lewis rose a bit higher to get a better look at the sky. The sun had completely disappeared and the world had gone black. Lewis kept looking into the sky but didn‚Äôt see the bird. He shrunk himself back up beside her tent and stuck his eye back into the hole he had chewed while she was away earlier in the day. She lay perfectly still and had her ears perked up as if trying to listen to something. Fuck is she on to me.

CrooooAAAAAoooooo

No no‚Ä¶ She‚Äôs listening to the call of the crow. He watched as she lay there, almost perfectly still, only her back rose and shrank slightly from each breath. He started to dribble. The hot saliva was sweet. All of a sudden she went rigid, her entire body locked up and she gasped quietly. Lewis copied her; afraid he had made a mistake. He watched her stay like that for six seconds, and then saw her relax. He let out a quiet sigh of relief. Sleep sleep little sheep Lewis Crysler wants your meat. His eyes bulged in horror as she moved, slowly slithering into the blanket of darkness outside. Lewis watched as she slowly rose and made her way toward the town bank. He stalked silently behind her licking his teeth in anticipation.

CrooooAAAAAoooooo

Brandon Bigfeet stopped for a second, a chill running up his spine. The shriek of the crow always meant something VERY wrong was about to happen. He considered abandoning his ploy, but decided he had made it too far to quit at the sound of one bad omen. After all he couldn‚Äôt possibly be the only one with something to do on a night as dark as this. The shriek was probably for some other sorry schmuck. Brandon slipped into the bank just as the jaws of darkness sank into the earth. He lit the lamp with a match he had stolen a day ago, and began rummaging through the bank. I‚Äôll need a weeks worth of food and water, the chainsaw and machete, maybe a pig

CrooooAAAAAoooooo

Brandon ignored the shriek. He couldn‚Äôt waste a second, if he was caught stealing from the bank he would be hung. His partner had been caught two nights ago, and when Brandon had looted his house he had found the map. All he needed was the resources to get there. He began throwing supplies into his ultra-rucksack and shopping trolley.

CrooooAAAAAoooooo

Again Brandon ignored the now closer shriek. Where‚Äôs that machete. It was here yesterday why is this place so disorganized‚Ä¶ Just then the crow darted in through the open doorway. Brandon yipped in surprise then dove into a crate. HOLY FUCKING SHIT HOLY FUCKING HELL IT‚ÄôS HERE FOR ME NO NO NO WHY ME WHY ME SHIIIIIIIT. He pulled the machete out from behind his back, finding it in the crate. He heard a single set of footsteps walk across the wood floor. ‚ÄúThank you Mr Crow you‚Äôre a genius why have I never thought of blowing myself up!‚Äù Brandon lifted his head out of the crate and watched the man fiddle with something on one of the tables. The crow was nowhere in sight. Brandon crept out of the crate, machete in hand, intent on finding the X on the map.

‚ÄùFREEZE MOTHERFUCK-‚Äú
CHOMP
"AHHHHH"
BOOOM

The crow watched from the top of the gate as his rewards were given out. Billy achieved his new and creatively painful death. Susan would meet her brother again in her next life. Lewis took a bite out of his long-lusted meal. And the explosion had shot Brandon‚Äôs unconscious body to the Oasis he and his partner had found a map to. But for those who had not acted upon the call of the crow, who had not exploited such a dark night, they would suffer the breakdown of one more town. The crow watched as the tiny people below him scrambled to loot the falling debris of the bank, and put out the fires of the explosion. Poor pitiful fools‚Ä¶ Chaos had come‚Ä¶
